questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
1. Greater auricular nerve
    • This nerve provides sensation to the ear lobe and posterior auricle.
    • So, the correct match is Skin over the ear lobe and posterior auricle.
  2. Auriculotemporal nerve
    • This nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), provides sensation to the external ear and the temporal region.
    • So, the correct match is External ear and temporal region.
  3. Auricular branch of the vagus nerve
    • Also known as Arnold's nerve, it provides sensation to the external acoustic meatus and auricle.
    • So, the correct match is External acoustic meatus and auricle.
  4. Lesser occipital nerve
    • This nerve provides sensation to the posterior auricle and the skin over the occipital region.
    • So, the correct match is Skin over the occipital region.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with dyspnea and palpitation. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease. ECG of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tall, peaked T waves and a wide QRS complex on ECG in a CKD patient are classic features of hyperkalemia.

  • Hyperkalemia, defined as a serum potassium level above 0-5.5 mEq/L, is commonly associated with impaired renal excretion, especially in chronic kidney disease (CKD).
  • As kidney function deteriorates, the ability to eliminate potassium declines, predisposing patients to elevated potassium levels.
  • Clinically significant hyperkalemia (usually >6.5 mEq/L) can present with muscle weakness, arrhythmias, or even cardiac arrest.
  • The most important and potentially fatal complication is its effect on cardiac conduction.
  • ECG is therefore the initial and most crucial test when hyperkalemia is suspected.
  • Typical ECG findings include:
    • Peaked T waves
    • Flattened or absent P waves
    • Prolonged PR interval
    • Widened QRS complex
  • These changes reflect increasing potassium levels and cardiac instability.
  • Causes of hyperkalemia:
  • Treatment algorithm of hyperkalemia:

Explanation of other options:

Hypokalemia (Option B): Typically causes ECG changes like U waves, flattened T waves, ST depression, and prolonged QT interval, which are not present in this case.

Hypocalcemia (Option C): Leads to QT interval prolongation due to delayed ventricular repolarization, which is not seen in this ECG.

Hypercalcemia (Option D): Characterized by a shortened QT interval from a reduced ST segment; again, not consistent with this ECG finding.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470284/

questions.text: A patient presenting with sciatica exhibits tenderness in the hamstring muscles. Which of the following nerves innervates a hybrid muscle that remains unaffected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is the Obturator nerve, as it supplies the adductor part of the hybrid muscles and remains unaffected in this condition.

  • Sciatica involves the sciatic nerve (L4-S3), which supplies the hamstrings (except for the short head of biceps femoris).
  • The adductor magnus is a hybrid muscle with dual innervation:
    • Adductor part → Obturator nerve (L2-L4)
    • Hamstring part → Tibial nerve (L4-S3)
  • Since the tibial nerve is affected in sciatica, the hamstring part of the adductor magnus is involved, but the adductor part (supplied by the obturator nerve) is spared.

Explanation for other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A): Incorrect because it supplies the rectus femoris, which is not relevant to sciatica.

Common peroneal nerve (Option B): Incorrect because it supplies the short head of biceps femoris, which can be affected in sciatica.

Tibial nerve (Option D) Incorrect because it is part of the sciatic nerve, meaning it is affected in this patient.

questions.text: A pediatric patient presents with a completely displaced supracondylar fracture of the humerus, confirmed on X-ray. Which classification is used for this type of fracture, and what is its stage?
questions.solution:
Gartland type 3 refers to a completely displaced supracondylar fracture of the humerus in children, with no cortical contact, and is the most unstable type.

  • The Gartland classification is the most widely used system for categorizing supracondylar fractures of the humerus in children, which are among the most common pediatric elbow fractures.

Gartland Classification:


  • Gartland Type 3 fractures are unstable, often with soft tissue swelling and risk of neurovascular injury. Prompt orthopedic management is necessary.

Explanation of other options:

Gartland 2 (Option B): Indicates partial displacement with intact posterior hinge-less severe than type 3.

Salter-Harris 3 (Option C): Involves a fracture through the physis and epiphysis, extending into the joint, used for physeal injuries, not supracondylar fractures.

Salter-Harris 2 (Option D): Fracture through the physis and metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis, again, unrelated to supracondylar fractures.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with hyperthermia, autonomic instability, confusion, hyperreflexia, muscle rigidity, and dilated pupils. He has been taking sertraline and was recently prescribed amitriptyline and sumatriptan for depression and migraines, respectively. Which medication is most likely to be effective in treating his current condition?
questions.solution:
Cyproheptadine, a serotonin receptor antagonist, is the treatment of choice for serotonin syndrome, which is suggested by this patient's clinical features and drug history.

  • This patient presents with classic signs of serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition caused by excessive serotonergic activity in the CNS.
  • Key features include:
    • Mental status changes: confusion, agitation
    • Neuromuscular hyperactivity: hyperreflexia, clonus, rigidity
    • Autonomic instability: tachycardia, diaphoresis, hyperthermia
    • Mydriasis (dilated pupils)
  • Precipitating factors in this case:
    • Sertraline (SSRI): increases serotonin by inhibiting reuptake
    • Amitriptyline (TCA): inhibits serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake
    • Sumatriptan: 5-HT1B/1D agonist, may exacerbate serotonergic effects when combined with SSRIs or TCAs
  • Management of Serotonin Syndrome:
    • Discontinue all serotonergic agents
    • Supportive care: IV fluids, benzodiazepines for agitation
    • Cyproheptadine: a 5-HT2A receptor antagonist, is used orally in moderate to severe cases and helps reverse the serotonergic toxicity

Explanation of other options:

Propranolol (Option B): Non-selective beta-blocker. Can worsen hypotension or mask signs of autonomic instability. Not used in serotonin syndrome.

Diphenhydramine (Option C): An H1-antihistamine; not effective against serotonergic activity. May worsen confusion or sedation.

Nitroprusside (Option D): A vasodilator used for hypertensive emergencies; not indicated here. The hypertension in serotonin syndrome is best managed with supportive care and cyproheptadine if needed

questions.text: A patient with prolonged intubation complained of respiratory distress. Which of the following staging systems is used to stage the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The Cotton-Meyer classification is used for staging post-intubation tracheal stenosis, which can develop due to prolonged intubation, leading to respiratory distress. This classification helps assess the severity of tracheal injury and stenosis caused by mechanical ventilation.

Cotton-Meyer Classification of Subglottic Stenosis

  • Used to classify subglottic stenosis based on cross-sectional airway obstruction.
  • Originally developed for pediatric patients, but now applied to adults.
  • Can be supplemented with letters (a-d) based on the number of laryngeal subsites involved.
  • Severe comorbidities or congenital abnormalities are marked with a '+' sign.
  • Idiopathic laryngotracheal stenosis (iLTS) commonly presents as Grade I-II stenosis.
  • iSGS (idiopathic subglottic stenosis) often occurs in women and presents with a higher grade of stenosis.

Explanation for other options:

Radkowski classification (Option B): Incorrect because the Radkowski classification is used for tracheal injuries, but it is not the primary staging system for post-intubation tracheal stenosis.

TNM classification (Option C): Incorrect because TNM is a staging system used for cancers (such as lung cancer) and does not apply to respiratory issues caused by prolonged intubation.

AJCC classification (Option D): Incorrect because the AJCC classification is primarily used for cancer staging and does not apply to conditions like tracheal stenosis caused by intubation.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7139051/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8892813/

questions.text: A patient complains of pain radiating down the posterior thigh and leg following a heavy lifting episode. Which spinal nerve root is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The S1 nerve root is most commonly associated with pain radiating down the posterior leg, including the hamstring and calf muscles.

  • The patient is presenting with pain in the back of the thigh and leg after lifting heavy weights, which is consistent with sciatica-like pain.
  • The S1 root is responsible for innervating the muscles of the posterior thigh and the calf, and it is often affected in cases of sciatica, particularly after heavy lifting or straining.

Explanation for other options:

L4 (Option A): Because L4 is more likely to cause pain radiating to the anterior thigh and knee, rather than the posterior thigh and leg.

L5 (Option B) Because L5 involvement typically causes pain that radiates to the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.

S2 (Option D): While S2 may be involved in some cases of sciatica, S1 is more commonly associated with posterior leg pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used to manage ADHD?
questions.solution:
Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that has been used off-label in the management of ADHD, especially when stimulants are not appropriate.

  • Reboxetine is a non-stimulant antidepressant belonging to the selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) class.
  • It works by inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, thereby increasing its levels in the synaptic cleft.
  • While not first-line for ADHD, reboxetine is occasionally used off-label when stimulant medications (e.g., methylphenidate or amphetamines) are contraindicated-such as in patients with:
    • History of substance abuse
    • Tics or Tourette's syndrome
    • Cardiovascular concerns
  • It may help improve attention and focus through enhanced noradrenergic signaling in the prefrontal cortex.

Explanation of other options:

Modafinil (Option A): A wakefulness-promoting agent used primarily for narcolepsy, obstructive sleep apnea, and shift-work sleep disorder. Though sometimes used off-label in ADHD, it is not an NRI.

Guanfacine (Option C): An alpha-2A adrenergic receptor agonist, used in ADHD treatment, particularly for hyperactivity and impulsivity, but not an NRI.

Methylphenidate (Option D): A CNS stimulant that blocks reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine, but is not selective for norepinephrine, and thus not classified as a selective NRI.

questions.text: What is the typical pressure setting for the valve in a Mapleson circuit?
questions.solution:
The adjustable pressure-limiting (APL) valve in a Mapleson breathing circuit is typically set at 30-40 cm H₂O to allow appropriate control of airway pressure during manual ventilation.

  • The Mapleson circuit is a semi-open anesthetic breathing system used in controlled and spontaneous ventilation.
  • It consists of:
    • Fresh gas flow inlet
    • Corrugated tubing
    • Reservoir bag
    • Adjustable Pressure-Limiting (APL) valve
  • The APL valve is crucial for:
    • Controlling the maximum pressure delivered during manual ventilation
    • Preventing barotrauma by allowing excess gas to escape once a set pressure is reached
    • The typical pressure setting for the APL valve is 30-40 cm H2O, which ensures:
    • Adequate positive pressure during assisted breaths
    • Protection against excessive airway pressure

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with a history of recurrent bleeding undergoes an endoscopic examination, which is given below. What is the investigation of choice (IOC) for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given endoscopic image shows a highly vascular, lobulated, reddish mass in the nasopharynx, which is suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This condition is a benign but highly vascular tumour seen in adolescent males and presents with recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

Investigation of Choice (IOC):

Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT) is the preferred imaging modality for JNA as it:

  • For a highly vascular nasopharyngeal mass in an adolescent male with recurrent epistaxis, CECT is the investigation of choice for diagnosing juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).
  • Identifies tumour extent and bony erosion.
  • Helps in staging and surgical planning.
  • Shows an intensely enhancing mass in the nasopharynx without significant necrosis.

Explanation for other options:

Biopsy (Option B) is incorrect because JNA is highly vascular, and biopsy may cause profuse bleeding, making it contraindicated.

X-ray (Option C) is incorrect because it has low sensitivity and may only show an indirect sign, like bony erosion of the pterygoid plates.

MRI (Option D) is incorrect because while MRI is useful for soft tissue delineation, CECT is preferred for preoperative vascular mapping and bony involvement.

Reference:

  1. https://medicine.uiowa.edu/iowaprotocols/juvenile-nasopharyngeal-angiofibroma

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms plays a key role in preventing polyspermy?
questions.solution:
• Cortical reaction: After the sperm enters the egg, cortical granules in the egg release enzymes that modify the zona pellucida, preventing further sperm from binding and entering the egg, thus preventing polyspermy.

Explanation for other options:

Acrosome reaction (Option A): It helps the sperm penetrate the egg, not prevent polyspermy.

Zona reaction (Option C): Although it helps block other sperm after one has entered, the cortical reaction is the main process preventing polyspermy.

Capacitation (Option D): It enables sperm to fertilise the egg but does not directly prevent polyspermy.

questions.text: A mother brings her daughter to the emergency room after she ingested an unknown substance. The child presents with hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and mydriasis. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Cocaine causes sympathomimetic toxidrome, characterized by hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and mydriasis due to increased catecholamine levels.

  • Cocaine is a powerful CNS stimulant derived from the Erythroxylum coca plant.
  • It is commonly abused for its euphoric and energizing effects.
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Cocaine blocks the reuptake of:
      • Norepinephrine (NE)
      • Dopamine (DA)
      • Serotonin (5-HT)
    • This leads to increased synaptic concentrations of these neurotransmitters, especially norepinephrine, resulting in sympathomimetic stimulation.
  • Clinical Features of Cocaine Toxicity:
    • Hypertension
    • Tachycardia
    • Hyperthermia
    • Mydriasis (dilated pupils)
    • Agitation, seizures, psychosis
    • Chest pain from coronary vasospasm → MI
    • Arrhythmias, sudden death

Explanation of other options:

Heroin (Option A): An opioid that causes miosis, hypotension, and respiratory depression, not the sympathomimetic signs seen here.

Morphine (Option B): Another opioid with similar effects as heroin: miosis, bradycardia, hypotension, and CNS depression.

Chlorpheniramine (Option D): A first-generation antihistamine with sedating and anticholinergic effects (e.g., dry mouth, urinary retention), but not typically associated with hyperthermia and marked cardiovascular stimulation.

questions.text: Which drug is used to reverse the muscle relaxant effects of vecuronium when renal function is normal?
questions.solution:
Sugammadex is a selective binding agent that rapidly and effectively reverses the neuromuscular blockade caused by vecuronium in patients with normal renal function.

  • Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker (aminosteroid class) used for muscle relaxation during anesthesia.
  • It works by competitively inhibiting acetylcholine at nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Sugammadex is a modified gamma-cyclodextrin, specifically designed to encapsulate and inactivate steroid-based neuromuscular blockers like:
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Upon IV administration, Sugammadex forms a tight 1:1 complex with free vecuronium, rapidly reducing its availability at the receptor sites, thus reversing muscle paralysis.
  • Onset of reversal: Within 2-3 minutes
  • Excretion: Renally cleared; use with caution in renal impairment
  • Advantages: No cholinergic side effects, no need for anticholinergic co-administration

Explanation of other options:

Neostigmine (Option B): An acetylcholinesterase inhibitor traditionally used to reverse non-depolarizing blockers, but it is less effective and slower than sugammadex for vecuronium. Requires co-administration with atropine or glycopyrrolate due to muscarinic effects.

Atropine (Option C): A muscarinic antagonist used to counteract the muscarinic side effects of neostigmine, not used alone to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

Physostigmine (Option D): A cholinesterase inhibitor that crosses the blood-brain barrier and is primarily used to reverse central anticholinergic toxicity, not for neuromuscular blockade reversal.

questions.text: An individual found near a railway track presents with dry skin, dilated dry pupils, slurred speech, and altered sensorium. Which of the following substances is the most likely cause of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Datura poisoning is characterised by anticholinergic symptoms such as dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), dry mouth, tachycardia, slurred speech, hallucinations, confusion, and altered sensorium.

  • The patient's symptoms suggest anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds.
  • Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning.
  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centres of the brain and then activates the motor centres. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centres in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat
    • Dysphagia
    • Difficulty in talking
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Flushed face
    • Pupil dilatation
    • Photophobia + Diplopia
    • Agitation and restlessness
    • Delirium
    • Urinary retention
    • Dry and hot skin
    • Exfoliation of the skin may occur
  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

Explanation for other options:

Morphine (Option A): Morphine poisoning typically causes pinpoint pupils (miosis), respiratory depression, and sedation. Dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic features.

Cannabis (Option B): Cannabis intoxication may cause euphoria, altered sensorium, conjunctival injection (red eyes) and increased appetite, but does not present with dry skin, dilated pupils, or the anticholinergic toxidrome seen in this case.

Alcohol (Option D): Alcohol intoxication commonly causes slurred speech and altered sensorium, but it does not result in dry skin or dilated pupils.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Expansion of right somatosensory fibres for the hand into neighbouring areas
Neighbouring fibres of the right somatosensory area extending into the right-hand area
Expansion of the right sensory cortex
Expansion of the left sensory cortex

questions.text: A patient experiences phantom limb pain following the amputation of the right limb. What would a PET scan most likely reveal in such a case?
questions.solution:
• After amputation, the brain undergoes cortical reorganisation.
  • In this case, the neighbouring somatosensory fibres that previously represented adjacent body parts extend into the region that formerly represented the right hand.
  • This reorganisation is associated with the perception of phantom limb pain.

Explanation for other options:

Expansion of right somatosensory fibres for the hand into Neighbouring areas (Option A):

  • Somatosensory fibres specifically responsible for the right hand expand into neighbouring regions.
  • However, it is not the fibres themselves that expand; rather, it is the cortical representation that changes.

Expansion of right sensory cortex (Option C):

  • Implies a general enlargement of the right sensory cortex.
  • However, the expansion is not global; rather, it involves the Neighbouring cortical areas invading the region corresponding to the amputated limb.

Expansion of left sensory cortex (Option D):

  • The left sensory cortex is responsible for processing sensory input from the right side of the body.
  • The reorganisation occurs in the sensory cortex corresponding to the amputated limb (in this case, the right cortex, which processes left-sided sensations).

Key Takeaway:

Phantom Limb Pain

  • Perceived due to cortical plasticity
  • In the phantom limb phenomenon, the limb does not exist (amputated), but the patient complains that he feels pain or itch in the limb.
  • Based on the evidence, brain reorganisation occurs when sensory input is cut off. For example, in leg amputees, the ventral posterior thalamic nucleus can perceive the signal that once received input from the leg and foot, now responds to stump (thigh) stimulation.n

Management :

  1. Epidural Anaesthesia: Used during amputation surgery to reduce acute pain and subsequent need for opioids, lowering phantom pain incidence.
  2. Spinal Cord Stimulation: Electric current stimulates spinal pathways, reducing phantom limb pain and causing a tingling sensation insteadin the phantom limb

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden decrease in vision, photophobia, circumcorneal congestion, and a visible hypopyon. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of sudden vision loss, photophobia (difficulty looking at light), circumcorneal congestion, and hypopyon strongly suggests acute anterior uveitis.

  • Anterior uveitis is characterised by the presence of fine, grey keratic precipitates (KPs) on the corneal endothelium, a hazy anterior chamber (aqueous flare), and a constricted pupil.

Anterior Uveitis

Definition: The most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain
  • Redness
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Serous discharge
  • Blurring and diminished vision

Examination Findings:

  • Keratic Precipitates (KPs):
    • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes
    • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages
    • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humour; this area is known as Arlt's triangle
  • Aqueous Cells:
    • Indicator of active inflammation
  • Aqueous Flare:
    • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues
  • Muddy Iris:
    • Oedema in the iris caused by protein leakage
  • Miosis:
    • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from the inflamed tissue
  • Nodules on the Iris:
    • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis

Complications: (Findings)

  • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to a festooned-shaped pupil
  • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma
  • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens
  • Cyclitic Membrane
  • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris

Explanation for other options:

Acute conjunctivitis (Option A): Conjunctivitis typically presents with diffuse conjunctival redness, watery/mucoid discharge, and itching (especially in allergic conjunctivitis).

Acute angle closure glaucoma (Option B): Presents with severe ocular pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision with halos around lights. The eye appears hazy with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil, not a hypopyon. IOP is significantly elevated (>40 mmHg), which is a distinguishing feature.

Episcleritis (Option C): Episcleritis causes localised redness without circumcorneal congestion or hypopyon. It is not associated with vision loss or photophobia.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image is suggestive of a Limbal dermoid.

Key Features of Limbal Dermoid:

  • Congenital lesion (often present since birth)
  • Located at the limbus (junction of cornea and sclera)
  • Non-progressive
  • May contain hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and connective tissue

Explanation for other options:

Pterygium (Option A): A pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular growth that extends onto the cornea, often due to UV exposure. Unlike limbal dermoid, it is progressive and vascularised.

Pyogenic Granuloma (Option C): Pyogenic granuloma is a vascular, red, pedunculated lesion that occurs after trauma or surgery. Unlike limbal dermoid, it is acquired and highly vascularised.

Pinguecula (Option D): A small, yellowish, raised lesion on the bulbar conjunctiva, usually near the limbus but not encroaching onto the cornea. Unlike limbal dermoid, it is acquired due to UV exposure and is seen in the elderly.

Reference:

  1. New Grading System for Limbal Dermoid: A Retrospective Analysis of 261 Cases Over 10 Years

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with respiratory distress and a history of recurrent respiratory infections. Based on the radiographs provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• CPAM (previously called Congenital Cystic Adenomatoid Malformation) is a developmental lung anomaly characterised by cystic or dysplastic lung tissue.
  • It typically presents in neonates or infants with recurrent respiratory infections and respiratory distress due to abnormal lung development.

Radiological Features:

  1. Chest X-ray (AP View) -Shows cystic mass in the left lower lobe.
  2. CT Chest (Coronal View) -Confirms multiple cystic lesions in the left lower lobe, ruling out other differentials.

AP view of chest radiograph showing left lower lobe CPAM

CT chest (coronal view) showing left lower lobe CPAM

CONGENITAL CYSTIC ADENOMATOID MALFORMATION (CCAM):

Explanation for other options:

Lung abscess (Option A): A lung abscess typically appears on imaging as a thick-walled cavity within the lung, often containing an air-fluid level.

Pyopneumothorax (Option C) will show an air-fluid level, and loss of silhouette with the dome of the diaphragm may be seen.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (Option D): Would show bowel loops in the thoracic cavity with mediastinal shift rather than isolated cystic lung lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included as a component in the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)?
questions.solution:
The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is an indicator used to measure the quality of life or well-being in a country. Unlike the Human Development Index (HDI), which considers economic factors, the PQLI focuses solely on basic physical needs.

EYS = Expected Year of School; MYS = Mean Year of School

choices.text: A cool and dry climate is needed

questions.text: Which of the following statements about adipocere formation is correct?
questions.solution:
Adipocere is a waxy substance formed postmortem due to the hydrolysis and hydrogenation of fat tissues in the body. This process is called saponification.

Adipocere (Saponification or Grave Wax):

  • Formation of fatty acid soap in warm, humid climates or when submerged in water. (Option B, C ruled out)
  • Process: Fatty acids undergo hydrolysis and hydrogenation, forming a waxy substance.
  • Medical Importance:
    • Describes the climate at the time of death.
    • Preserves body tissues for easier identification.
    • Formation takes 3 days to 3 months. (Option D ruled out)
  • Types of adipocere:
    • Fresh: Soft, moist, white, greasy.
    • Old: Dry, hard, brittle, yellow.
  • Absent fetus less than 7 months.

Key Takeaway:

Mummification

  • Occurs in dry, hot climates due to dehydration, preserving the body.
  • Loss of 60-70% body weight over 3-12 months.
  • Intra-uterine death can also result in mummification.
  • Chronic arsenic or antimony poisoning favours the process of mummification
  • Medical Importance:
    • Describes the climate at the time of death.
    • Helps in the determination of time since death (TSD) and easy identification.

questions.text: In cases involving sexual assault, how is the testimony of a female victim typically recorded in court?
questions.solution:
Under Section 327 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) in India, sexual assault cases mandate in-camera proceedings to ensure confidentiality and protect the victim from public scrutiny.

Explanation for other options:

Open court proceedings (Option A): In sexual assault cases, the privacy of the victim is prioritised, and open court proceedings are avoided to protect the victim's identity and dignity.

Closed court proceedings (Option B): While closed court proceedings ensure limited public access, they are not as specific or protective as hearings conducted on camera.

Hearing in a different location (Option C): While certain situations might necessitate a different location for the hearing, it is not the standard protocol for recording evidence in sexual assault cases.

Reference

  1. Legal changes towards justice for sexual assault victims
  2. https://www.indiacode.nic.in/show-data?actid=AC_CEN_3_20_00051_190805_1523340333624&orderno=166
  3. https://www.indiacode.nic.in/show-data?actid=AC_UP_88_469_000010_000010_1600861667761&orderno=6

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents as calm and charming in front of a psychiatrist. However, he engages in aggressive behaviour towards friends, frequently skips classes, disregards traffic rules, and has been involved in a police interrogation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Persistent disregard for social rules, impulsivity, aggression, and lack of remorse strongly suggest Antisocial Personality Disorder.

  • Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) is a Cluster B personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others.
  • The diagnosis requires that this pattern has been present since age 15 (preceded by Conduct Disorder) and persists into adulthood.
  • Key Diagnostic Features of ASPD:
    • Frequent law-breaking, deceitful, and impulsive behaviour
    • Aggressiveness and irritability
    • Lack of remorse
    • Disregard for safety of self or others (e.g., skipping classes, breaking traffic rules)
    • Superficially charming or manipulative demeanor
  • These individuals often come into conflict with the law and are commonly involved in criminal investigations.
  • Treatment:
    • Psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), contingency management
    • Medications: Antipsychotics, mood stabilizers (e.g., lithium), β-blockers (for aggression)

Explanation of other options:

Narcissistic Personality Disorder (Option B): Characterized by grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy, but not commonly associated with aggression, criminal behaviour, or repeated rule-breaking.

Schizotypal Personality Disorder (Option C): Involves eccentric behaviour, odd beliefs, and social anxiety, but not aggression or legal troubles.

Paranoid Personality Disorder (Option D): Involves distrust and suspicion of others' motives without justification, not impulsivity or aggressive rule-breaking.

questions.text: A professional singer reports difficulty producing high-pitched notes. Examination reveals bowing of the right vocal cord. Which of the following muscles is most likely impaired?
questions.solution:
• The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensioning and elongating the vocal cords, which helps in adjusting pitch. Damage to this muscle can result in difficulty in achieving higher pitches, leading to symptoms like hoarseness or difficulty singing at high pitches.


Explanation for other options:

Posterior cricoarytenoid (Option A): This muscle abducts (opens) the vocal cords, which is not related to high-pitch singing or vocal cord bowing.

Lateral cricoarytenoid (Option B): It adducts (closes) the vocal cords, and it does not affect pitch in the same way as the cricothyroid muscle.

Thyroarytenoid (Option D): It is involved in relaxing the vocal cords, which lowers the pitch and does not contribute to high-pitch singing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient diagnosed with homocystinuria reports joint pain and muscle weakness. Supplementation with which vitamin is beneficial in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Homocystinuria is often due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, which requires Vitamin B6 as a cofactor. Supplementing with Vitamin B6 can help reduce homocysteine levels and alleviate symptoms like joint pain and weakness.

Homocystinuria:


Explanation for other options:

Vitamin B12 (Option B) deficiency causes type 2 homocystinuria, but there will be additional symptoms of neurological manifestation due to lack of adenosyl B12 and accumulation of methylmalonic acid.

Vitamin B1 (Option C) Thiamine deficiency typically presents with symptoms related to the nervous system, such as peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular abnormalities, and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Vitamin B7 (Option D) Biotin deficiency causes hair thinning, alopecia, brittle nails prone to splitting or breaking and neurological manifestations since biotin is required for decarboxylases containing enzymes.

Reference:

  1. Adenosylcobalamin
  2. Methylcobalamin

questions.text: Which of the following diseases follows the mode of inheritance shown below?
questions.solution:
• The above pedigree shows an X-linked recessive inheritance, which can be seen with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.
  • Males (XY) express the disorder if they inherit the affected X chromosome since they lack a second X for compensation.
  • Females (XX) can be carriers if they inherit one affected X chromosome, often showing no symptoms due to the normal allele on the other X.
  • Affected males cannot pass the disorder to their sons, but can pass the affected X to daughters, making them carriers.

Explanation for other options:

Wilson disease (Option B) is an autosomal recessive disorder involving the ATP7B gene mutation.

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) (Option C) occurs due to paternal deletion and maternal imprinting of the SNORP gene on chromosome 15q. A subset of PWS can also occur due to maternal disomy.

Achondroplasia (Option D) is an autosomal dominant disorder involving the FGFR3 gene mutation.

questions.text: A soldier presents with fever, rash, and neck stiffness. Lab tests indicate a deficiency in the membrane attack complex (MAC). Which organism is most likely responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
Neisseria meningitidis is the likely cause of bacterial meningitis. The symptoms of fever, rash, and neck rigidity, combined with the deficiency in the membrane-attacking complex, are consistent with this diagnosis.

Explanation for other options:

Neisseria gonorrhoea (Option B) primarily affects the genital tract and anorectal region and is not associated with meningitis.

Klebsiella (Option C) causes community-acquired pneumonia, catheter-associated UTI, and sepsis.

CMV (Option D) typically causes hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and purpuric rashes.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of multiple myeloma is associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster?
questions.solution:
The drug that is used to treat multiple myeloma and is known to cause reactivation of herpes zoster is Bortezomib, a proteasome inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma.

It has been associated with an increased risk of herpes zoster reactivation due to its immunosuppressive effects.

  • Given as IV/SC.
  • Adverse effects: Thrombocytopenia, Peripheral neuropathy, Neutropenia, Anaemia, DIC.

Explanation for other options:

Lenalidomide (Option B) is an immunomodulatory analogue of thalidomide & is the DOC in MDS associated with 5q deletion. It suppresses bone marrow and is associated with significant leukopenia.

Daratumumab (Option C) (against CD-38) and Elotuzumab (Option D) (against SLAMF7) are monoclonal antibodies used in the treatment of multiple myeloma, and while they may cause various side effects, they are less commonly associated with herpes zoster reactivation compared to bortezomib.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has consulted multiple plastic surgeons to correct a perceived facial deformity. Despite reassurances from doctors and her family that no such defect exists, she remains convinced and frequently checks her appearance in the mirror. She insists on surgical intervention. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
SSRIs are first-line pharmacological treatment for Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), as they help reduce obsessional thoughts and compulsive behaviours related to perceived appearance flaws.

  • Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by:
    • Preoccupation with a perceived defect or flaw in appearance (often imagined or minor)
    • Repetitive behaviours such as mirror checking, excessive grooming, or seeking reassurance
    • Social withdrawal and impaired functioning
    • High rates of plastic surgery consultation, which often provides no relief
  • BDD falls under the Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders category in DSM-5.
  • Key Features:
    • Persistent thoughts about perceived physical flaws
    • Excessive comparisons with others
    • Poor insight or delusional conviction about their appearance
    • Functional impairment due to distress
  • Management:
    • First-line pharmacotherapy: SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, fluvoxamine)
    • First-line psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
    • Surgery is not recommended and usually leads to dissatisfaction

Explanation of other options:

Atypical antipsychotic (Option B): Used only in severe or delusional BDD or when there's poor response to SSRIs; not first-line.

Insight therapy (Option C): Insight-oriented psychotherapy is not effective in BDD, as most patients have poor or absent insight into their condition.

SNRI (Option D): SNRIs are less effective than SSRIs for obsessive-compulsive spectrum disorders like BDD and are not first-line.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4948290/

questions.text: A child presents with anemia, mental retardation, bone pains, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy shows a characteristic "crumpled tissue paper" appearance of macrophages. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency in this condition?
questions.solution:
Gaucher disease, caused by glucocerebrosidase deficiency, leads to accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages, giving the classic "crumpled tissue paper" appearance on bone marrow biopsy.

  • Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • It is caused by deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase), leading to accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages.
  • Key Features of Gaucher Disease:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly (due to infiltration by Gaucher cells)
    • Pancytopenia or anemia
    • Bone pain, osteopenia, avascular necrosis
    • Neurological involvement in some types (especially Type 2 and Type 3
    • Characteristic Gaucher cells: lipid-laden macrophages with "crumpled tissue paper" cytoplasm in bone marrow biopsy
  • Types of Gaucher Disease:
    • Type 1 (non-neuronopathic): Most common, affects spleen, liver, bone
    • Type 2 (acute neuronopathic): Infantile onset, severe neurological symptoms
    • Type 3 (chronic neuronopathic): Slower neurological progression
  • Treatment:
    • Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with recombinant glucocerebrosidase
    • Substrate reduction therapy (SRT) in select cases

Explanation of other options:

Hexosaminidase-A (Option A): Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, cherry-red macula, and no hepatosplenomegaly or "crumpled tissue paper" cells.

Iduronate 2-sulphatase (Option B): Deficiency causes Hunter syndrome (MPS II), a mucopolysaccharidosis presenting with coarse facial features, developmental delay, and hepatosplenomegaly, but not the marrow findings seen in Gaucher disease.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (Option C): Deficiency causes G6PD deficiency, a hemolytic anemia triggered by oxidative stress (e.g., infections, fava beans), with no bone involvement or Gaucher cells.
