questions.text: What is the primary purpose of PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure) in mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
PEEP maintains positive pressure in the lungs at the end of expiration to keep alveoli open, thereby preventing atelectasis and improving oxygenation.

  • Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is a setting used in mechanical ventilation that maintains a certain level of pressure in the lungs at the end of expiration, preventing the alveoli from collapsing.
  • It is especially beneficial in conditions like ARDS, pulmonary edema, and hypoxemic respiratory failure, where alveolar collapse impairs oxygenation.
  • Physiological Benefits of PEEP:
    • Prevents atelectasis by keeping alveoli open.
    • Recruits collapsed alveoli, improving ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) matching.
    • Increases functional residual capacity (FRC), aiding oxygen exchange.
    • Improves lung compliance, making ventilation more effective.
    • Reduces work of breathing, particularly in obstructive lung diseases like COPD.
  • Clinical Indications of PEEP:
    • ARDS: Prevents alveolar collapse, improves oxygenation
    • Pulmonary edema: Helps push fluid out of alveoli, improving gas exchange
    • COPD with auto-PEEP: Applied PEEP may reduce dynamic hyperinflation
    • Postoperative atelectasis: Re-expands collapsed alveoli
  • Contraindications of High PEEP:
    • Tension pneumothorax: Can worsen intrathoracic pressure and respiratory compromise
    • Hypovolemic shock: Further reduces venous return → hypotension
    • High intracranial pressure (ICP): Increases thoracic pressure → decreases cerebral perfusion
    • Bronchopleural fistula: May impair healing by increasing pressure gradient across the fistula

choices.text: Tuberculoid leprosy with Antigen test positive
Tuberculoid leprosy with Antigen test negative
Lepromatous leprosy with positive antigen test
Borderline leprosy with negative antigen test

questions.text: A patient presented with a single skin lesion on arm with loss sensation and ulnar nerve enlargement. Histopathology shown below. What is the diagnosis and antigen test status?
questions.solution:
Tuberculoid leprosy is characterized by strong cell-mediated immunity, localized lesions, nerve involvement, and a positive lepromin (antigen) test.

Histopathology reveals granulomas with well-formed epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells, with no visible acid-fast bacilli.

Tuberculoid Leprosy (TT)

  • Tuberculoid leprosy (TT) is part of the Ridley-Jopling classification of Hansen’s disease.
  • It reflects a strong immune response to Mycobacterium leprae
  • It is characterized by:
    • Asymmetric nerve involvement (e.g., ulnar thickening)
  • Histology: Well-formed granulomas with epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells
  • Clinical features:
    • Few well-demarcated hypopigmented or erythematous plaques
    • Loss of sensation over lesions
    • Nerve thickening (e.g., ulnar, common peroneal)
    • Paucibacillary (very few or no bacilli seen on skin smear)
  • Histopathology:
    • Well-formed granulomas
    • Epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells
    • Dense lymphocytic infiltrate
    • No acid-fast bacilli (AFB)
  • Lepromin test: Positive (due to good T-cell immunity)
  • Lepromin Test Overview
    • It is a skin test for measuring cell-mediated immunity to Mycobacterium leprae.
    • Positive in tuberculoid and borderline tuberculoid forms.
    • Negative in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous forms.

questions.text: A sexually active patient presents with painful lesions on the penis
questions.solution:
Herpes genitalis presents as painful grouped vesicles or ulcers on an erythematous base, commonly caused by HSV-2.

  • Herpes genitalis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) most often caused by Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV-2) and occasionally by HSV-1.
  • It is the most common cause of painful genital ulcers.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Painful vesicles or ulcers on the genitalia
    • Vesicles rupture to form shallow, painful ulcers with an erythematous base
    • Often associated with fever, dysuria, inguinal lymphadenopathy in primary infection
    • Lesions may recur due to latency in dorsal root ganglia
    • Diagnosis: Tzanck smear (shows multinucleated giant cells), PCR, viral culture, or serology

Explanation of other options:

Chancroid (Option B): Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi; presents with painful ulcers but these are deep, soft, non-indurated, often with ragged edges and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), usually unilateral.

Syphilis (Options C): Caused by Treponema pallidum; primary chancre is painless, indurated, and clean-based. Also associated with painless lymphadenopathy.

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)(Option D): Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1-L3); painless transient genital ulcer followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) weeks later.

questions.text: A jeep driver presented with pain in the gluteal region along with swelling. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pilonidal sinus is a chronic inflammatory condition in the natal cleft, especially in people with prolonged sitting habits (e.g., drivers), presenting with pain and swelling near the gluteal area.

  • Pilonidal sinus occurs in the sacrococcygeal region, typically in young, hirsute males who spend long periods sitting (like jeep or truck drivers).
  • The condition involves ingrowth of hair into the skin, causing a sinus tract or abscess formation.
  • Key Features:
    • Location: Midline over the sacrum or coccyx, in the natal cleft
    • Symptoms: Pain, swelling, discharge (sometimes foul-smelling), and intermittent abscesses
    • Risk Factors: Prolonged sitting, poor hygiene, obesity, coarse body hair
    • Diagnosis: Clinical based on symptoms and local findings
  • Treatment:
    • Acute abscess: Incision and drainage
    • Chronic/recurrent: Surgical excision (midline or off-midline closures like Bascom or Karydakis procedure)
    • Pilonidal sinus excision and repair by rhomboid flap

Explanation of other options:

Fistula in ano (Option B): Involves a tract between the anal canal and perianal skin, presenting with discharge near the anus, not in the upper gluteal region.

Fissure in ano (Option C): A painful tear in the anal mucosa, causes sharp pain during defecation and fresh bleeding, but not gluteal swelling.

Gluteal abscess (Option D): While this can present similarly with gluteal swelling and pain, it usually arises from infection or trauma and lacks the typical midline sinus tract or chronic features of a pilonidal sinus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman, who had her last pregnancy 20 years ago, presents with heavy bleeding and a mass felt on the perineum. A smooth, round, globular structure is observed on examination. On bimanual examination, the uterus is firm, and the cervix admits one finger. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A myxomatous (fibroid) polyp is a benign leiomyoma that can prolapse through the cervix, presenting as a smooth mass with a firm uterus and abnormal bleeding years after delivery.

  • Myxomatous polyps (also called fibroid polyps or prolapsed submucous fibroids) are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus that can protrude through the cervix and present as a mass at the introitus or perineum.
  • In this case, the key findings include:
    • Smooth, round, globular mass on perineal examination
    • Palpable, firm uterus on bimanual exam
    • Cervix admitting one finger (suggesting something protruding through the cervix)
  • This constellation strongly suggests a prolapsed submucous fibroid (i.e., a myxomatous polyp), especially in a woman long past childbearing age.

Leiomyoma:

  • Leiomyomas are non-cancerous tumors composed of smooth muscle cells that arise from the myometrium.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Asymptomatic in ~75%: Often discovered incidentally
    • Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB) in ~30%: Includes menorrhagia and metrorrhagia
    • Pelvic pain symptoms: Dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia
    • Reproductive issues: Infertility
    • Pressure effects: Increased urinary frequency or retention, constipation
    • Sensation of heaviness: Lower abdominal or pelvic discomfort

Explanation of other options:

Uterine Inversion (Option B): Occurs acutely postpartum, not decades after delivery. It presents with severe pain, hemorrhage, and shock-not seen here.

Placental Polyp (Option C): Retained placental tissue occurs shortly after delivery or abortion. It is highly unlikely 20 years post-childbirth.

Hypertrophied Cervix (Option D): Refers to generalized cervical enlargement, not a discrete globular mass at the perineum. The presence of a protruding mass with a separate firm uterus rules this out.

choices.text: There is more compliance in 3HP than in 9H and 6H.
There is no significant difference in compliance between 3HP, 6H, and 9H.
The chance of abortion in 3HP is the same as in 6H.
The 3HP regimen is less effective than 6H and 9H in preventing active tuberculosis.

questions.text: A patient is initiated on the 3HP regimen (Isoniazid + Rifapentine once weekly for 3 months) for tuberculosis preventive therapy (TPT). Which of the following statements about the 3HP regimen is true?
questions.solution:
The 3HP regimen, consisting of a 3-month course of weekly rifapentine and isoniazid, offers higher patient compliance compared to the longer 9H (9-month isoniazid) and 6H (6-month isoniazid) regimens. Its shorter duration improves adherence and minimises the risk of treatment interruptions, enhancing overall effectiveness.

Tuberculosis Prevention Therapy (TPT): Treatment given to individuals who are at high risk of developing active TB & prevent progression from latent TB infection.

TB prophylaxis is indicated in the following high-risk patient groups:

  • Contacts of open cases who show recent Mantoux conversion.
  • Children with a sputum-positive TB patient in the family.
  • Neonate of a tubercular mother.
  • Patients with leukaemia, diabetes, silicosis or those receiving immunosuppressant medication or those on long-term corticosteroid therapy.
  • HIV-infected contacts of sputum-positive cases.

The recommended regimens for tuberculosis treatment include the following options:

  • 6H or 9H: Isoniazid (5 mg/kg) daily for 6 months (6H) or 9 months (9H).
  • 3HP: Rifapentine (10 mg/kg) combined with high-dose Isonazid (15 mg/kg) weekly for 3 months.
  • 4R: Rifampin (10 mg/kg) daily for 4 months.
  • 3HR: Isoniazid (5 mg/kg) and Rifampin (10 mg/kg) daily for 3 months.

The chance of abortion in 3HP is the same as in 6H (Option C): The difference in the duration of exposure leads to a different side effect profile, and the risk of pregnancy-related complications, including abortion, is not the same in both regimens.

The 3HP regimen is less effective than 6H and 9H in preventing active tuberculosis (Option D): It is incorrect because 3HP is as effective, if not slightly more effective, in preventing active TB when compared to the longer regimens of 6H and 9H.

Reference:

  1. https://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/treatment/ltbi.htm#:~:text=CDC%20and%20the%20National%20Tuberculosis,weekly%20isoniazid%20plus%20rifapentine%20(3HP)

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with an infection caused by Enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) O157:H7. In this serotype designation, what does the "H" denote?
questions.solution:
The "H" antigen in E. coli serotyping refers to the flagellar antigen, which determines the motility of the bacteria.

O157:H7 is a strain of Enterohaemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) known for producing Shiga toxin, leading to haemorrhagic colitis and haemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS).

Serotyping of E. coli:

  • "O" antigen → Somatic (LPS) antigen (Option D)
  • "H" antigen → Flagellar antigen (Option C)
  • "K" antigen → Capsular antigen (Option A)

Fimbriae (Option B) aid in bacterial adhesion, but they are not part of E. coli serotyping as the "H" antigen.

questions.text: A patient presents with headaches, palpitations, and hypertension. On examination, urine VMA is positive. His biopsy findings are given below. Which of the following is a correct statement?
questions.solution:
Based on the biopsy, we can observe a nesting pattern (Zellballen pattern), which is suggestive of pheochromocytoma, which is associated with MEN2A.

The genetic mutation most commonly associated with pheochromocytoma is the gain-of-function mutation in the RET gene.

questions.text: What structure is marked "X" in the image provided below ?
questions.solution:
The structure marked "X" is the testicular vein, which courses along the posterior abdominal wall toward the deep inguinal ring.

  • The testicular vein is part of the spermatic cord and drains blood from the testis via the pampiniform plexus.
  • It ascends in the retroperitoneum, with the right testicular vein draining into the IVC, and the left testicular vein draining into the left renal vein.
  • In surgical anatomy, this structure is identified near the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels and anterior to the psoas major.
  • It is especially important in inguinal hernia repair, orchidectomy, and varicocele surgery.

Basic Surgical Anatomy of the Testis:

Location and Structure

Paired oval-shaped organs in the scrotum.

Suspended by the spermatic cord (contains blood vessels, nerves, vas deferens).

Layers:

  • Tunica Vaginalis: Double-layered serous membrane from the peritoneum.
  • Tunica Albuginea: Dense, fibrous capsule beneath the tunica vaginalis.

questions.text: A woman presents with a twin pregnancy. On ultrasound, the estimated age of one fetus is 1 month more than the other fetus.
questions.solution:
Superfetation is the fertilization of two ova in different menstrual cycles, leading to a significant gestational age difference between twins.

  • Superfetation refers to the conception of a second fetus during an ongoing pregnancy, caused by ovulation and fertilization occurring in a separate menstrual cycle.
  • It is an extremely rare phenomenon in humans due to hormonal and physiological changes that usually prevent further ovulation and implantation once pregnancy begins.
  • In reported cases, it results in fetuses with a clear age gap, such as one fetus being a month older than the other, as described in this scenario.

Explanation of other options:

Superfecundation (Option B): Fertilization of two ova during the same cycle from separate acts of intercourse, possibly with different fathers. Twins are of the same gestational age.

Suppositious child (Option C): A fictitious or fraudulently presented child, often introduced to claim inheritance or lineage rights.

Posthumous child (Option D): A child born after the death of the biological father, but conceived while he was still alive.

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicular lesions in the genitourinary region. The image shows multiple grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the image and the clinical features, the causative agent is Herpes. <strong

Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus:

  • Genital infections
    • Mostly seen in HSV type 2
    • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions
    • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy
    • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
      • Male: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
      • Female: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum.
  • Cutaneous:
    • Site:
      • Face (cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead)
      • Buttocks (infants as napkin rash)
    • 'Fever blister' or herpes febrile or cold sores (viral reactivation in febrile patients)
    • Herpetic whitlow: Occupational variety seen in doctors, dentists, and nurses.
    • Eczema herpeticum: Generalised crops of vesicles appear in the affected area with widespread ulceration, as seen in children with eczema.
    • Herpes gladiatorum (Wrestler's herpes): In athletes who play skin-to-skin contact sports like wrestlers.
    • Herpes multiforme (red, raised, target-like lesions on skin)
  • Mucosal
    • Site: Buccal mucosa (most common)
    • Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis (primary infection)
    • Recurrent herpes labialis
  • Ophthalmic
    • Dendritic corneal ulcers
    • Corneal blindness and conjunctivitis are also observed
    • Chorioretinitis and acute necrotising retinitis are rare.
  • Nervous system
    • Encephalitis (HSV Encephalitis)
      • Caused by HSV-1
      • The most common cause of sporadic acute viral encephalitis
      • Affected site: Temporal lobe
    • Meningitis
      • Most commonly caused by HSV-2
      • Mollaret meningitis (recurrent lymphocytic meningitis)
    • HSV can result in Bell's palsy.
  • Visceral
    • Symptoms like dysphagia, substernal pain and weight loss.
    • Tracheobronchitis and pneumonitis (lung involvement)
  • Congenital
    • If a pregnant woman has genital lesions during labour, the risk of infection can be mitigated by performing a cesarean section.
    • Neonatal herpes: A disseminated disease involving multiple organs, with or without encephalitis. The mortality rate is high, and survivors may have neurological impairments.
    • Transplacental infections leading to congenital malformations are rare.

Explanation for other options:

Chancroid (Option B) causes painful ulcers but typically presents as a single, larger ulcer with ragged edges, not multiple vesicles.

Syphilis (Option C) causes painless genital ulcers.

Candidiasis (Option D) does not cause painful vesicular lesions.

choices.text: There is no allergic sensitisation to aspirin and its metabolites
Occurs on exposure to only aspirin
Occurs with exposure to other NSAIDs, too, that block COX-1

questions.text: A patient experiences breathing difficulty and nasal polyps after taking aspirin, with a similar past history. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
The condition described in the question is Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), also known as Aspirin-Intolerant Asthma or Samter's Triad, which typically involves the combination of:

  • Asthma
  • Nasal polyposis
  • Aspirin intolerance

In AERD, the inhibition of COX-1 by aspirin or NSAIDs leads to reduced production of prostaglandins, particularly prostaglandin E2 (Page E2), which normally helps regulate inflammation.

This leads to an increase in the production of leukotrienes, potent inflammatory mediators that cause bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation, worsening asthma and causing the symptoms of AERD.

Explanation for other options:

There is no allergic sensitisation to aspirin and its metabolites (Option A): The condition is not due to classic IgE-mediated allergy to aspirin or its metabolites. Instead, it is believed to be a result of the inhibition of COX-1 (cyclooxygenase 1) by aspirin, which leads to an imbalance in leukotriene and prostaglandin production, triggering respiratory symptoms.

It can also be triggered by other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), especially those that inhibit COX-1, such as ibuprofen, naproxen, and other NSAIDs. The condition is not limited to aspirin alone (Option D & C).

Responds to Montelukast (Option B): Montelukast, a leukotriene receptor antagonist, is commonly used to manage symptoms in AERD as it helps reduce inflammation and bronchoconstriction associated with the condition.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image.
questions.solution:
A nasopharyngeal airway (NPA) is a flexible, soft rubber or plastic tube inserted through the nostril into the nasopharynx to maintain airway patency in patients with obstructed breathing. It is commonly used in semi-conscious or unconscious patients when an oropharyngeal airway is not suitable.


Explanation for other options:

Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) (Option B): It is incorrect because an LMA is inserted into the pharynx and forms a seal over the laryngeal inlet, unlike an NPA, which is placed through the nose.

NG Tube (Option C): It is incorrect because a nasogastric tube is used for feeding or decompression of the stomach, not for airway management.

Oropharyngeal tube (Option D): It is incorrect because an oropharyngeal airway is inserted through the mouth, while the given device is inserted through the nose.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, P2L2, with a history of infravaginal cervical lengthening, is considering surgical options.
questions.solution:
Fothergill surgery (also known as Manchester repair) is ideal for young women under 40 years with cervical elongation and uterine prolapse who wish to preserve fertility.

  • Fothergill surgery is specifically indicated in women with uterine prolapse who desire uterine conservation, especially when associated with infravaginal cervical elongation.
  • It is appropriate for younger women (typically <40 years) who have completed their families or wish to preserve reproductive potential.
  • The procedure involves:
    • Amputation of the elongated cervix
    • Plication of the Mackenrodt's (cardinal) ligaments to support the uterus
    • Anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy for vaginal wall support
  • This combination restores normal anatomy while retaining the uterus, which aligns with the needs of a young woman with cervical elongation.
  • Complications include:
    • Cervical stenosis
    • Fibrosis
    • Cervical incompetence (if future pregnancy occurs)
    • Urinary retention

Explanation of other options:

McCall culdoplasty (Option B): Used to prevent enterocele by suspending the vaginal apex, typically performed during or after hysterectomy-not suitable for patients needing cervical correction or uterine conservation.

LeFort's repair (Option C): A partial colpocleisis reserved for elderly women with advanced prolapse who are unfit for more extensive surgery and do not desire future sexual activity or fertility.

Hysterectomy (Option D): Although definitive, it's inappropriate here given the patient's age and her need for uterine preservation due to prior cervical surgery and reproductive considerations.

questions.text: A patient presents with a headache, recurrent episodes of high blood pressure, and tachycardia. Her urine shows elevated levels of vanillylmandelic acid, and a CT scan reveals a retroperitoneal tumour in the right lumbar region. Which of the following syndromes is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (Option C): NF2 involves bilateral vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and ependymomas, not typically associated with pheochromocytomas. This distinguishes it from NF1, which is associated with pheochromocytomas.

Pheochromocytoma is associated with MEN 2A, VHL, HPPS, and NF1, but not with NF2, which primarily involves schwannomas and meningiomas.

  • This patient has classic features of pheochromocytoma:
    • Symptoms: Headache, hypertension, tachycardia, sweating
    • Biochemical marker: Elevated urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA), a catecholamine metabolite
    • Imaging: Retroperitoneal tumor, possibly adrenal or extra-adrenal (paraganglioma)
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare catecholamine-secreting tumors derived from chromaffin cells, usually located in the adrenal medulla.
  • They may also arise from extra-adrenal paraganglia (called paragangliomas).

Syndromes associated with pheochromocytoma:

  • MEN 2A and 2B (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia):
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia (in MEN 2A)
  • Von Hippel-Lindau Disease (VHL):
    • Hemangioblastomas, retinal angiomas, RCC, pancreatic cysts, and pheochromocytoma
  • Hereditary:
    • Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndromes (HPPS):
    • Caused by mutations in SDH genes (e.g., SDHB, SDHD)
    • Associated with head, neck, thoracic, or abdominal paragangliomas
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) (not listed in the question):
    • Café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, optic gliomas, and pheochromocytoma

Explanation of other options:

MEN 2A syndrome (Option A): Associated with pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia.

Von Hippel-Lindau Disease (Option B): Autosomal dominant syndrome strongly linked with pheochromocytomas and other vascular tumors.

Hereditary Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndromes (Option D): These are the classic familial syndromes associated with pheochromocytomas or extra-adrenal paragangliomas.

questions.text: Examination of a specific suspicious stain shows characteristic findings. What is the test to be performed?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Barberio test, indicated by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals.

  • The Barberio test specifically detects Spermine, a compound derived from the prostate, and is used to identify seminal fluid.


Explanation for other options:

Teichmann test (Option A): This test detects haemoglobin or blood, not seminal fluid.

Takayama test (Option C): Similar to the Teichmann test, the Takayama test is used for haemoglobin detection.

Florence Test (Option D): This test detects choline and produces different crystal formations (dark brown rhombic crystals).

questions.text: Identify the visual field defect from the given image
questions.solution:
A blind spot enlargement occurs when the physiological blind spot (corresponding to the optic nerve head) increases in size, often due to optic nerve or retinal disorders.

  • Common Causes of Blind Spot Enlargement:
    • Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH)
    • Inflammatory or infectious diseases: Syphilis, West Nile virus, rubella vaccination
    • Papilledema (increased intracranial pressure)
    • Optic disc drusen

Explanation for other options:

Altitudinal defect (Option A): An altitudinal defect involves loss of vision in the upper or lower half of the visual field, commonly seen in ischemic optic neuropathy (ION) or branch retinal artery occlusion (BRAO).

  • Unlike blind spot enlargement, it respects the horizontal midline.

Roenne's nasal step (Option B): This defect occurs in glaucoma, appearing as a nasal step-shaped loss in the visual field due to retinal nerve fibre layer damage. It is different from blind spot enlargement, which affects the optic nerve head region rather than a specific sector of the visual field.

Arcuate scotoma (Option D): Arcuate scotomas follow the distribution of the nerve fibre layer and are seen in glaucoma or optic neuropathies. They extend from the blind spot but do not primarily cause its enlargement.

Key Takeaway:

Papilloedema:

  • Swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure
  • Characteristic Features:
    • Passive oedema without inflammation.
    • Swelling primarily in the optic nerve head in front of the lamina cribrosa.
    • Engorged, tortuous small blood vessels and swollen nerve fibres.
    • Axoplasmic stasis with swollen, disrupted mitochondria.
    • Retinal changes include macular star and cotton-wool spots.
  • Signs:
    • Initial blurring of optic disc margins.
    • Enlargement of the blind spot due to the separation of the retina.
    • Hyperaemia, swelling, and engorgement of disc vessels.
    • Potential for haemorrhages, exudates, and macular star formation.
    • Chronic cases may lead to optic atrophy and visual loss.

Reference:

  1. Blind spot enlargement: A differential diagnosis
  2. Artefactual uniocular altitudinal visual field defect - PMC
  3. Open Angle Glaucoma - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is primarily responsible for the perception of a sour taste?
questions.solution:
TRPP3 (transient receptor potential polycystin 3), also known as PKD2L1, is a cation channel that has been proposed to be involved in sour taste

  • Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and umami.
  • All these tastes are recognised by binding of the taste chemical to a protein receptor molecule that lies on the taste receptor cell to initiate the receptor potential.
  • Each taste has a different mechanism for triggering receptor potential.

questions.text: A man with a history of occasional food intake from outside presents with 4 days of abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia. Which diagnostic test is best to confirm the suspected illness?
questions.solution:
• Blood culture is the most reliable test to confirm the diagnosis in the early stages of typhoid fever, particularly within the first week of illness.
  • Typhoid fever, caused by Salmonella typhi, is suspected due to the patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia (a feature known as "relative bradycardia").

questions.text: In sacrocolpopexy (sacrocolposuspension), which is the correct site of attachment of the mesh?
questions.solution:
In sacrocolpopexy, the mesh is anchored to the anterior longitudinal ligament over the sacral promontory to provide durable support to the vaginal vault or uterus.

  • Sacrocolpopexy is a surgical procedure performed for vault prolapse or uterine prolapse, particularly when uterine preservation is desired or following hysterectomy.
  • It is often performed abdominally or laparoscopically.
  • In this procedure, a synthetic mesh is used to suspend the vaginal apex (or uterus) to the anterior longitudinal ligament over the sacral promontory-a strong anchoring point on the anterior surface of the sacrum at the lumbosacral junction.
  • This provides physiologic and durable support, preserving the axis of the vagina and minimizing prolapse recurrence.
  • It is preferred in sexually active women and those desiring anatomical and functional restoration.

Explanation of other options:

Ischial spine (Option B): While it's an anatomical landmark for procedures like uterosacral ligament suspension, it is not the site for mesh attachment in sacrocolpopexy.

Pubic symphysis (Option C): Lies anteriorly and has no role in pelvic organ prolapse surgeries involving vault suspension.

Ischial tuberosity (Option D): Serves as the origin for hamstring muscles and is unrelated to any pelvic organ prolapse surgical mesh fixation.

questions.text: A patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia develops flushing, gout, and elevated liver enzymes after starting medication. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these side effects?
questions.solution:
Niacin (Nicotinamide) is commonly used to lower triglycerides and raise HDL cholesterol & is associated with side effects like flushing, gout & elevated liver enzymes.

Niacin:

Niacin is Vitamin B3 or nicotinic acid. It inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue and ↓triglyceride production by the liver. It also increases HDL levels. Its use is limited by its side effects:

  • Flushing (taking aspirin before niacin helps to reduce flushing)
  • Dry skin
  • Dyspepsia
  • Hepatotoxicity presents with fatigue and weakness
  • Hyperglycemia- it can indicate insulin resistance and should be used cautiously in those with diabetes
  • Increases uric acid levels, hence contraindicated in gout

Explanation for other options:

Atorvastatin (Option B) is a statin used primarily to lower LDL cholesterol and triglycerides. While it can cause elevated liver enzymes and muscle-related issues (such as myopathy), it is not typically associated with flushing or gout.

Fenofibrate (Option C) is a fibrate that effectively lowers triglycerides. It can lead to elevated liver enzymes and muscle-related side effects, but flushing and gout are not commonly associated with its use.

Cholestyramine (Option D) is a bile acid sequestrant used to lower LDL cholesterol. It is mainly known to cause gastrointestinal issues like constipation, but it does not cause flushing, gout, or elevated liver enzymes.

questions.text: A 13-year-old patient presents with perianal itching, mostly at night. A swab was taken, and the microscopic image showed oval eggs with a flattened side, as the given image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Scotch-tape test:

A piece of clear tape is pressed against the skin around the anus to collect eggs, typically overnight. The tape is then examined under a microscope for pinworm eggs.


Life cycle:

  • Enterobius vermicularis spends the entire lifecycle in humans.
  • It has no intermediate hosts and does not undergo systemic migration.
  • The eggs hatch in the intestine, and the larvae enter the caecum and mature into adults.
  • The male worm does not migrate and most often dies after mating and is passed in the faeces.
  • The female worm migrates to the rectum from the colon and travels to the perianal skin at night to lay its sticky eggs and dies after laying all its eggs or gets crushed due to scratching.

Pathogenicity:

  • The embryonated egg is the infective form.
  • The disease thus caused is called enterobiasis, which is more common in children than in adults.
  • It affects females > males.
  • The infection occurs in two ways:
    • Exogenous autoinfection is where the eggs are transferred from the perianal region to the mouth by the nails after scratching the region.
    • Endogenous autoinfection/retro-infection is where the larva migrates retrograde and travels back into the colon after hatching in the perianal skin.

Larvae: The larvae mature in the cecum into adult worms and are not infectious forms of Enterobius.

Explanation for other options:

Hymenolepis nana (Option A) The dwarf tapeworm typically causes abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea, but not perianal itching.

Ancylostoma and Necator americanus (Options B and D) Ancylostoma, now known as Necator americanus, is a hookworm that primarily causes iron deficiency anaemia, ground itch, and creeping eruption.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with a gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. What is the most likely diagnosis based on fundoscopy findings?
questions.solution:
The image given above is retinitis pigmentosa fundoscopy findings showing a pale waxy disc, bony spicules, and attenuation of arteries.

  • Nyctalopia is one of the symptoms of retinitis pigmentosa, but it is not included in the triad.
  • The Triad of retinitis pigmentosa includes a pale, waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.
  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a dystrophy of rods and cones. Initially, rods are affected.
  • Most common hereditary fundus dystrophy.
  • It can be sporadic (40-50%) or hereditary.
  • If hereditary, autosomal dominant is the most common mode of inheritance, followed by autosomal recessive (AR). X-linked recessive inheritance is the least severe form.

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Nyctalopia (night blindness)
  • Peripheral visual field loss
  • Mid-peripheral superior scotoma leads to ring/ doughnut scotoma, resulting in tubular/ tunnel vision.

Signs:

  • Triad of a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.
  • Tapetal reflex: shining reflex at macula - seen in female carriers of XLR inheritance.

Atypical Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Atypical retinitis pigmentosa includes heterogeneous disorders that share clinical features with typical pigmentary retinal dystrophy.
  • Conditions included are:
    • RP sine pigmento - absence or paucity of pigment accumulation
    • Retinitis punctata albescens - scattered whitish-yellow spots with arteriolar attenuation, usually sparing the macula.
    • Sectoral RP - only inferior quadrants are involved.

Explanation for other options:

Retinal haemorrhage (Option B): Retinal haemorrhages occur in vascular disorders like diabetic or hypertensive retinopathy. They do not cause progressive night blindness or peripheral vision loss.

Diabetic retinopathy (Option C): Diabetic retinopathy presents with microaneurysms, haemorrhages, exudates, and neovascularisation. It primarily causes central vision loss (e.g., macular oedema) rather than peripheral vision loss.

Hypertensive retinopathy (Option D): Fundoscopic findings include flame-shaped haemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and arteriolar narrowing. It does not cause progressive night blindness or peripheral vision loss.

Key Takeaway:

Systemic associations in Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Refsum's disease: It is a defect in phytanic acid metabolism. RP+ Cerebellar ataxia+ Polyneuropathy. It is managed with a low phytanic acid diet.
  • Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome (m/c): involves RP, mental retardation, obesity, polydactyly, and paraplegia.
  • Usher's syndrome: It is retinitis pigmentosa (RP) with Sensory neural deafness.
  • Kearns-Sayer syndrome involves RP, heart block, and chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO).
  • Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome involves RP, acanthocytosis, abetalipoproteinemia, and ataxia. It is managed with a low-fat diet and vitamin supplements.

Ocular associations in Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Keratoconus
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC)
  • Open-angle glaucoma (OAG)
  • Cystoid mmacular oedema(CME)

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560777/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560805/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK525980/

questions.text: Which of the following ions plays the most significant role in establishing the resting membrane potential of a cell?
questions.solution:
Potassium ions are the primary contributors to the resting membrane potential. The RMP is mainly determined by the K+ gradient across the cell membrane, as potassium ions move out of the cell through potassium leak channels.

  • The loss of positively charged K+ ions from the cell creates a negative charge inside the cell relative to the outside, establishing the RMP, which is typically around -70 mV in neurons.

Resting membrane potential (RMP):

  • It is defined as the voltage difference between the exterior and interior of an excitable cell
  • In any cell, K+ is the major determinant of RMP
  • The major contribution of RMP is through passive diffusion of K+ ions, followed by active diffusion through Na+-K+ ions.

Generation of RMP:

Cover the baby's head and body
Bathe the baby with warm water
Clear eyes with a sterile swab

questions.text: A mother gives birth in a rural setting attended by a skilled care provider. Which of the following actions is not appropriate as part of immediate newborn care?
questions.solution:
Immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is discouraged right after birth. Instead, the focus should be on keeping the baby warm and starting breastfeeding.

Antenatal Care and Skilled Attendance at Birth by ANMs/LHVs/SNs:

  • The Government of India, under its National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) and Reproductive and Child Health (RCH)-II program, is committed to ensuring that all births are attended by skilled healthcare professionals.
  • This applies to both healthcare facilities and community settings.
  • The aim is to provide easy access to emergency care for mothers and newborns, reducing the number of maternal and newborn deaths in the country.

Newborn care by ASHA/skilled care attendant:

  • Place the baby on the mother's abdomen.
  • Look for meconium. If there is none, proceed to dry the baby with a warm towel or a piece of clean cloth. (Do not wipe off the white greasy substance (vernix) covering the baby's body. Vernix helps to protect the baby's skin.)
  • Breastfeeding is to be started as soon as possible after delivery, preferably within 1 hour after birth. (Option A ruled out)
  • Wrap the newborn with a blanket/sheet; ensure to cover the head as well. (Option B ruled out)
  • Avoid bathing the baby on the first day. Delay further on winter days. For small babies, delay bathing till the cord falls off. (Option C)
  • Wipe both eyes (separately) with sterile gauze. (Option D ruled out)

Reference:

  1. Guidelines for Antenatal Care and Skilled Attendance at Birth
  2. https://nihfw.ac.in/Doc/Flipchart%20for%20ASHA.pdf

questions.text: Identify the condition depicted in the radiograph below.
questions.solution:
Pancreatic calcification is most commonly seen in chronic pancreatitis, particularly due to alcohol abuse, but can also occur in other conditions such as hereditary or tropical pancreatitis. The radiographic findings in such cases typically show:

  • Multiple scattered calcifications in the epigastric region, corresponding to the pancreatic ducts.
  • Dystrophic calcification due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the pancreas.
  • History of recurrent abdominal pain, malabsorption, or diabetes (if exocrine or endocrine pancreatic insufficiency develops).

Explanation for other options:

Mesenteric calcification (Option B) is incorrect because mesenteric calcifications are typically seen in chronic ischemia, metastatic disease, or mesenteric lymph node calcification, which appear more diffuse and scattered in the abdomen, rather than being localised to the pancreatic region.

Horseshoe kidney (Option C) is incorrect because a horseshoe kidney is identified by a fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys, typically seen on ultrasound or CT, rather than radiographic calcifications.

Jejunal fecolith (Option D) is incorrect because a jejunal fecolith appears as a localised radiopaque density in the small intestine, often associated with small bowel obstruction, rather than diffuse pancreatic calcifications.

choices.text: Check for congenital anomalies, sex of baby, but do not reveal gender to the patient
Check for congenital anomalies, do not check the sex of the fetus
Check for congenital anomalies, sex of baby and reveal gender if it is female
Check only routine ANC, and avoid USG

questions.text: A G5P4 woman comes for her first routine sonography. She has four daughters and desires a boy this time, and asks to know the sex of the fetus. According to the PCPNDT Act, which action should a radiologist choose?
questions.solution:
Under the PCPNDT Act, fetal sex determination is prohibited, and the radiologist must focus solely on assessing congenital anomalies without attempting to determine fetal gender.

  • The Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, enacted in India in 1994 and amended in 2003, was introduced to combat female feticide and address the declining sex ratio.
  • It strictly prohibits sex selection and sex determination before or after conception.
  • During routine prenatal ultrasounds, a radiologist is legally obligated to examine fetal growth, viability, and congenital anomalies but is prohibited from determining or recording the fetal sex.
  • Violating this can lead to severe penalties, including suspension of medical license and criminal prosecution.
  • In this case, despite the patient's request due to personal bias (having four daughters), the radiologist must maintain ethical and legal integrity by not attempting to determine or disclose the fetal gender.

Explanation of other options:

Check for congenital anomalies, sex of baby, but do not reveal gender to the patient (Option A): Even if the sex is not revealed, determining the sex itself is illegal under the PCPNDT Act, unless it's done under specific medical indications (which are rare).

Check for congenital anomalies, sex of baby and reveal gender if it is female (Option C): This clearly violates the PCPNDT Act by both determining and disclosing the sex of the fetus, regardless of gender.

Check only routine ANC, and avoid USG (Option D): Avoiding ultrasound altogether is not appropriate, as it is essential for routine antenatal care, especially for detecting fetal anomalies.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3498638/

questions.text: What would be the appropriate management for a 28-year-old woman who presents with a painless, gradually enlarging swelling under her tongue (as shown in the image), which becomes more prominent while eating but is not tender or red, and has no significant medical history or history of trauma or infection?
questions.solution:
The most definitive treatment for a ranula is removal of the sublingual gland, which addresses the source of mucus extravasation and minimizes recurrence.

  • A ranula is a mucous extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual salivary gland due to duct rupture or blockage.
  • It typically presents as:
    • A painless, bluish, dome-shaped swelling on the floor of the mouth.
    • Becomes prominent during meals due to increased salivation.
    • Often fluctuant, non-tender, and transilluminant.
  • Types:
    • Simple ranula: Confined to the floor of the mouth.
    • Plunging ranula: Extends through or around the mylohyoid muscle into the neck.
  • Management:
    • Sublingual gland excision is the gold standard, as it removes the source of mucus production and prevents recurrence.
  • Adjunct: Sometimes accompanied by removal of the ranula itself or marsupialization if needed.

Explanation of other options:

Incision and drainage (Option A): Offers only temporary relief. High recurrence rate and not definitive as it doesn't address the source (gland).

Marsupialization (Option C): Involves suturing the cyst wall to oral mucosa to form a continuous epithelialized tract. It's less invasive and often used in children, but recurrence is more common compared to gland excision.

Excision (Option D): Refers to removing the cyst only, without removing the source gland, leading to a high chance of recurrence.

questions.text: A traveller develops diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and vomiting after consuming oysters. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a common cause of gastroenteritis linked to the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood, especially oysters. The typical symptoms include diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and vomiting, often appearing within 24 hours of ingestion.

Vibrio parahaemolyticus:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a gram-negative bacterium, part of the Vibrio genus, commonly found in marine environments. It causes gastroenteritis primarily through the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood, especially oysters.

Transmission:

  • Ingestion of contaminated seafood, particularly raw oysters and fish, is the primary route of infection.
  • Associated with coastal areas and warm seawater.

Clinical Features:

  • Diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Vomiting
  • Fever
  • Symptoms typically appear within 24 hours of consuming contaminated food.

Virulence Factors:

  • Haemolysin production (particularly thermostable direct haemolysin) is responsible for cell damage and intestinal symptoms.
  • Adhesion factors that help the bacteria adhere to the intestinal mucosa.

Diagnosis:

  • Stool culture is used for diagnosis. The bacterium can be isolated from the stool of infected individuals.
  • PCR

Treatment:

  • Supportive care (hydration and electrolyte replacement)
  • Doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, or third-generation cephalosporins are used in severe cases or for immunocompromised patients.

References: Three New Regulators of Swarming in Vibrio parahaemolyticus - PMC.

questions.text: Identify the 'X' marked drug in the given image.
questions.solution:
Amino-caproic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that works by inhibiting the activation of plasminogen to plasmin, thus preventing the breakdown of fibrin in blood clots.

Explanation for other options:

Clopidogrel (Option A) is an antiplatelet agent that prevents platelet aggregation by inhibiting the ADP receptor on platelets. It does not affect the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin.

Tenecteplase (Option C) is a thrombolytic agent that facilitates the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, promoting the breakdown of clots. It is the opposite of Amino-caproic acid in terms of its action.

Heparin (Option D) is an anticoagulant that works by inhibiting thrombin and factor Xa to prevent clot formation, but it does not directly affect the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin.

questions.text: Identify the disease associated with the following image provided
questions.solution:
The given image shows a 'crumpled tissue paper' appearance, a characteristic finding of Gaucher's disease.

Gaucher disease:

  • It is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by mutations in the GBA gene, which encodes the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.
  • Accumulation of glucocerebroside (glucosylceramide) within lysosomes of macrophages, forming characteristic Gaucher cells.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Hematologic: Pancytopenia
    • Skeletal: Bone crisis, severe bone pain.
    • Neurological: Parkinsonism, cognitive impairment, neuropathy
  • Investigations:
    • Bone marrow examination: Shows Gaucher cells with a characteristic wrinkled tissue paper appearance. Gaucher cells are macrophages that accumulate with glucocerebroside.
    • Enzyme assay: Demonstrates reduced activity of glucocerebrosidase in leukocytes or fibroblasts.
    • Long bone X-rays may show the Erlenmeyer flask deformity.

Explanation for other options:

Tay-Sachs disease (Option B) is caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides in neurons. It presents with progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, cherry-red spot on the macula, but no Gaucher cells in the bone marrow.

Sandhoff's disease (Option C) occurs due to a hexosaminidase A and B deficiency, leading to GM2 ganglioside accumulation. It presents with similar neurodegenerative symptoms as Tay-Sachs but with visceral involvement, unlike Gaucher's disease..

Fabry's disease (Option D) is caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It presents with neuropathic pain, angiokeratomas, corneal opacities, and renal/cardiac complications. No Gaucher cells are observed.

A- Arrector pilorum, B- Eccrine sweat gland, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland

questions.text: Identify the markers in the given slide:
questions.solution:
These markers on the provided slide match the following structures:

  • A: Eccrine sweat glands: Found all over the skin, these play a role in thermoregulation.
  • B: Arrector pili: Tiny muscles that contract to make hair stand upright and are connected to hair follicles.
  • C: Sebaceous gland: Sebum-secreting glands that coat and lubricate skin and hair.
  • D: Apocrine gland: Located in the groin and axilla, these glands secrete thicker sweat, which adds to body odour.

Histology of Glands

  • Glands are specialised structures in the body that produce and secrete substances such as hormones, enzymes, or other fluids.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with bronchial asthma develops postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) during delivery of her first child. Which drug is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Carboprost is contraindicated in asthma due to its bronchoconstrictive properties, which can trigger life-threatening asthma exacerbations.

  • Carboprost is a synthetic analogue of Prostaglandin F2α (PGF2α), used in the management of refractory PPH due to uterine atony.
  • However, it induces bronchial smooth muscle contraction, making it dangerous in patients with asthma.
  • Dose: 250 µg IM every 15-90 mins, up to a maximum of 2 mg.
  • Efficacy: Very effective in controlling uterine bleeding (~88%).
  • Side effects: Bronchospasm, diarrhea, hypertension, fever, nausea, vomiting.
  • Absolute Contraindications: Asthma, pulmonary hypertension, amniotic fluid embolism.
  • Relative Contraindications: Cardiac disease, liver/renal dysfunction, preeclampsia.
  • In asthmatic patients, using carboprost could lead to bronchoconstriction and respiratory distress, which can be fatal.

Explanation of other options:

Methyl ergometrine (Option A): Causes vasoconstriction and is contraindicated in hypertension, not asthma. It’s relatively safe in asthmatic patients if blood pressure is controlled.

Misoprostol (Option C): A Prostaglandin E1 analogue. It does not cause bronchoconstriction, making it safe in asthma. Used rectally, orally, or sublingually for PPH.

Oxytocin (Option D): First-line agent for PPH. Promotes uterine contraction by acting on oxytocin receptors. It’s safe in asthma, with no bronchial side effects.

Reference:

https://www.uptodate.com/contents/postpartum-hemorrhage-medical-and-minimally-invasive-management?search=postpartum%20hemorrhage%20management&source=search_result&selectedTitle=2~150&usage_type=default&display_rank=2#H187794904

questions.text: A man presented to the emergency after a road traffic accident (RTA) with chest pain and breathing difficulty. An X-ray was done. What type of breathing pattern is observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Paradoxical breathing is observed in flail chest, which typically results from multiple rib fractures following blunt trauma, as seen in this patient.

  • In this scenario, a road traffic accident (RTA) patient with chest pain and dyspnea following trauma and imaging suggestive of multiple adjacent rib fractures likely has a flail chest.
  • Flail chest occurs when three or more consecutive ribs are fractured in at least two places, resulting in a free-floating chest segment.
  • This segment exhibits paradoxical movement:
    • Inward movement during inspiration (while the rest of the chest expands)
    • Outward movement during expiration (while the rest of the chest contracts)
  • This abnormal motion disrupts normal ventilation mechanics, leading to:
    • Hypoventilation
    • Mediastinal flutter (which may cause cardiovascular compromise)
    • Pendular air movement (air shunts between lungs inefficiently)
  • Management of flail chest includes:
    • Analgesia to relieve pain and promote effective breathing
    • Oxygen supplementation
    • Intercostal chest drain (if pneumothorax/hemothorax present)
    • Intubation with positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) if respiratory failure occurs
    • Rib fixation in selected severe cases

Explanation of other options:

Cheyne Stokes (Option A): Characterized by cyclic crescendo-decrescendo respirations with apnea. Seen in congestive heart failure and central nervous system disorders-not associated with trauma or flail chest.

Biot (Option B): Irregular breaths with intermittent apnea, usually due to brainstem injury or raised intracranial pressure, not trauma-induced.

Kussmaul (Option C): Deep, rapid breathing seen in metabolic acidosis (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis), not typical of thoracic trauma or rib fractures.

questions.text: A child presents with photosensitivity and multiple skin cancers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Xeroderma pigmentosum is a rare genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair leading to photosensitivity and early-onset skin cancers.

  • Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in nucleotide excision repair mechanisms, specifically the inability to repair UV-induced thymidine dimers in DNA.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Severe sunburn with minimal UV exposure
    • Photosensitivity
    • Freckling and hyperpigmented macules in sun-exposed areas
    • Development of multiple skin malignancies (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma) at an early age
    • Ocular involvement and neurological degeneration in some cases
  • The hallmark is early and multiple cutaneous malignancies, especially in sun-exposed regions.

Explanation of other options:

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option B): A genetic disorder of collagen type I causing bone fragility, blue sclerae, and fractures. Photosensitivity or skin cancer is not a feature.

Hypervitaminosis A (Option C): Causes dry skin, alopecia, hepatosplenomegaly, and pseudotumor cerebri, but not skin cancer or DNA repair defects.

Paget's disease (Option D): A disorder of abnormal bone remodeling, usually in elderly individuals. It does not affect children or cause skin cancers.

questions.text: A floppy infant presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pompe disease presents in infancy with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly, due to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes affecting cardiac and skeletal muscle.

  • Pompe disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type II) is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by acid α-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency.
  • This leads to accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes, especially in the cardiac and skeletal muscles.
  • Clinical Features of Infantile Pompe Disease:
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Macroglossia
    • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy → Cardiomegaly on X-ray
    • Feeding difficulties
    • Respiratory distress
  • Investigations:
    • Chest X-ray: Cardiomegaly
    • Elevated CK, AST, ALT
    • ECG: Short PR interval, tall QRS
    • PAS-positive vacuoles in muscle biopsy
    • Confirmatory test: Enzyme assay showing low acid α-glucosidase
  • Management:
    • Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) - Alglucosidase alfa
    • Supportive care (nutrition, respiratory)

Explanation of other options:

Transposition of the Great Arteries (Option B): Presents with cyanosis early in life. While cardiomegaly may be seen, hypotonia and hepatomegaly are not typical features.

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option C): Causes cyanosis and a boot-shaped heart on X-ray. It does not present with generalized hypotonia or hepatomegaly.

Ebstein's anomaly (Option D): Involves downward displacement of tricuspid valve, presenting with cyanosis and right-sided heart failure. Hypotonia and hepatomegaly are not characteristic.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the use of the drug in the given image
questions.solution:
EMLA cream contains prilocaine, which can cause methemoglobinemia, especially in infants and patients with G6PD deficiency.

  • EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics) is a topical anesthetic composed of:
    • 2.5% lidocaine
    • 2.5% prilocaine
  • It is used for surface anesthesia, typically before procedures like venipuncture, minor skin surgeries, or cannulation.
  • One of its known rare but serious side effects is methemoglobinemia, particularly due to prilocaine, which is metabolized to o-toluidine, a known oxidizing agent that reduces the oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin.
  • This risk is more significant in:
    • Infants
    • Patients with G6PD deficiency
    • Patients receiving large or repeated doses

Explanation of other options:

EMLA contains ropivacaine and lidocaine (Option A): EMLA does not contain ropivacaine; it contains lidocaine and prilocaine in equal concentrations.

EMLA contains 5% lignocaine (Option C): EMLA contains 2.5% lidocaine (lignocaine) and 2.5% prilocaine, not 5% lidocaine alone.

EMLA acts within 15 minutes (Option D): EMLA typically requires at least 60 minutes under occlusion to achieve full effect; it does not act in 15 minutes.

questions.text: A patient suffers an inversion injury to the ankle during a football match. Which structure is most likely to get injured?
questions.solution:
The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured structure in inversion ankle sprains due to its anatomical location and relative weakness among lateral ligaments.

  • The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is part of the lateral ligament complex of the ankle, which also includes the calcaneofibular and posterior talofibular ligaments.
  • It extends from the anterior margin of the lateral malleolus (fibula) to the neck of the talus.
  • During an inversion injury, the foot rolls inward, placing excessive strain on the lateral side of the ankle-especially the ATFL.
  • This ligament is most commonly injured in low ankle sprains, particularly during sports or missteps.
  • Injury Grading:
    • Grade I: Mild stretching
    • Grade II: Partial tear
    • Grade III: Complete rupture
  • Clinical Features:
    • Pain and swelling over the lateral malleolus
    • Positive anterior drawer test
    • Bruising, tenderness, and instability of the ankle joint
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical examination (anterior drawer test)
    • X-rays to rule out fracture
    • MRI for soft tissue injury assessment
  • Treatment:
    • Grades I & II: RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation), bracing, physiotherapy
    • Grade III: May require surgical repair

Explanation of other options:

Tibialis anterior tendon (Option A): Primarily involved in dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot; not typically injured in lateral (inversion) sprains as it lies anterior-medially.

Tibialis posterior tendon (Option B): Supports the medial longitudinal arch and assists in inversion; more commonly injured in medial ankle injuries or overuse, not lateral inversion sprains.

Extensor hallucis longus tendon (Option C): Involved in extension of the big toe and dorsiflexion; lies on the anterior ankle and is not subjected to strain during inversion.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459212/

questions.text: A 40-year-old female, known case of myasthenia gravis on mycophenolate mofetil and pyridostigmine, now presents with breathing difficulties. Her serum calcium is found to be 13.5 mg/dL. What is the most likely cause of her hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Primary hyperparathyroidism, most commonly due to a parathyroid adenoma, is the most likely cause of persistent, significant hypercalcemia in this patient.

  • Hypercalcemia in this patient is unlikely to be drug-induced or paraneoplastic given her background and medication.
  • The most consistent and common cause of chronic hypercalcemia, especially with levels >13 mg/dL, is primary hyperparathyroidism, which is most frequently caused by a parathyroid adenoma.
  • Myasthenia gravis and her treatment do not explain hypercalcemia. The finding is likely incidental and points toward coexisting primary hyperparathyroidism.

Primary Hyperparathyroidism

  • Cause: Solitary adenoma (∼80% cases)
  • Pathophysiology: Excess PTH secretion → ↑ bone resorption, ↑ renal calcium reabsorption, ↓ phosphate reabsorption
  • Symptoms mnemonic: "Stones, Bones, Groans, Psychiatric Moans"
    • Stones: Nephrolithiasis
    • Bones: Osteitis fibrosa cystica, bone pain
    • Groans: Constipation, abdominal pain
    • Psychiatric Moans: Depression, confusion
  • Serum Findings: ↑ Ca²⁺, ↓ PO4³⁻, ↑ PTH, normal or high ALP

Explanation of other options:

Small cell carcinoma of lung (Option A): This tumor is associated with SIADH and ectopic ACTH, not hypercalcemia.

Drug-induced hypercalcemia (Option B): Neither mycophenolate mofetil nor pyridostigmine are associated with hypercalcemia.

Adenocarcinoma lung (Option D): This histological type rarely causes hypercalcemia. If any lung cancer does, it's squamous cell carcinoma via PTHrP secretion.

A. Select a case and a control.
B. Matching
C. Measure total exposure
D. Analysis

B. Matching

C. Measure total exposure

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with acute epigastric pain and elevated serum lipase. He was stabilised after three days. What is the most common pathology associated with the chest X-ray obtained?
questions.solution:
• The patient's presentation with acute epigastric pain and elevated serum lipase indicates acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis can lead to systemic inflammation and various complications, including ARDS, a type of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema.
  • ARDS leads to increased permeability of the pulmonary capillaries, resulting in the leakage of fluid into the alveoli, which causes diffuse opacities on a chest X-ray.

Explanation for other options:

Acute Pulmonary Oedema (ARDS) (Option B): Acute pulmonary oedema is cardiogenic.

Pulmonary thromboembolism (Option C): Pulmonary thromboembolism will not show any abnormality on chest X-ray.

Miliary tuberculosis (TB) (Option D): Miliary TB can present with diffuse micronodular opacities on a chest X-ray, resembling millet seeds, and is typically associated with a history of chronic symptoms like fever, weight loss, and night sweats.

Reference:Acute lung injury and ARDS in acute pancreatitis: Mechanisms and potential intervention - PMC

choices.text: Change to salbutamol MDI twice daily

questions.text:
A 26-year-old patient with a history of bronchial asthma experiences two daytime episodes and one nighttime episode per week. He uses albuterol as needed. Post-bronchodilator spirometry shows an improvement in FEV1 from 76% to 83%.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient has mild persistent asthma and requires initiation of an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) like fluticasone for long-term control.

  • This patient's symptoms; daytime attacks more than once weekly and nighttime symptoms, fulfill the criteria for mild persistent asthma.
  • The partial reversibility of airway obstruction seen on spirometry (FEV1 improving from 76% to 83% after a bronchodilator) also supports this diagnosis.
  • In such cases, relying solely on short-acting β2-agonists like albuterol is not sufficient.
  • Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) such as fluticasone are the cornerstone of controller therapy, reducing airway inflammation and the frequency of exacerbations.
  • According to the stepwise approach to asthma management:
    • Step 1 (intermittent): PRN short-acting β2-agonists (SABAs) for symptoms less than once a week.
    • Step 2 (mild persistent): Regular low-dose ICS is introduced, typically when symptoms occur ≥3 times per week or nocturnal symptoms occur ≥1 per week.
    • Step 3-5: Progressive escalation depending on control, including higher ICS doses, LABAs, oral steroids, and biologics like omalizumab or mepolizumab.

Explanation of other options:

Add oral prednisolone 10 mg daily (Option A): Oral corticosteroids are reserved for severe cases or acute exacerbations; their chronic use is avoided due to systemic side effects.

Continue albuterol whenever required (Option B): While effective for symptom relief, albuterol alone does not address the underlying inflammation seen in persistent asthma.

Change to salbutamol MDI twice daily (Option D): Salbutamol is not intended for regular scheduled use. Maintenance therapy in persistent asthma requires an ICS, not increased use of a SABA.

questions.text: Identify the labelling correctly:
questions.solution:
A - Superior Vena Cava: The superior vena cava is usually located on the right side of the image, returning deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the right atrium of the heart.

B - Ascending Aorta: The ascending aorta originates from the left ventricle and is positioned just slightly to the left of the superior vena cava.

C - Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is located just beneath the ascending aorta and carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs.

D - Descending Aorta: The descending aorta is located posteriorly, descending downward after arching around the left side of the heart.

questions.text: An infant presents with hypotonia, macroglossia, and hepatomegaly. Additionally, a patient with elevated triglycerides (esterified with long-chain fatty acids) presents with fatigue, and a muscle biopsy reveals fat vacuoles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Carnitine deficiency manifests with fatigue, and muscle biopsy shows fat vacuoles

Carnitine Deficiency:

  • Common in preterm babies
  • Cause:
    • Inadequate biosynthesis or renal leakage.
    • Hemolysis
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Impaired fatty acid oxidation→hypoglycemia & Lipid accumulation→muscular weakness

Explanation for other options:

Fatty Acid Synthase defect (Option B) causes growth retardation, neurological deficits due to impaired myelination, fatigue or muscle weakness from energy imbalance, impaired wound healing and skin abnormalities due to disrupted lipid synthesis.

Lipoprotein Lipase Deficiency (Option C) causes eruptive xanthomas, lipemia retinalis and recurrent pancreatitis.

Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (Option D) causes Hypoketotic hypoglycemia, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, seizures, coma during metabolic crises, hepatomegaly and liver dysfunction due to fatty infiltration and sudden unexplained death.
