questions.solution: Chromophobe RCC has a distinct histological appearance, showing plant cells, perinuclear halos, and raisinoid nuclei similar to the histopathological image above.

questions.text: Which disease is associated with the term "Desert Rheumatism"?
questions.solution: Options B, C, and D are not referred to as Desert Rheumatism.

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is contraindicated in the treatment of iron poisoning?
questions.solution: BAL (Dimercaprol) is a chelator primarily used to treat poisoning by heavy metals such as arsenic, mercury, and lead. However, it is contraindicated in iron poisoning because it does not effectively bind to iron. It may displace iron from its binding sites, potentially worsening the toxicity. Therefore, using BAL in iron poisoning could exacerbate the condition rather than alleviate it.

questions.text: A male patient with ARDS shows poor response to oxygen therapy. What is the primary role of interleukin-8 (IL-8) in the pathogenesis of ARDS?
questions.solution:
Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a potent chemokine that recruits neutrophils to the site of inflammation in the lungs in Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).


Explanation for other options:

Endothelial Cell Activation (Option A), mediated by IL-1 and TNF-α, leads to increased vascular permeability and upregulation of adhesion molecules. This facilitates leukocyte adhesion and migration, an essential step in the inflammatory response.

Macrophage Activation (Option C) is influenced by IL-4 and IL-10. IL-4 promotes the M2 anti-inflammatory phenotype, supporting tissue repair and resolution of inflammation. IL-10 suppresses pro-inflammatory cytokine production, modulating macrophages to dampen inflammatory responses.

Promotion of Surfactant Production (Option D) is indirectly supported by IL-6 by influencing surfactant protein expression, though it is not the primary cytokine for this role.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is recommended to begin an exercise regimen. Which of the following glucose transporters is sensitive to insulin?
questions.solution:
This GLUT 4 is insulin-sensitive and is primarily found in adipose tissue, cardiac and skeletal muscle. During exercise, insulin facilitates glucose uptake via GLUT4, helping regulate blood glucose levels.


GLUT 1-5 are facilitative bidirectional transporters, whereas SGLT 1 is a sodium-dependent unidirectional transporter.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of easy fatiguability, anemia, hyperpigmentation over the knuckles, oral mucosa, palms, and hands, along with tachycardia. Blood pressure is recorded at 80/60 mmHg, and serum sodium is 130 mEq/L. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The constellation of fatigue, anemia, hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and hyponatremia is typical of Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency).

  • Primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as Addison's disease, results from destruction or dysfunction of the adrenal cortex, leading to decreased production of glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgens.
  • The most common causes include autoimmune adrenalitis (most common worldwide), tuberculosis (most common in India), fungal infections, HIV/AIDS, metastatic malignancies, or bilateral adrenalectomy.
  • The clinical features stem from hormone deficiencies:
    • Glucocorticoid deficiency causes: fatigue, weight loss, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, postural hypotension, and hyponatremia (dilutional).
    • Mineralocorticoid deficiency leads to hypotension, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.
    • Excess ACTH (due to lack of cortisol feedback) results in hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas, skin creases, and mucosa.
    • Androgen deficiency in females may cause reduced body hair and libido.
  • Investigations:
    • Random cortisol: >500 nmol/L rules out adrenal insufficiency.
    • Short ACTH stimulation test: If cortisol remains <500 nmol/L after stimulation, it confirms adrenal insufficiency.
    • Plasma renin and aldosterone levels help detect mineralocorticoid deficiency.
    • Autoimmune adrenal antibodies may be checked if autoimmune cause is suspected; CT/MRI may be used in antibody-negative cases.
  • Treatment:
    • Glucocorticoid replacement: Oral hydrocortisone is first-line; prednisolone or dexamethasone are alternatives.
    • Mineralocorticoid replacement: Fludrocortisone corrects aldosterone deficiency.

Explanation of other options:

Conn's syndrome (Option A): Characterized by hyperaldosteronism, leading to hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Hyperpigmentation and hypotension are not features.

Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option C): May present with fatigue and anemia, but does not explain hyperpigmentation, hypotension, or hyponatremia. Neurological symptoms like paresthesias and gait disturbances would typically be present.

Cushing syndrome (Option D): Features include central obesity, moon face, purple striae, and hypertension due to cortisol excess. Hypotension and hyperpigmentation are generally not observed, making it unlikely here.

questions.text: A child presents with growth failure. Biochemical analysis shows normal Ca2+, normal PTH, reduced phosphate, and increased ALP. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hypophosphatemic rickets presents with low phosphate, elevated ALP, and normal calcium and PTH, due to defective renal phosphate reabsorption.

  • Hypophosphatemic rickets (especially X-linked) is the most common hereditary cause of rickets.
  • It results from renal phosphate wasting despite normal vitamin D and calcium levels.
  • In these patients:
    • Serum phosphate is low due to proximal renal tubular phosphate loss.
    • Calcium remains normal because intestinal absorption is preserved.
    • PTH is normal or mildly elevated, unlike in nutritional rickets.
    • ALP is elevated due to increased osteoblastic activity during defective bone mineralization.
  • The child presents with growth failure, a key clinical feature.
  • Radiographic features of rickets such as metaphyseal fraying, cupping, and splaying are usually seen.

Explanation of other options:

Nutritional rickets (Option A): PTH is elevated, and calcium is often low or low-normal due to vitamin D deficiency. Also, 25(OH)D is decreased.

Type 1 VDDR (Option C): Caused by 1-alpha hydroxylase deficiency, leading to low 1,25(OH)2D, low calcium and phosphate, elevated PTH, and ALP. It does not show normal calcium and PTH.

Type 2 VDDR (Option D): Due to end-organ resistance to 1,25(OH)2D. Despite normal or elevated 1,25(OH)2D, calcium and phosphate are low, PTH is elevated, and ALP is raised.

choices.text: Nothing, as the child is already exposed

questions.text: Ajay, a 3-year-old child, is the younger brother of Anuj, who is currently undergoing treatment for diphtheria in the hospital. Ajay lives in the same household and received his diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago. What is the most appropriate course of action for the care of Ajay?
questions.solution:
Ajay is a household contact of a diphtheria case and should receive erythromycin prophylaxis, even though he is vaccinated and asymptomatic.

  • When a confirmed case of diphtheria is identified, close contacts (like household members) are at risk of asymptomatic carriage or developing the disease.
  • Recommended Management for Asymptomatic Close Contacts (like Ajay):
    • Antibiotic Prophylaxis:
      • Oral erythromycin 40-50 mg/kg/day (max 2 g/day) for 10 days
      • OR single dose of benzathine penicillin G
    • Vaccination Review:
      • Booster only if:
      • Less than 3 doses taken previously
      • No booster in the last 5 years
      • Ajay received his last diphtheria vaccine dose 16 months ago, so he does not need a booster now.
    • Monitoring:
      • Observe for symptoms for 7 days
      • Take cultures if symptoms develop

Explanation of other options:

One booster dose (Option A): Not needed now, as Ajay received a dose within the last 5 years. Boosters are only required if the last dose was ≥5 years ago.

Nothing, as the child is already exposed (Option B): Incorrect, because vaccination does not guarantee full protection, and exposed individuals can still become carriers or symptomatic.

Erythromycin + diphtheria toxoid (Option C): Not indicated in Ajay's case, as diphtheria toxoid is only added if: Immunization is incomplete or last booster was ≥5 years ago

questions.text: A farmer presents with foot swelling and discharging sinuses. Staining of the lesion shows Gram-positive filamentous structures.
questions.solution:
Nocardia brasiliensis causes actinomycetoma, presenting with swelling, sinuses, and granules, and appears as Gram-positive filamentous bacteria on stains.

  • Nocardia brasiliensis is a soil-dwelling aerobic actinomycete, commonly causing actinomycetoma; a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. Farmers and those who walk barefoot are at higher risk.
  • Key clinical features of actinomycetoma include:
    • Painless swelling of the foot
    • Multiple discharging sinuses
    • Presence of sulphur granules (actually colonies of the bacteria)
    • Gram-positive, filamentous, weakly acid-fast rods on microscopy
    • Common in tropical/subtropical regions
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by Gram stain, acid-fast staining, culture, and biopsy.
  • Treatment includes trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) and prolonged antibiotics.

Explanation of other options:

Sporothrix schenckii (Option B): A dimorphic fungus causing sporotrichosis, typically follows a thorn prick and causes nodular lymphangitis, not discharging sinuses with filamentous Gram-positive organisms.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C): Causes acute pyogenic infections, abscesses, or cellulitis. It is Gram-positive cocci in clusters, not filamentous organisms, and doesn’t cause actinomycetoma.

Aspergillus (Option D): A septate hyaline fungus causing aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised hosts. It is not Gram-positive and does not appear filamentous on Gram stain.

choices.text: Penectomy + Superficial inguinal lymph node dissection

questions.text: An elderly male presents with the following lesion as shown and then diagnosed with carcinoma of stage T3 lesion with no clinically palpable inguinal lymph node. What is management?
questions.solution:
In T3 penile carcinoma with clinically negative nodes, prophylactic superficial inguinal lymph node dissection is indicated along with penectomy to address occult metastasis.

  • Penile carcinoma staging determines the need for lymph node dissection.
  • A T3 lesion indicates involvement of the urethra or corpus cavernosum, suggesting locally advanced disease.
  • Even when inguinal lymph nodes are not palpable, there is a significant risk of micrometastasis.
  • Hence, superficial inguinal lymph node dissection is advised prophylactically to detect early nodal involvement, which improves prognosis.
  • Radical penectomy is performed to excise the primary tumour.
  • Deeper node dissection or more aggressive interventions are reserved for clinically positive nodes or bulky disease.

Explanation of other options:

Penectomy + Ilio-inguinal lymph node dissection (Option A): This is reserved for cases with clinically palpable or confirmed metastatic inguinal lymphadenopathy, not clinically node-negative patients.

Penectomy + Orchidectomy (Option B): Orchidectomy is not indicated unless testicular involvement is suspected, which is not suggested here.

Penectomy alone (Option D): This addresses the primary lesion but does not treat possible occult lymphatic spread, which is essential in T3 disease.

questions.text: A patient with cervical cancer is found to have pelvic sidewall involvement and hydronephrosis on evaluation. What is the stage?
questions.solution:
Stage III B cervical cancer is defined by pelvic sidewall involvement and/or hydronephrosis, both of which are present in this patient.

  • The FIGO 2018 staging system for cervical cancer emphasizes anatomical spread, including the pelvic sidewall and hydronephrosis as critical criteria for Stage III B.
  • Stage III B:
    • Tumor extends to the pelvic sidewall
    • And/or causes hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney (not due to other causes)
  • In this patient:
    • Pelvic sidewall involvement → suggests extensive local invasion.
    • Hydronephrosis → due to ureteral compression/obstruction by tumor, a hallmark of advanced disease.
  • Hence, the diagnosis is Stage III B cervical cancer.

Reference:

https://radiopaedia.org/articles/cervical-cancer-staging-1

questions.text: Which combination of metabolites is typically produced in cases of methanol poisoning?
questions.solution:
In methanol poisoning, metabolites like formic acid and lactic acid accumulate and cause toxic effects like histotoxic hypoxia and optic neuritis.

  • Methanol poisoning causes the formation of Formate ions. Acids formed lead to defective mitochondria and lactic acidosis, which increase AG. Increase in plasma osmolality. Osmolal gap is also seen.
  • Methanol, also known as wood alcohol, is a CNS depressant often found in illicit liquors. It is highly toxic. Methanol toxicity is infamous for causing metabolic acidosis and optic nerve damage, leading to snowfield vision and potential blindness.

Methanol Poisoning:

Metabolism and Pathophysiology:

  1. Methanol → Formaldehyde (via alcohol dehydrogenase).
  2. Formaldehyde → Formic acid (via aldehyde dehydrogenase).
    • Formic acid leads to:
      • Metabolic acidosis.
      • Retinal damage (optic neuritis).

Symptoms:

  • Early: Severe abdominal cramps.
  • Neurological: Snowfield vision, vision loss, dilated and fixed pupils, muscular weakness.
  • Systemic: CNS and cardiac depression.

Treatment:

  1. Stabilisation: Immediate supportive care.
  2. Haemodialysis: To remove methanol and formic acid.
  3. Antidotes:
    • Ethanol: Competes with methanol for alcohol dehydrogenase.
    • Fomepizole: Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase.
  4. Other Therapies:
    • Folinic acid: Enhances formic acid metabolism.
    • Sodium bicarbonate: Treats acidosis.

Glycolic acid and oxalic acid (Option A, C, D) are mainly formed in ethylene glycol poisoning

Postmortem Findings:

  • Putamen haemorrhagic necrosis (specific finding).
  • Absence of postmortem clotting.

choices.text: The sucrose lysis test is used for confirmation
Flow cytometry is the best investigation
The most common cause of death is heart failure

questions.text: Which of the following statements about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is accurate?
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry to evaluate CD55 and CD59 is the best investigation to diagnose paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria.


Sucrose lysis test (Option B) is no longer the test of choice for diagnosis.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient with a prior helminth infection presents with motile larvae (~200 microns) in the stool, while no eggs are detected. Which of the following parasites is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Rhabditiform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis hatch and migrate to the intestinal lumen and are excreted in the stool. No eggs are seen.


Explanation for other options:

Ancylostoma (Hookworm) (Option A) eggs, not larvae, are found in stool. Causes iron deficiency anaemia due to intestinal blood loss.

Ascaris lumbricoides (Option B), large eggs with thick-walled, mammillated surfaces are seen in stool, not larvae.

Schistosoma (Option C) non-motile ova with characteristic spines (lateral in S. mansoni, terminal in S. haematobium) are found in stool or urine.

questions.text: Which of the following beta-blockers is effective in patients with reduced ejection fraction and has been shown to reduce mortality in chronic heart failure without causing long-term worsening of the condition?
questions.solution:
Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta blocker that is beneficial in chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). It helps improve heart function, reduce symptoms, and reduce mortality over time in heart failure patients.

  • Beta-blockers that have been proven to improve the survival of patients with HFrEF/Chronic HF are
    • Bisoprolol
    • Metoprolol
    • Carvedilol

Explanation for other options:

Propranolol (Option A) is a non-selective beta blocker, which blocks both beta-1 and beta-2 receptors. It is not typically preferred in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction as it may cause bronchospasm due to beta-2 receptor blockade and has less favourable long-term outcomes compared to cardioselective beta blockers like bisoprolol.

Pindolol (Option C) is a non-selective beta blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA), meaning it partially stimulates beta receptors while blocking them. This property is generally not ideal in chronic heart failure, as it may not provide the same mortality benefits as other beta-blockers without ISA.

Esmolol (Option D) is a short-acting, cardioselective beta blocker typically used for acute conditions like arrhythmias and perioperative hypertension. It is not used for long-term management of chronic heart failure.

Learning Outcome:
