questions.text: Identify the given drain:
questions.solution:
The image depicts a Romovac drain, a commonly used closed suction drain that applies negative pressure to collect postoperative fluid.

  • Closed suction drains, such as Romovac, Jackson-Pratt (JP), and Hemovac, are self-contained drainage systems that apply negative pressure to evacuate blood, pus, or serous fluid from surgical sites.
  • The Romovac specifically uses spring-loaded bellows to maintain continuous negative pressure.
  • It helps prevent hematoma, seroma, and infection, and allows for quantifiable drainage output.
  • Commonly used in orthopedic, plastic, and oncologic surgeries.

Types of Surgical Drains Overview:


Explanation of other options:

Underwater seal drain (Option A): Used for thoracic drainage (e.g., pneumothorax, hemothorax), not for routine surgical site drainage. It prevents air from re-entering the pleural space.


Nelaton drain (Option B): A straight soft rubber urinary catheter, used in short-term bladder catheterization, not a surgical site drain.


References:

Jackson Pratt (JP) Drain - Saint John’s Cancer Institute

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents in labor with active genital ulcers, likely of infectious etiology such as Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV).
questions.solution:
LSCS is recommended to prevent vertical transmission of infection (especially HSV) from mother to neonate during vaginal delivery in the presence of active genital ulcers.

  • Genital ulcers in pregnancy are often caused by HSV-2.
  • If the mother has active lesions at the time of delivery, vertical transmission of the virus can occur, leading to neonatal herpes, which has high morbidity and mortality.
  • Neonatal herpes can manifest as:
    • Localized skin, eye, mouth (SEM) infection
    • Disseminated infection
    • Central nervous system involvement
  • To prevent transmission:
    • LSCS is the preferred mode of delivery when active lesions or prodromal symptoms are present at the time of labor.
  • Timing: LSCS is ideally performed within 4-6 hours of membrane rupture to minimize viral exposure.

Explanation of other options:

Classic Caesarean Section (Option B): Involves a vertical uterine incision, reserved for rare indications (e.g., transverse lie with back down, placenta previa, or lower uterine segment not developed). Not indicated for genital ulcers.

Vaginal Delivery (Option C): Contraindicated in active genital herpes or suspicious ulcers due to high risk of neonatal HSV infection.

Induction of Labour (Option D): Inducing labor increases risk of prolonged exposure to infection, making it unsafe in the presence of active genital ulcers.

questions.text: During which phase of clinical trials is the appropriate dosage range of a drug established?
questions.solution:
• Phase 1 focuses on evaluating the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of a drug in a small group of healthy volunteers or patients.
  • The primary goal is to determine the drug's safety profile and establish an appropriate dose range.
  • Dosing is initially determined based on preclinical data and adjusted as necessary based on observed effects and tolerability in this phase.

Phases of clinical trials:

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain, and serum triglyceride levels are 1500 mg/dL. What is the most likely defect present?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of severe abdominal pain and elevated serum triglyceride levels suggests familial chylomicronaemia syndrome, and it is caused by an Apo-CII defect.

Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia (Familial Chylomicronemia Syndrome)

Explanation for other options:

Apo B-48 defect (Option A) is commonly associated with abetalipoproteinemia. Clinical features include fat malabsorption, Vitamin K deficiency, and Vitamin A deficiency symptoms.

Apo B-100 defect (Option B) (Hypercholesterolemia) presents with atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease (early onset) and Tendon xanthomas.

LDL receptor defect (Option D) (Hypercholesterolemia) presents with atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease (early onset) and Tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: Based on the constituents, identify the fluid given to post-operative patients:
questions.solution:
The given composition closely matches Ringer lactate, an isotonic fluid commonly used postoperatively to maintain electrolyte balance and prevent metabolic acidosis.

  • Ringer Lactate (also called Hartmann's Solution) is a crystalloid isotonic solution designed to mimic plasma electrolyte composition.
  • It contains:
    • Na⁺ - 130 mmol/L
    • Cl⁻ - 109 mmol/L
    • K⁺ - 4 mmol/L
    • Ca²⁺ - 1.5 mmol/L
    • Lactate - 28 mmol/L
    • Osmolality ~273 mOsm/kg
  • This makes it ideal for perioperative and postoperative fluid replacement, especially since lactate acts as a buffer by being metabolized into bicarbonate, which prevents hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, unlike normal saline.
  • Ringer lactate is rapidly cleared due to suppression of ADH, promoting diuresis, making it suitable for patients at risk of volume overload.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Haemaccel (Option B): It is a colloid solution containing gelatin and electrolytes, mainly used in shock or blood loss. It is not routinely used for postoperative maintenance fluids and doesn't match the above composition.

Isolyte P (Option C): Contains more calcium (2.7 mEq/L) and includes magnesium and bicarbonate not present in the given table. It is typically used for pediatric maintenance rather than adult post-op care.

Isolyte M (Option D): Has a higher sodium content (~140 mEq/L), more potassium (5 mEq/L), and acetate instead of lactate as a buffer. It doesn't match the given profile.

Reference:

Intravenous fluids - Pocket Book of Hospital Care for Children - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 29-week pregnant woman is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) based on Doppler findings and presents with calf tenderness. Which anticoagulant is most appropriate for treatment?
questions.solution:
• Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), such as enoxaparin, is the preferred anticoagulant for treating DVT in pregnancy.
  • It is safe, does not cross the placenta, and has a lower risk of causing heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) than unfractionated heparin.
  • LMWH is also effective in preventing the extension of the thrombus and reducing the risk of pulmonary embolism, making it the standard treatment for DVT during pregnancy.

Key Takeaway:

Reference:

  1. Antiphospholipid Syndrome - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. Anticoagulants

questions.text: An ICU patient develops a central line-associated infection. Microscopy reveals gram-positive, oval-shaped organisms reproducing by budding. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Candida species are yeast-like fungi that reproduce by budding and can cause central line infections, especially in immunocompromised patients.

Explanation for other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option A): These are gram-positive cocci in clusters, not oval-shaped.

Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option C): These are gram-positive cocci in clusters, not oval-shaped.

Escherichia coli (Option D): These are gram-negative rods.

questions.text: In the given graph, identify the type of inhibition:
questions.solution:
In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme, often resulting in an increased Km without affecting Vmax.

Uncompetitive Inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing it from converting the substrate into a product. This type of inhibition results in:

  • Decrease in Km: Since the inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, it effectively lowers the concentration of the enzyme available for reaction, making the apparent affinity of the enzyme for the substrate appear higher
  • Decrease in Vmax: The inhibitor reduces the maximum rate of reaction because it prevents the enzyme-substrate complex from proceeding to form the product, thus lowering the overall reaction rate at saturating substrate concentrations.

Reference:

  1. Physiology, Noncompetitive Inhibitor - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Persistent occipito-posterior (OP) face-to-pubis delivery is most likely to be seen in which pelvic type?
questions.solution:
Persistent occipito-posterior (OP) and face-to-pubis deliveries are most commonly associated with the anthropoid pelvis, due to its elongated anteroposterior diameter.

  • The anthropoid pelvis has:
    • An oval-shaped inlet elongated in the anteroposterior direction
    • Straight side walls, wide sacrosciatic notches
    • A narrow subpubic angle
  • This configuration:
    • Favors the occiput of the fetus remaining posterior rather than rotating anteriorly
    • Makes persistent OP positions and face-to-pubis deliveries more likely
    • These deliveries are usually longer and more difficult due to malrotation and the need for greater head flexion or deflexion

questions.text: Diagnose the following based on the images provided below.
questions.solution:
The given image reveals cutaneous nodules, and its HPE shows Michaelis-Guttman's bodies; thus, this patient is most likely suffering from Malakoplakia.

Explanation for other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A) granulomas exhibit caseating necrosis surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and Langhans giant cells, along with acid-fast bacilli on Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

Pyoderma gangrenosum (Option C) is an idiopathic, ulcerative skin condition without granulomas or the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. It primarily involves neutrophilic dermatosis. The clinical appearance is of rapid ulceration with undermined borders.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option D) is a malignant epithelial tumour. It displays keratin pearls, atypical squamous cells, and invasive behaviour but lacks granulomas or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. Cytologic atypia and the absence of granulomatous inflammation differentiate it from malakoplakia.

questions.text: In a patient with renal failure who has received Vecuronium or Rocuronium, which of the following agents is typically used for reversal of the neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor commonly used to reverse the effects of non-depolarising muscle relaxants like vecuronium and rocuronium.

  • In patients with renal failure, neostigmine is preferred because it does not rely on renal excretion as much as sugammadex.
  • Neostigmine works by increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, outcompeting the muscle relaxant and reversing the blockade.

Explanation for other options:

Although Sugammadex(Option A) is a highly effective reversal agent for vecuronium and rocuronium, it is contraindicated in patients with severe renal impairment. Since sugammadex is primarily excreted by the kidneys, its use in renal failure could lead to prolonged effects and potential accumulation.

Physostigmine (Option C) is not used to reverse neuromuscular blockades caused by vecuronium or rocuronium. It is mainly used to treat anticholinergic toxicity, as it can cross the blood-brain barrier.

Rivastigmine (Option D) is not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade. It is primarily used to treat cognitive symptoms in Alzheimer's disease and other dementias.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is found unconscious after playing with shampoo that contained rotenone. Which of the following enzymes is inhibited by this compound?
questions.solution:
Rotenone inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) of the electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia.

Electron Transport Chain:

  • ETC complexes are present in the inner mitochondrial membrane
  • There are 5 protein complexes in ETC: Complex I to V

2,4-dinitrophenol (Option D) is an uncoupling agent that disrupts the coupling of electron transport and ATP synthesis in mitochondria. If DNP were added, it would uncouple oxidative phosphorylation from respiration but wouldn't block respiration entirely.

questions.text: A woman seeks Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks of gestation due to fetal anomalies. Whose opinion is not required in this decision?
questions.solution:
The opinion of a lawyer is not required for MTP beyond 24 weeks; only a medical board consisting of a gynecologist, radiologist, and pediatrician is mandated by the MTP Act.

  • Under the MTP (Amendment) Act, 2021, MTP beyond 24 weeks is legally permitted only in cases of substantial fetal anomalies.
  • This requires the opinion of a state-level medical board, constituted as follows:
    • Gynaecologist: Evaluates maternal health and carries out or advises on termination.
    • Radiologist: Confirms fetal anomalies through imaging (ultrasound, MRI).
    • Pediatrician: Assesses postnatal prognosis and viability of the fetus.
  • The lawyer is not a member of this medical board. While legal proceedings may occasionally be involved, legal counsel is not needed for medical decision-making or approval under the act.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act:

  • The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.
  • Indications:
    • Maternal Risk
    • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome.
    • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
    • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape.
    • Contraceptive Failure.
  • Qualifications:
    • MBBS, MD/DNB/DGO
    • MBBS who has trained in gynaecology for 6 months
    • MBBS who has performed 25 MTPs under supervision
    • ASHA and AYUSH cannot perform MTP.
  • Additions of 2021 amendment:
    • Abortions allowed up to 20-24 weeks.
    • <20 weeks - Single doctor’s decision; 20-24 weeks - 2 doctors.
    • Extension of abortion rights to single, unmarried females.
    • Inclusion of marital rape under the MTP Act.
    • Abortions >24 weeks in cases of significant fetal anomalies with no gestational upper limit, are to be decided by a state medical board(gynecologist, pediatrician, radiologist). (Options A,B,C ruled out)

Reference:

https://nhm.hp.gov.in/storage/app/media/uploaded-files/mtp-amendment-act2021.pdfpage 2

questions.text:
What is the correct chronological sequence of events during neuromuscular transmission leading to an action potential?
1. Sodium channels open in the end plate.
2. Calcium enters at the nerve end plate.
3. Release of acetylcholine.
questions.solution:
Events in Neuromuscular Action Potential Conduction:

2. Calcium enters at the nerve end plate: Calcium ions enter the nerve terminal when an action potential reaches the nerve end. This influx of calcium is crucial for the subsequent release of neurotransmitters.

3. Release of acetylcholine: The entry of calcium ions into the nerve terminal triggers the release of acetylcholine (ACh) from vesicles into the synaptic cleft.

1. Sodium channels open in the end plate: The binding of acetylcholine to receptors on the muscle end plate causes sodium channels to open, leading to an influx of sodium ions into the muscle cell and generating an action potential in the muscle.

questions.text: The most common congenital diaphragmatic hernia seen in neonates is:
questions.solution:
Left posterolateral (Bochdalek) hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) in neonates.

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect where abdominal organs herniate into the thoracic cavity due to a defect in the diaphragm, leading to pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory distress in neonates.
  • Bochdalek hernia is the most common type (90%), occurring due to failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal.
  • Left side involvement is more common (84%) because the left pleuroperitoneal canal closes later than the right, and the presence of the liver on the right provides a protective effect.
  • Symptoms in neonates include:
    • Severe respiratory distress soon after birth
    • Scaphoid (sunken) abdomen
    • Mediastinal shift
    • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Types of CDH:

Explanation of other options:

Right anteromedial (Option B): Refers to Morgagni hernia, which is rare, usually asymptomatic, and less common than left-sided Bochdalek hernias.

Esophageal hiatus (Option C): Hiatal hernias typically present later in life and are usually acquired, not the most common congenital type in neonates.

Central location (Option D): Central tendon defects are very rare and not associated with typical neonatal diaphragmatic hernia presentations.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized body aches, poor wound healing, corkscrew hairs on her arms, and white lines of Frenkel on X-ray as shown below. This clinical presentation is most consistent with which of the following micronutrient deficiencies?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) leads to defective collagen synthesis, resulting in fragile capillaries, bleeding, poor wound healing, corkscrew hairs, and characteristic radiological findings like white lines of Frenkel.

  • Vitamin C plays a crucial role in collagen synthesis, which is essential for maintaining the structural integrity of blood vessels, skin, bone, and connective tissues.
  • Scurvy occurs when there is prolonged deficiency of vitamin C, especially in children with inadequate dietary intake (e.g., lack of fruits and vegetables).
  • Clinical Features of Scurvy:
    • Musculoskeletal pain, particularly in legs
    • Corkscrew hairs, petechiae, ecchymoses
    • Poor wound healing, bleeding gums, anemia
    • Pseudoparalysis: refusal to move limbs due to pain
    • Frog-leg posture
    • Scorbutic rosary at the costochondral junctions
    • White lines of Frenkel (dense metaphyseal lines seen on X-ray)
    • Pelkan spurs: metaphyseal spurs
  • Radiological Signs:
    • White line of Frenkel: dense zone of provisional calcification
    • Wimberger ring: circular calcification surrounding the epiphysis
    • Scorbutic rosary: sharply defined, angular swellings at the costochondral junctions (unlike the smoother swellings in rickets)
  • Treatment:
    • Vitamin C supplementation (100-200 mg/day)
    • Symptom resolution typically begins within 1 week

Explanation of other options:

Zinc deficiency (Option A): Causes growth retardation, alopecia, delayed wound healing, hypogonadism, and dermatitis, but not corkscrew hairs or Frenkel lines.

Copper deficiency (Option C): Leads to anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmented hair, but not the bleeding or radiologic features seen in scurvy.

Iron deficiency (Option D): Presents with pallor, fatigue, irritability, and microcytic hypochromic anemia, but not corkscrew hairs, bleeding gums, or radiologic signs of scurvy.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture healing you can expect in a fracture treated in a manner shown in the X-ray given below?
questions.solution:
Fractures treated with rigid internal fixation heal by primary bone healing, which involves direct remodeling without callus formation.

  • Primary (Direct) Bone Healing occurs when a fracture is anatomically reduced and stabilized with absolute stability, such as with rigid internal fixation (e.g., compression plating).
  • In this process:
    • Osteons (Haversian systems) directly cross the fracture line without forming a callus.
    • Healing occurs via direct remodeling of lamellar bone and cutting cones led by osteoclasts and osteoblasts.
    • Fracture hematoma is disrupted during surgery, preventing endochondral ossification.
    • Healing is slower but results in strong, anatomically aligned bone with minimal deformity.
    • Since no callus forms, X-rays may not show visible signs of healing, making it harder to assess radiologically.
  • This method is often used in diaphyseal fractures of long bones treated surgically with compression plates.

Explanation of other options:

Secondary healing (Option B): Healing occurs via callus formation through endochondral ossification and is typical of fractures treated non-surgically (e.g., casting). It is faster but less precise.

Creeping substitution (Option C): Refers to the gradual replacement of necrotic bone or cartilage with viable lamellar bone during secondary healing; it is a process within indirect healing, not a type itself.

Intramembranous ossification (Option D): A bone formation mechanism where bone develops directly from mesenchymal tissue, typically seen in flat bones like the skull, not a fracture healing type.

questions.text: A patient who was involved in a road traffic accident (RTA) underwent ileal resection. He now presents with fatigue. Which of the following is NOT expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Microcytic hypochromic anemia is typically seen in iron deficiency, not in vitamin B12 deficiency, which occurs after ileal resection and causes macrocytic anemia.

  • The terminal ileum is essential for vitamin B12 absorption, facilitated by intrinsic factor.
  • Ileal resection impairs this process, leading to vitamin B12 deficiency, which results in:
    • Macrocytic anemia
    • Neurological symptoms due to subacute combined degeneration (SACD)
    • Proprioceptive loss and Romberg's sign
    • Cytoplasmic-nuclear dys-synchrony on bone marrow biopsy
  • Key Features of Vitamin B12 Deficiency (Post-Ileal Resection):
    • Anemia Type: Macrocytic, not microcytic
    • Neurologic: Peripheral neuropathy, sensory ataxia, SACD
    • Histology: Hypersegmented neutrophils, megaloblastic changes
    • Bone Marrow: Cytoplasmic maturation continues, but nuclear maturation is delayed → cyto-nuclear dys-synchrony (Option A ruled out)
    • Romberg's sign: Positive due to dorsal column involvement (Option C ruled out)
    • Subacute Combined Degeneration: Posterior and lateral column demyelination (Option D ruled out)

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441923/

choices.text: Myxoid degeneration of the bone marrow

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow examination reveals 22% plasma cells, and biopsy shows deposition of pink, acellular material. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, increased plasma cells, and microscopic findings of pinkish acellular material deposition suggest primary amyloidosis.

Explanation for other options:

Myxoid Degeneration of the Bone Marrow (Option A) refers to the replacement of normal bone marrow tissue with gelatinous material composed of mucopolysaccharides. It is often associated with severe malnutrition, chronic illness, or malignancy.

Plasma Cell Leukaemia (Option C) is a rare and aggressive form of multiple myeloma where plasma cells circulate in large numbers in the blood. It is characterised by anaemia, hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, and organomegaly.

Haemolytic Anaemia (Option D) is a condition where red blood cells are destroyed (haemolysis) faster than they can be produced. It can result from autoimmune disorders, infections, hereditary factors, or external factors like toxins or drugs.

questions.text: The administration of methotrexate leads to decreased synthesis of which of the following nucleotides?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is a folate analogue that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).

  • DHFR is crucial for the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, a cofactor required for the synthesis of thymidylate (TMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis.
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, methotrexate reduces the synthesis of TMP, leading to impaired DNA synthesis, particularly affecting rapidly dividing cells.
  • Methotrexate does not directly inhibit the synthesis of CMP, GMP, or AMP to the same extent.

questions.text: A patient presents with faecal discharge emerging from the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Faecal discharge from the umbilicus suggests a persistent connection between the intestine and the umbilicus.
  • Meckel's diverticulum with a fistula(a congenital remnant of the vitellointestinal duct) can cause faecal umbilical discharge.

Meckel's Diverticulum:


Meckel's Diverticulum and Related Anomalies

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent infections, and imaging reveals the absence of the thymus. Further evaluation shows low levels of adenosine deaminase (ADA). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical features and imaging, this child most likely has Severe combined immunodeficiency.


Explanation for other options:

Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia (Option A) is an X-linked condition due to a defect in B-cell development, leading to a lack of antibodies (hypogammaglobulinemia). The thymus is typically normal in Bruton's, and ADA levels are not usually affected. The immunodeficiency is primarily due to B-cell dysfunction, not T-cell problems, as seen in SCID.

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome (Option C) is caused by a genetic defect in MHC class II expression, leading to impaired T-cell function because T cells cannot recognise antigens properly. The thymus is present in Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome, and ADA levels are typically normal, distinguishing it from SCID, which involves thymic absence and low ADA.

DiGeorge Syndrome (Option C) is caused by a deletion on chromosome 22q11.2, leading to thymic hypoplasia and deficient T-cell development. It often presents with a reduced thymus but not its complete absence. ADA levels are normal, and while there is immune dysfunction, the hallmark features (e.g., cardiac defects, facial anomalies) are typically more pronounced in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text:
Match the following ECG waves with the conditions:

a) Atrial flutter
b) Atrial fibrillation
c) Ventricular tachycardia
e) Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia

1.
2.
3.
4.
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is A) a-2, b-1, c-4, d-3

Atrial Flutter:

In atrial flutter, the standard PR interval is absent due to the presence of continuous, rapid flutter waves instead of discrete P waves. These flutter waves occur in a regular pattern at a rate of 250-350 beats per minute, producing the classic "sawtooth" appearance on ECG. Since the AV node conducts only a fraction of these impulses (commonly 2:1 or 4:1), the ventricular rhythm remains organized, but without a definable PR interval.


Atrial Fibrillation (AF):

The ECG in AF displays an irregularly irregular rhythm with normal QRS complexes. P waves are absent, and the baseline shows erratic, low-amplitude fibrillatory waves. The ventricular rate is typically rapid at onset (120-160 beats/min), but may become slower in chronic cases due to AV nodal fatigue or medication effects.


Ventricular Tachycardia (VT):

In monomorphic VT, the ECG shows wide QRS complexes (>120 ms) with a regular rhythm and uniform morphology across leads. The QRS axis varies based on the site of origin and may resemble either left or right bundle branch block patterns. In polymorphic VT, such as Torsades de Pointes, the QRS morphology changes continuously and is often linked to a prolonged QT interval.


Paroxysmal Ventricular Tachycardia:

This arrhythmia presents on ECG as a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia with QRS duration less than 120 ms and shortened R-R intervals. The heart rate typically ranges between 150-250 beats per minute. P waves are frequently absent or hidden within the T waves.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for transporting iodine into the thyroid follicular cells?
questions.solution:
The Na/l symporter (NIS) is responsible for the active transport of iodine into the thyroid follicular cells. It uses the sodium gradient to co-transport iodine into the cell from the bloodstream.

Pendrin (Option B):

  • Pendrin is an iodide/chloride exchanger located on the apical membrane of thyroid follicular cells.
  • It is involved in the movement of iodide into the follicle lumen but not in the transport of iodine into the thyroid follicular cells.

CI/I symporter (Option C): This option is incorrect, as there is no known CI/I symporter in the thyroid.

questions.text: A heavy lifter presents with lower back ache. Identify the nerve compressed in the following disc prolapse?
questions.solution:
L5 nerve root is the most commonly compressed nerve in lumbar disc prolapse, especially at the L4-L5 level, causing dorsiflexion weakness and pain over the anterolateral leg and dorsum of the foot.

  • Lumbar disc prolapse commonly affects individuals involved in repetitive heavy lifting or strenuous physical activity.
  • In this case:
    • L4-L5 disc prolapse compresses the L5 nerve root.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Lower back pain
    • Radiating leg pain (sciatica) down the lateral thigh, anterolateral leg, and dorsum of the foot
    • Motor weakness: especially of extensor hallucis longus (difficulty lifting the big toe or foot-foot drop)
    • No reflex loss (ankle and knee jerks are typically preserved)
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-Ray : Useful to rule out bony pathology.
    • CT : Reveals disc shape abnormalities, loss of pre-thecal fat, and herniated material pressing on nerve roots or theca.
    • MRI : Gold standard. Clearly shows the prolapsed disc, nerve roots, and thecal sac.
    • Myelography : Useful when CT or MRI is unavailable. Shows dye flow block, indentation, or root cut-off sign in lateral prolapse.

questions.text: At what age is surgery typically performed for cleft lip in infants?
questions.solution:
Cleft lip repair is typically performed at around 3 months of age, following the 'Rule of 10s' to ensure optimal safety and outcomes.

  • Cleft lip is a congenital craniofacial anomaly where there is a failure of fusion of the maxillary and medial nasal processes.
  • Timing of Surgical Repair:
    • The widely followed guideline for cleft lip repair is the "Rule of 10s":
      • 10 weeks of age
      • 10 pounds (approximately 4.5 kg)
      • 10 g/dL hemoglobin
    • This rule ensures the infant has:
      • Sufficient growth and development
      • Adequate nutritional reserves
      • Improved anesthesia safety
    • Early correction helps with:
      • Feeding efficiency
      • Speech development
      • Parent-infant bonding
      • Cosmetic and psychological benefit

Explanation of other options:

6 months (Option B): More appropriate for cleft palate repair, not cleft lip. Delaying lip repair till 6 months may impact early feeding and bonding.

1 year (Option C): Typically the age for cleft palate repair to support speech development, but too late for primary cleft lip repair.

18 months (Option D): Significantly delayed for cleft lip repair. At this age, speech development is well underway, and late repair may impair outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a sepsis patient in the ICU?
questions.solution:
Hyperglycemia is the most common metabolic complication of TPN, especially in critically ill septic patients, due to insulin resistance and glucose overload.

  • Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is used in patients who cannot absorb nutrients from the gastrointestinal tract.
  • In ICU settings, especially in sepsis, patients are in a hypermetabolic and insulin-resistant state.
  • TPN solutions contain high concentrations of glucose to meet energy requirements, and in septic patients, this can lead to profound hyperglycemia, which increases the risk of infections, impairs wound healing, and worsens outcomes.
  • Common Indications for TPN:
    • Short bowel syndrome
    • Severe malabsorption
    • Bowel obstruction or ileus
    • Enterocutaneous fistulae
    • High-output fistulas
  • Complications of TPN:
  • Hyperglycemia is particularly important to monitor in ICU patients as it correlates with worse clinical outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

Hyperlipidemia (Option A): Though TPN contains lipids, this is less likely an acute complication in sepsis compared to hyperglycemia.

Hyperglyceridemia (Option C): Elevated triglycerides can occur due to lipid emulsions in TPN, but it's not as common or significant in septic ICU patients as hyperglycemia.

Hypoglycemia (Option D): Can occur if TPN is suddenly discontinued or if there's insulin overdose, but during administration in sepsis, hyperglycemia is more likely.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of dyspnea, chest tightness and dry cough. His chest X-ray shows diffuse interstitial fibrosis. He has an occupational history of working in a factory for 20 years. Biopsy examination shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given history and the histopathology image showing dumbbell-shaped asbestos bodies, he is most likely suffering from asbestosis.


Explanation for other options:

Silicosis (Option B) is an occupational disease caused by silica or crystalline quartz exposure.

  • It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying.
  • Silicosis presents as small, rounded opacities in the upper lobe.
  • Results in calcification of hilar lymph nodes(eggshell calcification)
  • HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern due to interlobular septal thickening on the background of ground-glass opacity.

Anthracosis/coal workers' pneumoconiosis (Option C) is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners.

  • Alveolar or interstitial macrophages engulf the inhaled carbon pigment, which accumulates in the connective tissue.
  • On prolonged exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis, called complicated coal workers' pneumoconiosis.
  • The upper lobesof the lungs are commonly involved.

Berylliosis (Option D) is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to beryllium.

  • It is seen in people working on processing alloys for high-tech industries like aerospace.
  • Chest radiography shows nodules along the septal lines with hilar and mediastinal lymph node enlargement.
  • HRCT will show pulmonary nodules, diffuse interstitial fibrosis, and interlobular septal thickening.

choices.text: Saccular aneurysm of the distal arch
Dissecting aneurysm of the arch of the aorta

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with chest pain and hoarseness of voice for the past month. Based on the radiographic image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation and radiographic findings of a localised outpouching on the aorta are consistent with a saccular aneurysm of the aortic arch.
  • The patient presents with chest pain and hoarseness of voice, which suggests the involvement of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve-a phenomenon known as Cardiovocal Syndrome (Ortner syndrome).

Explanation for other options:

Dissecting aneurysm of the arch of the aorta (Option B) is incorrect because an aortic dissection typically presents with sudden, severe tearing chest pain radiating to the back, often in a hypertensive patient. Imaging shows an intimal flap and a double lumen, which differs from the focal outpouching seen in a saccular aneurysm.

Coarctation of the aorta (Option C) is incorrect because aortic coarctation leads to hypertension in the upper limbs, weak lower limb pulses, and rib notching due to collateral circulation. Radiographically, it appears as a narrowing of the aortic lumen, not an outpouching.

Stenosis of the aorta (Option D) is incorrect because aortic stenosis refers to valvular narrowing (typically at the aortic valve), leading to exertional dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope, rather than localised arch pathology.

questions.text: In a population with 500 live births, 12 stillbirths, and 9 deaths occurring within the first 7 days of life, what is the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR)?
questions.solution:
The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) is calculated as the number of deaths of live-born infants within the first 7 days of life per 1000 live births.


Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) = (No. of deaths of children (neonates) 0 - 28 days of life / live births) x 1000)

questions.text: Identify the syndrome associated with the chromosomal pattern shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows a pair of chromosomes with a paternal region deletion associated with Prader-Willi syndrome.


Explanation for other options:

Angelman Syndrome (Option A) occurs due to microdeletion or mutation of the maternal chromosome 15 (or paternal chromosome 15 imprinting).

Clinical Features:

  • Severe intellectual disability
  • Ataxia
  • Seizures
  • Characteristic "happy demeanour" with frequent laughter.
  • Obesity and hyperphagia are not typical features.

Rett Syndrome (Option C) occurs due to a mutation in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome, primarily affecting females.

Clinical Features:

  • Normal development initially, followed by regression with loss of motor and cognitive skills.
  • Stereotypic hand movements,
  • Severe intellectual disability.

Cri du Chat Syndrome (Option D) occurs due to deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion).

Clinical Features:

  • High-pitched
  • A cat-like cry in infancy
  • Microcephaly
  • Intellectual disability and distinct facial features.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels?
questions.solution:
Phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase can be caused by a deficiency of dihydrobiopterin reductase (BH2), which helps in the conversion of dihydrobiopterin to tetrahydrobiopterin. This leads to the failure of the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.

Phenylketonuria (PKU)

PKU is an inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This deficiency leads to an accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, including phenylpyruvic acid.


Mental Retardation:

  • Cause:Mental retardation in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylketones, which compete with other neutral amino acids for transport across the blood-brain barrier.
  • Management:To prevent mental retardation, a phenylalanine-restricted diet should be followed, along with tyrosine supplements.

Hypopigmentation:

  • Cause:Reduced melanin production in PKU results from a deficiency in tyrosine, a crucial component for melanin synthesis. This leads to lighter skin and hair colour compared to individuals without PKU.

Musty/ Mousy urine odour:

  • Cause: Due to the accumulation of phenylpyruvic acid (from excess phenylalanine) in the urine

    • Non-classic phenylketonuria Type II is characterised by a defect in dihydrobiopterin reductase.

Explanation for other options:

Tyrosine transaminase (Option A) causes Type II tyrosinemia, but does not cause phenylketonuria. Also known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia

Dopa Decarboxylase (Option B) is involved in the conversion of DOPA to Dopamine. It requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme.

Tyrosine hydroxylase (Option C) converts Tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA), does not cause phenylketonuria

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the mucosa of the nasopharynx
Loss of sensation in the maxillary area of the face
Loss of sensation in the jaw area
Loss of sensation in the scalp and nose

questions.text: On lesion of the nerve passing through the blue arrow-marked region. What will be the clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The blue arrow in the given image likely marks the supraorbital foramen, through which the supraorbital nerve (a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, CN V1) passes. Lesioning this nerve would cause sensory loss in the scalp, forehead, and upper nose region.

Trigeminal Nerve (CN V) and its Branches


Explanation for other options:

Loss of sensation in the mucosa of the nasopharynx (Option A): Incorrect because this is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not the supraorbital nerve.

Loss of sensation in the maxillary area of the face (Option B). Incorrect because the maxillary division (V2), passing through the foramen rotundum, supplies this region.

Loss of sensation in the jaw area (Option C): Incorrect because the mandibular division (V3), not the supraorbital nerve, supplies sensation to the jaw.

choices.text: Genetic testing for the TATP7B gene

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with jaundice, fatigue, tremors, muscle rigidity, behavioural changes, hepatosplenomegaly, and Kayser-Fleischer rings. Which of the following investigations is definitive for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The clinical presentation of jaundice, fatigue, muscle stiffness, tremors, behavioural changes, hepatosplenomegaly, and Kayser-Fleischer rings(most specific) suggests Wilson's disease, which is diagnosed by serum ceruloplasmin test.

questions.text: TTF-1 immunohistochemical marker is associated with which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
TFF-1 (Trefoil Factor 1) is an immunohistochemical marker for lung adenocarcinoma

Markers that are useful in lung adenocarcinomas are:

  • TTF-1
  • MUC1
  • Napsin A

Explanation for other options:

P40 and p63 are the Markers for squamous cell carcinoma (Option A)

Chromogranin is a marker for Small-cell lung cancer (Option C). It is a protein found in the secretory vesicles of neuroendocrine cells and is most commonly used as a marker for neuroendocrine tumours such as small-cell lung cancer, carcinoid tumours, and neuroblastomas.

Cytokeratins (CK7 and CK18) and Ki-67 are the markers for Large cell carcinoma (Option D)

questions.text: A patient with inflammatory bowel disease experiences severe abdominal cramping. Which of the following drugs is most likely prescribed for its direct spasmolytic action on gastrointestinal smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Dicyclomine is an antispasmodic medication that works by directly relaxing smooth muscles in the gastrointestinal tract, thereby reducing spasms and alleviating pain in conditions like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Antispasmodic Anticholinergics:

Scopolamine, by blocking muscarinic receptors in the GI tract, causes:

  • Reduced Tone and Motility: This slows down the passage of gastrointestinal contents.
  • Antispasmodic effect: Helps to alleviate spasms and cramps by reducing the tone and contractions of the gastrointestinal tract, but not as specific (Option B)as Dicyclomine in IBD.

Other antispasmodic anticholinergic drugs:

  1. Dicyclomine:Used as an antispasmodic for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and other gastrointestinal problems.
  2. Valethamate:Used to hasten dilation of the cervix during labour and as a visceral antispasmodic for urinary, biliary, and intestinal colic.

Explanation for other options:

Galantamine (Option C) is a cholinesterase inhibitor primarily used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. It does not exert a direct spasmolytic effect on the gastrointestinal tract.

Rivastigmine (Option D) is another cholinesterase inhibitor used in Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease. It has no direct spasmolytic effect on smooth muscle in the GI tract.

questions.text: A woman noticed neck swelling 2 months back. Clinical examination reveals a solitary nodule on the right side. What is the most appropriate initial investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Thyroid function tests (TSH, T3, T4) are the most appropriate initial investigation for a newly discovered thyroid nodule to assess thyroid hormonal status.

  • In the evaluation of a solitary thyroid nodule, the first step is to assess thyroid function through serum TSH, T3, and T4 levels.
  • This helps determine whether the nodule is functioning autonomously (suggesting a toxic nodule or hyperfunctioning adenoma) or is non-functioning (which has a higher risk of malignancy).
  • Approach to Thyroid Nodule:
    • Initial test: Serum TSH ± T3/T4.
    • If TSH is suppressed: Do a thyroid scintigraphy (radioisotope scan) to check for a hot nodule (typically benign).
    • If TSH is normal or high: Proceed to ultrasound and FNAC (Fine-needle aspiration cytology) based on sonographic features.
    • Algorithm:
  • This logical stepwise approach helps avoid unnecessary imaging and radiation in the early stages.

Explanation of other options:

Radioisotope I123 assay (Option B): Though useful for assessing nodule functionality (hot vs. cold), it is not the first-line investigation. It is done only after TSH testing, especially if TSH is low.

PET scan (Option C): Used to assess metabolic activity and identify metastases in known malignancies. It is not part of initial evaluation and is reserved for staging or identifying recurrence.

Radioisotope I131 assay (Option D): Primarily used for therapy in hyperthyroidism or thyroid cancer ablation, not for diagnostic evaluation of a thyroid nodule.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ultrasound finding in the given image?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly presents on ultrasound as absence of the cranial vault with exposed brain tissue and the classic "frog eye" sign, making it the most likely diagnosis.

  • Anencephaly is a lethal neural tube defect (NTD) resulting from failure of closure of the rostral (cranial) end of the neural tube around the 25th day of embryonic development.
  • Ultrasound Features:
    • Absence of cranial vault and calvarium
    • Absent cerebral hemispheres
    • Presence of bulging orbits, giving the classic "frog eye" appearance
    • Detected as early as 11-14 weeks in antenatal scans
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Failure of cranial neuropore closure → defective skull formation
    • Brain tissue is exposed and degenerates due to amniotic fluid exposure
  • Prognosis:
    • Lethal condition; most fetuses are stillborn or die shortly after birth

Explanation of other options:

Hydranencephaly (Option B): Cerebral hemispheres are replaced by CSF, but the skull and cranial bones are present. There is no frog eye appearance.

Spina Bifida (Option C): A neural tube defect affecting the spine, not the brain. It presents with signs like lemon sign (scalloping of frontal bones) and banana sign (curved cerebellum) on ultrasound, not absence of cranial vault.



Lissencephaly (Option D): A disorder of neuronal migration causing a smooth brain surface, seen later in gestation or postnatally; cranial bones are present, and there's no frog eye sign.

questions.text: A patient sustains a head injury in a road traffic accident and shows signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). Which diuretic is the most suitable for reducing ICP in this scenario?
questions.solution: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic commonly used in clinical practice to reduce increased intracranial pressure (ICP). It works by drawing water out of the brain and into the bloodstream, thereby reducing cerebral oedema and lowering ICP.

questions.text: A child presents with pruritic skin lesions and chronic diarrhoea. A gluten-free diet is recommended. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the patient's symptoms and the advice that was given, the child is most likely suffering from celiac disease, which is a sensitivity to Gluten.

Explanation for other options:

Whipple's disease (Option B) is a rare systemic infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei.

It presents with chronic didiarrhoeaamalabsorption, weight loss, and arthralgia. Skin lesions are not characteristic.

Crohn's disease (Option C) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting any part of the gastrointestinal tract. It often presents with abdominal pain, diarrhoea (often non-bloody), weight loss, and perianal disease. Skin manifestations like erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum may occur, but are not itchy.

Ulcerative colitis (Option D) is a chronic inflammatory condition limited to the colon and rectum. It presents with bloody diarrhoea, tenesmus, and abdominal pain. No itchy skin lesions are associated with ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A woman presents at 10 weeks of gestation and seeks medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). The appropriate choice would be?
questions.solution:
The combination of Mifepristone and Misoprostol is the safest and most effective method for medical abortion up to 10 weeks of gestation.

  • For first-trimester medical termination (up to 10 weeks POG), the standard regimen includes:
    • Mifepristone 200 mg orally: An antiprogesterone that sensitizes the myometrium to prostaglandins by blocking progesterone support to the pregnancy.
    • Followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally or sublingually 24-48 hours later: A prostaglandin E1 analogue that induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy.
  • Why this regimen?
    • High efficacy (>95%)
    • Non-invasive
    • Can be used safely in outpatient settings
    • Low complication rate

Explanation of other options:

Dinoprostone (Option B): Prostaglandin E2 is used mainly in second-trimester abortion or labor induction, not first-trimester MTP.

Oxytocin (Option C): Effective only in later gestation when oxytocin receptors are more abundant. Not used in the early first trimester for abortion.

Intrauterine Hyperosmolar Saline (Option D): Outdated method used for mid-trimester abortions; carries risk of complications like DIC and is not used today for early pregnancy termination.

questions.text: A patient with adenocarcinoma of the stomach undergoes distal gastrectomy. Which nutrient should be supplemented for the patient?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 supplementation is necessary after distal gastrectomy due to loss of intrinsic factor production and reduced gastric absorption.

  • In a distal gastrectomy, the lower part of the stomach is removed, often along with partial removal of the duodenum and associated lymph nodes.
  • One key consequence is reduced or absent intrinsic factor production, which is secreted by parietal cells in the stomach and is essential for Vitamin B12 absorption in the terminal ileum.
  • Without adequate intrinsic factor, patients are at high risk of developing Vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to:
    • Megaloblastic anemia
    • Neurological symptoms (e.g. paresthesia, ataxia)
    • Glossitis and fatigue
  • Thus, lifelong Vitamin B12 supplementation (parenteral or high-dose oral) is often required following gastrectomy.

Explanation of other options:

Vitamin C (Option B): Important for wound healing and immunity, but not specifically deficient after gastrectomy. Its absorption is not significantly affected.

Vitamin A (Option C): A fat-soluble vitamin absorbed in the small intestine. Although overall digestion may be altered post-gastrectomy, Vitamin A deficiency is not a primary concern unless there is associated fat malabsorption.

Calcium (Option D): Calcium absorption may be moderately affected after gastrectomy due to altered gastric acid production, but it is less immediately impacted compared to Vitamin B12, and deficiency usually develops more slowly.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with fever, rash, bleeding gums, and a positive tourniquet test. His platelet count is 25,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most important prognostic feature in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
In a suspected case of dengue hemorrhagic fever, platelet count is the most important prognostic indicator, directly correlating with bleeding risk.

  • This clinical presentation; fever, rash, bleeding gums, positive tourniquet test, and thrombocytopenia (25,000) ; is strongly suggestive of Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF) or Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP).
  • In such settings, platelet count is a critical parameter used to monitor the severity of thrombocytopenia and to guide risk of bleeding and decisions like hospitalization or platelet transfusion.
  • Key prognostic roles of platelet count in Dengue:
    • Risk of spontaneous bleeding increases sharply when platelet count falls below 20,000/mm3.
    • Helps classify severity and need for inpatient management.
    • Guides decisions on fluid resuscitation and platelet support.

Explanation of other options:

Elevated total leukocyte count (Option B): May indicate secondary infection but is not a key prognostic marker in bleeding complications of dengue or ITP.

Hematocrit (Option C): In dengue shock syndrome, hematocrit helps assess plasma leakage, but bleeding risk is more directly related to platelet count.

Peripheral smear (Option D): Useful for identifying morphological changes or ruling out leukemias or infections, but not prognostic in acute bleeding risk management.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia?
questions.solution:
Bochdalek hernia, a posterolateral diaphragmatic defect, is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), typically occurring on the left side.

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a developmental defect of the diaphragm that allows abdominal contents to herniate into the thoracic cavity, impairing lung development (pulmonary hypoplasia).
  • Bochdalek Hernia - Key Features:
    • Location: Posterolateral diaphragm (usually left-sided)
    • Cause: Failure of pleuroperitoneal membrane closure during embryogenesis
    • Clinical Presentation:
      • Respiratory distress in the neonatal period
      • Scaphoid abdomen (due to displaced abdominal contents)
      • Decreased breath sounds on the affected side
      • Mediastinal shift on imaging
    • Diagnosis: Antenatal ultrasound or postnatal chest X-ray
    • Management: Initial stabilization with ventilation, followed by surgical repair

Explanation of other options:

Hiatal Hernia (Option A): Involves stomach herniation through the esophageal hiatus. Typically acquired in adults, not a common form of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Morgagni Hernia (Option B): Anterior diaphragmatic defect through the foramen of Morgagni. It is less common and often asymptomatic or incidentally found.

Umbilical Hernia (Option D): Protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring, common in infants, but not a type of diaphragmatic hernia.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines should be kept at the lowest level?
questions.solution:
Compared to the other vaccines listed, the OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is kept at the lowest level in Intermediate-Level Refrigerators (ILRs).

Rota (Rotavirus Vaccine) (Option D): The Rotavirus vaccine is sensitive to temperature fluctuations and is generally stored in ILRs at 2°C to 8°C. However, it is often kept at a higher level in the cold chain to ensure stability.

questions.text: Identify the given fracture:
questions.solution:
Chance is a seatbelt injury that results from a flexion-distraction mechanism. It involves disruption of the posterior column structures and is frequently associated with intra-abdominal injuries.

  • Radiographic findings show a horizontal fracture through the posterior elements or disruption of the facet joints and spinous processes.

Explanation for other options:

Compression Fracture (Option A): The vertebral body becomes wedge-shaped due to the collapse of the anterior portion, with the posterior height usually preserved.

Burst Fracture (Option B): The vertebral body is shattered, with fragments extending into the spinal canal, potentially causing spinal cord compression.

Impacted fracture (Option D): Impacted fracture shows jammed together bone fragments leading to increased density at the site of injury. The image below shows an impacted Colle's fracture.

choices.text: Galactosemia due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase enzyme deficiency
Hereditary fructose intolerance due to aldolase B deficiency
Galactosemia due to galactokinase enzyme deficiency

questions.text: An infant presents with vomiting after feeding. A Benedict's test is performed and returns positive for a non-glucose reducing substance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A positive Benedict's test with vomiting after milk feeding in a neonate indicates classic galactosemia, due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase deficiency.

  • Classic galactosemia is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT).
  • This leads to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactose in the blood and tissues after ingestion of lactose (milk sugar).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Onset after milk feeding (contains lactose → galactose)
    • Vomiting
    • Diarrhea
    • Jaundice
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Failure to thrive
    • Cataracts
    • Intellectual disability if untreated
    • Reducing substances (e.g., galactose) in urine → positive Benedict's test
  • Investigations:
    • Positive Benedict's test (detects reducing sugars, including galactose)
    • Enzyme assay for GALT activity
    • Confirmed by genetic testing
  • Management:
    • Eliminate galactose/lactose from diet (soy-based formula)
    • Early diagnosis prevents irreversible complications

Explanation of other options:

Hereditary fructose intolerance (Option B): Caused by aldolase B deficiency, presenting after fructose/sucrose ingestion (usually post-weaning), not soon after milk feeding. Benedict's test may be positive for fructose, but timing of symptoms doesn't match.

G6PD deficiency (Option C): Leads to hemolysis, especially after oxidative stress (e.g., infection, fava beans, certain drugs). No vomiting after feeding or positive Benedict's test expected.

Galactokinase deficiency (Option D): A milder form of galactosemia presenting primarily with cataracts, without systemic symptoms like vomiting or hepatomegaly. Benedict's test may still be positive, but not as severe as GALT deficiency.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with a height of 4 feet has a karyotype, as shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
Based on the given karyotyping, there is a monosomy of the X chromosome, which is seen in Turner syndrome.

Explanation for other options:

Klinefelter syndrome (Option B) is male hypogonadism resulting from two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes. It is characterised by hypogonadism in males, gynecomastia, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, frontal baldness, narrow shoulders, wide hips and long legs.

Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome (MRKHS) (Option C) is characterised by failure of development of the uterus and the vagina, while ovarian function and external genitalia are normal.

Edwards syndrome (Option D) is caused by the presence of Trisomy 18. It is characterised by low birth weight, closed fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, microcephaly, micrognathia, cardiac and renal malformations, and intellectual disability. 95% of cases die in the 1st year of life.

questions.text: Identify the procedure commonly performed in patients with recurrent gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):
questions.solution:
360-degree Nissen fundoplication is the most commonly performed surgical procedure for recurrent GERD unresponsive to medical therapy.

  • GERD is caused by dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), allowing stomach contents to reflux into the esophagus.
  • While lifestyle changes and medications like PPIs and H2 blockers are first-line therapies, surgical intervention is indicated in refractory cases or when complications arise.
  • Nissen fundoplication involves a 360-degree wrap of the gastric fundus around the lower esophagus, strengthening the LES and preventing reflux.
  • It remains the gold standard surgery for GERD, especially when symptoms persist despite optimal medical therapy.
  • Key components of anti-reflux surgery:
    • Restore intra-abdominal esophagus
    • Crural (diaphragmatic) repair
    • Fundoplication - reinforcement of the LES
  • Fundoplication types:
    • Nissen (360°) - complete wrap, more effective long-term control of reflux
    • Toupet (270° posterior) and Dor (anterior) - partial wraps used in patients with poor esophageal motility

Explanation of other options:

Partial gastrectomy (Option B): Not a treatment for GERD; typically used for gastric malignancies or refractory peptic ulcer disease.

Esophageal banding (Option C): A treatment for esophageal varices in portal hypertension, not used for reflux disease.

270-degree Nissen fundoplication (Option D): A misleading term, this refers to Toupet fundoplication, which is a partial posterior wrap. It's used in selected cases, especially with esophageal dysmotility, but has higher long-term recurrence rates than full Nissen.

questions.text: A child presents with failure to pass stools and is diagnosed with Hirschsprung disease. Which of the following colon layers will show a congenital absence of neurons?
questions.solution: In Hirschsprung's disease, the congenital absence of neurons is seen in the submucosa (Meissner's plexus) and the muscularis propria (myenteric plexus). This occurs due to a mutation in the RET gene, which leads to the loss of Ganglion cells.

questions.text: From the radiograph provided, which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Chiari type 1 malformation is characterised by a small posterior fossa, which leads to herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum.

Explanation for other options:

Dandy-Walker malformation (Option B): Dandy-Walker malformation is characterised by a large posterior fossa and the presence of a posterior fossa cyst.

Vein of Galen malformation (Option C): The vein of Galen malformation is identified by an enlarged vein of Galen on imaging.

Corpus callosum agenesis (Option D): Agenesis of the corpus callosum refers to the absence or underdevelopment of the corpus callosum, but it is not seen in the given image.

Reference:

Arnold-Chiari Malformation - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct chronological order of steps in disaster management?
questions.solution:
• Impact: Refers to the immediate consequences of the disaster.
  • Response: Actions taken to address the immediate needs and mitigate further damage.
  • Rehab: Short for rehabilitation, involving recovery efforts and rebuilding.
  • Mitigation: Long-term strategies to reduce the risk of future disasters.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman with a previous LSCS presents with antepartum hemorrhage (APH) and required obstetric hysterectomy. A specimen (placenta invading uterine wall) is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis based on clinical history and the specimen image?
questions.solution:
Placenta accreta syndrome involves abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall, often necessitating hysterectomy when separation fails, especially in scarred uteri from prior LSCS.

  • Placenta Accreta Syndrome (PAS) is a serious condition where the placenta invades too deeply into the uterine wall, often due to a defective decidua basalis and absence of the Nitabuch layer.
  • It is strongly associated with:
    • Previous cesarean section
    • Placenta previa
    • Uterine surgery/scarring
  • In PAS, manual separation fails, leading to massive hemorrhage, requiring life-saving obstetric hysterectomy.
  • Placenta Accreta Spectrum Variants:
    • Placenta accreta: Chorionic villi adhere to endometrium
    • Placenta increta: Invade into the myometrium
    • Placenta percreta: Penetrate through serosa, possibly bladder
  • Management:
    • Total PAS (e.g., increta/percreta): Immediate hysterectomy, especially in patients with completed family
    • Partial PAS: Attempt conservative management (oxytocics, embolization, MTX)
    • Complicated PAS (e.g., bladder invasion): Hysterectomy with partial cystectomy if needed

Explanation of other options:

Uterine inversion (Option B): Involves turning inside-out of uterus after delivery. Not related to LSCS history or hysterectomy specimens.

Abruptio placenta (Option C): Premature placental separation. Does not require hysterectomy, nor show placental adherence to the uterine wall.

Placenta previa (Option D): Placenta covers cervix → painless APH. Managed via cesarean, not typically associated with hysterectomy or placental invasion.

questions.text: A patient presents with weakness of the right upper and lower limbs, along with left-sided facial nerve palsy and horizontal gaze palsy to the left side. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Foville syndrome results from a pontine lesion affecting the abducens nucleus, facial nerve, and corticospinal tract, producing ipsilateral facial and gaze palsy with contralateral hemiparesis.

  • The clinical presentation of right-sided hemiparesis (upper and lower limbs), along with left-sided cranial nerve VII palsy and horizontal gaze palsy to the left, is characteristic of Foville syndrome.
  • This syndrome arises from a lesion in the dorsal pons, typically involving the abducens nucleus (CN VI), facial nerve fascicles (CN VII), paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), and corticospinal tract.
  • Key findings in Foville syndrome include:
    • Ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy (due to abducens nucleus or PPRF involvement)
    • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron facial palsy
    • Contralateral hemiparesis from corticospinal tract involvement
  • These findings distinguish Foville from other pontine syndromes that may share overlapping features but lack conjugate gaze deficits.

Brainstem stroke syndromes

  • Foville Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN VI palsy + VII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis + Conjugate gaze paralysis towards the side of brainstem lesion
  • Weber Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN III palsy (ptosis, pupillary dilation) + contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal tract).
  • Millard-Gubler Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN VI and VII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis (No gaze paralysis - differentiates it from Foville syndrome) (Option A ruled out)
  • Benedikt Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN III palsy + contralateral ataxia and tremor (red nucleus involvement). (Option B ruled out)
  • Wallenberg Syndrome: Ipsilateral Horner syndrome, ataxia, dysphagia, and hoarseness + contralateral loss of pain/temperature.
  • Locked-In Syndrome: Quadriplegia and anarthria with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. (Option D ruled out)
  • Raymond Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN VI palsy + contralateral hemiparesis.
  • Dejerine Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN XII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis and impaired proprioception/vibration.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560896/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK544268/#

questions.text: A 27-year-old football player is brought to the ER after he collapsed due to sudden cardiac arrest. Based on the biopsy findings of his cardiac tissue, what is the most likely cause of his death?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a helter-skelter appearance, which is a characteristic feature of Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM):

  • Etiology:
    • Mutations in any one of several genes that encode sarcomeric proteins.
    • Most are missense mutations.
    • Most commonly in the genes encoding
      • Myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C)
      • β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC/MYH7)
      • Cardiac TnI, TnT, and α-tropomyosin
    • Characterised by
      • Myocardial hypertrophy
      • Poorly compliant left ventricular myocardium
      • Abnormal diastolic filling
      • Intermittent ventricular outflow obstruction.
    • It is the leading cause of left ventricular hypertrophy unexplained by other clinical or pathologic causes.
    • It is a leading cause of sudden death in the young.

Explanation for other options:

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option B) is characterised by left ventricular dilation and impaired systolic function. Histopathologically, it shows "ninja star nuclei", where cardiomyocyte nuclei are abnormally arranged in a star-shaped or irregular pattern due to fibre stretching. DCM also presents with cardiomyocyte hypertrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and myocardial fibre degeneration.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option C) shows signs of fibrotic changes in the myocardium.

Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy (Option D) shows infiltration of fat in the right ventricular myocytes.

questions.text: A young athlete presented with chest pain and dyspnea. His brother passed away due to sudden cardiac death. He is diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). A harsh systolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. Which of the following maneuvers will increase the intensity of this murmur?
questions.solution:
The Valsalva maneuver reduces preload, exacerbating left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) in HCM and thereby increasing the murmur.

  • This is a classic case of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM), an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by asymmetric septal hypertrophy, dynamic LV outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO), and increased risk of sudden cardiac death, especially in young athletes.
  • Genetic mutations:
    • β-myosin heavy chain: Associated with significant hypertrophy and earlier presentation.
    • Troponin T: May cause minimal hypertrophy but high risk of sudden cardiac death due to myocardial disarray.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • The thickened septum narrows the LVOT.
    • Systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve further blocks the outflow.
    • LV becomes non-compliant, impairing diastolic filling.
    • Myocyte disarray increases risk of arrhythmias, especially ventricular fibrillation.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Exertional angina, dyspnea, and syncope due to dynamic obstruction and poor diastolic filling.
    • Sudden cardiac death often during exertion, especially in genetically predisposed athletes.
    • Jerky or bifid pulse due to dynamic changes in LV ejection.
    • Harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, best heard at the left sternal border, which mimics aortic stenosis but lacks radiation to the neck.
  • Why murmur increases with Valsalva:
    • The Valsalva maneuver reduces venous return and preload, leading to a smaller LV cavity. This enhances septal-mitral valve contact, worsening the dynamic LVOT obstruction and increasing the intensity of the murmur in HOCM.

Explanation of other options:

Squatting (Option A): Increases both venous return and afterload, which distends the LV cavity and relieves the obstruction, thereby reducing murmur intensity.

Leaning forward with head down/up (Option B): This maneuver accentuates diastolic murmurs, particularly of aortic regurgitation, but has no significant impact on HOCM murmur.

Hand grip (Option C): Increases afterload, which reduces the gradient across the obstructed LVOT and diminishes murmur intensity in HCM.

Reference:

https://litfl.com/hypertrophic-cardiomyopathy-hcm-ecg-library/

questions.text: Identify the orthopedic implant shown in the image
questions.solution:
The implant shown is a Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS), commonly used for intertrochanteric fractures of the femur.

  • The Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS) is a sliding screw-plate system used to manage stable intertrochanteric femur fractures, especially in elderly patients.
  • Components:
    • A large lag screw: Inserted into the femoral neck and head.
    • A side plate with barrel: Fixed along the lateral femoral cortex with cortical screws.
  • The "dynamic" mechanism allows for controlled collapse at the fracture site during weight-bearing, which promotes healing by compression.
  • Indications:
    • Stable intertrochanteric fractures (AO/OTA 31-A1 and some A2 fractures)
    • Osteoporotic bone in elderly patients
  • Advantages:
    • Allows for controlled impaction at the fracture site
    • Simple and effective in appropriate fracture patterns


Explanation of other options:

Adynamic Hip Screw (Option B): Not a recognized term in orthopedics-nonexistent terminology.

Condylar Hip Screw (Option C): Used for distal femur (condylar) fractures, not for intertrochanteric fractures.

Intramedullary Nail (Option D): While proximal femoral nails can treat intertrochanteric fractures, the implant in the image is extramedullary, not an intramedullary nail.


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557514/

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration due to cobalamin deficiency

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with fatigue, tingling sensation in the arms, weight loss, and a history of polyuria. A bone marrow biopsy was performed, and the findings are shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of plasmacytosis in the bone marrow, along with symptoms like polyuria (from hypercalcemia), neuropathy, fatigue, and weight loss, strongly indicates multiple myeloma.

Bone marrow biopsy findings: Numerous plasma cells with eccentric nuclei, perinuclear clearing (hof), and basophilic cytoplasm consistent with plasmacytosis.

  • Multiple myeloma (MM) is a plasma cell malignancy characterized by monoclonal proliferation of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow, leading to overproduction of abnormal immunoglobulin or light chains (M protein).
  • Key Clinical Clues in This Case:
    • Fatigue and weight loss → Constitutional symptoms
    • Tingling in arms → Neuropathy (common due to paraproteinemia or amyloidosis)
    • Polyuria → Due to hypercalcemia (part of CRAB criteria)
    • Bone marrow biopsy → Shows >10% abnormal plasma cells (as seen in the image)
  • Diagnostic Features of MM:
    • Bone marrow plasmacytosis >10% (as seen on histology)
    • CRAB Criteria:
      • C: Hypercalcemia
      • R: Renal dysfunction
      • A: Anemia
      • B: Bone lesions (lytic lesions on imaging)
    • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP): M-spike
    • Urine: Bence Jones protein
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
    • Flow cytometry: CD138+ plasma cells
    • FISH: High-risk cytogenetics (e.g., 17p deletion)
    • Imaging:
      • Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia
      • MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
      • PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease

Explanation of other options:

Subacute combined degeneration due to cobalamin deficiency (Option A): Presents with neurological symptoms like paresthesia and loss of proprioception but does not cause hypercalcemia or plasma cell proliferation in bone marrow.

Subacute degeneration due to diabetes (Option C): Refers to diabetic neuropathy, which causes tingling and numbness but no marrow abnormalities or CRAB features.

Megaloblastic anemia (Option D): Results from B12 or folate deficiency, causes macrocytic anemia and neurological symptoms, but not hypercalcemia or increased plasma cells on biopsy.

choices.text: Administer beta blocker and intensive blood monitoring

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Stanford type B aortic dissection. What is the most appropriate initial management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Initial management of Stanford type B aortic dissection includes medical therapy with beta blockers and close hemodynamic monitoring to control blood pressure and prevent progression.

  • Aortic dissection occurs when a tear in the intima of the aorta allows blood to track between the layers of the vessel wall, creating a false lumen.
  • The Stanford classification divides dissections based on whether the ascending aorta is involved:
    • Type A: Involves the ascending aorta - requires surgical management.
    • Type B: Involves only the descending aorta - primarily managed medically unless complications arise.
  • Classifications of aortic dissection:
  • Initial treatment for Stanford type B dissection:
  • Beta blockers (e.g., labetalol, esmolol): reduce shear stress by lowering heart rate and blood pressure.
  • Target systolic BP
  • Pain management and intensive care monitoring are essential to watch for signs of progression or complications (e.g., organ ischemia).
  • Only complicated type B dissections (e.g., ongoing pain, rupture, organ malperfusion) require intervention such as endovascular stenting.

Explanation of other options:

Bypass graft (Option A): Used in surgical repair of Type A dissections or in complicated cases with organ ischemia in type B; not first-line for uncomplicated Stanford B dissection.

Percutaneous endovascular stent (Option B): Reserved for complicated type B dissections with malperfusion or rupture; not appropriate as initial management in uncomplicated cases.

Balloon dilation (Option C): Used in valvular or vascular stenosis, not indicated in aortic dissection and may worsen the tear by increasing intraluminal pressure.

questions.text: Which type of ulcer is given below?
questions.solution:
The ulcer shown is a venous ulcer, typically located in the gaiter area of the leg with irregular sloping edges and surrounding hyperpigmentation due to chronic venous insufficiency.

  • Venous ulcers are the most common type of leg ulcer and are usually caused by chronic venous hypertension due to incompetent valves in superficial or deep veins.
  • The classic location is the medial malleolus or the gaiter area (lower third of the leg above the ankle).
  • Characteristic features of venous ulcers include:
    • Irregular margins with a sloping edge
    • Shallow, moist base with granulation tissue
    • Brownish discoloration of surrounding skin (due to hemosiderin deposition)
    • Associated stasis dermatitis or lipodermatosclerosis
    • Pain may be mild or absent, typically relieved by elevation
  • Healing requires:
    • Leg elevation
    • Compression therapy
    • Management of varicose veins or deep vein insufficiency


Explanation of other options:

Arterial ulcer (Option B): Occurs over pressure points like toes or heels; has punched-out edges, pale or necrotic base, very painful, and absent distal pulses-unlike the moist, shallow venous ulcer.

Pressure ulcer (Option C): Occurs over bony prominences (sacrum, trochanter, heels) due to prolonged pressure, commonly in bedridden patients; not typically seen in ambulatory individuals.

Diabetic ulcer (Option D): Also known as neuropathic ulcer, commonly found on plantar surfaces or metatarsal heads in patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy; they are deep, painless, and often have a punched-out appearance.

questions.text: What is the correct composition and dosing schedule of the Shanchol vaccine?
questions.solution:
• Shanchol is a bivalent oral cholera vaccine given in 2 doses
  • This refers to a vaccine that targets two different strains of Vibrio cholerae and requires two doses for complete immunisation.
  • The Shanchol vaccine is bivalent, meaning it covers two different strains of Vibrio cholerae (01 and 0139) and typically requires two doses for full protection.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient complains of a persistent headache. A CT scan of the head was performed, as shown below. What is the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of the NCCT head shows a star of death appearance, which is a characteristic feature of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The white star-shaped region depicts blood surrounding the circle of Willis.

Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH)


Explanation for other options:

Epidural haemorrhage (Option B): EDH typically appears as a biconvex or lentiform shape on a CT scan.

Subdural haemorrhage (Option C): SDH usually presents as a crescent-shaped or sickle-shaped haemorrhage.

Intraparenchymal haemorrhage (Option D): Intraparenchymal haemorrhage will show a hyperdense pathology.
