questions.text: Linear growth of bone is disturbed when a fracture occurs in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
The epiphyseal plate (growth plate) is the primary site for longitudinal bone growth, and its injury disrupts this growth process.

  • The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate, is a layer of hyaline cartilage located between the epiphysis and metaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents.
  • It plays a critical role in longitudinal bone growth through endochondral ossification.
  • When a fracture occurs at the epiphyseal plate, it can interfere with the process of bone elongation.
  • This may lead to:
    • Growth disturbances
    • Angular deformities
    • Limb length discrepancies
  • These complications are especially concerning in pediatric fractures and are categorized under Salter-Harris classification depending on the severity and location of the fracture.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537199/

choices.text: Resistance to rifampicin and sensitive to fluoroquinolones
Mutation only to INH A and kat G gene

questions.text: For MDR-RR TB, what is the indication of short course bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Short-course bedaquiline-containing regimens are indicated for MDR/RR-TB patients who are rifampicin-resistant but fluoroquinolone-sensitive.

  • Multidrug-resistant / Rifampicin-resistant tuberculosis (MDR/RR-TB) is defined by resistance to rifampicin, with or without resistance to other first-line drugs.
  • The short-course bedaquiline-containing regimen (typically the 6-month BPaLM regimen) is indicated when the strain is resistant to rifampicin but remains sensitive to fluoroquinolones.
  • BPaLM Regimen Components:
    • Bedaquiline
    • Pretomanid
    • Linezolid (600 mg)
    • Moxifloxacin
  • WHO Endorsed Regimen Use:
    • Indicated when:
      • Confirmed Rifampicin resistance (MDR/RR-TB)
      • Confirmed Fluoroquinolone susceptibility
      • Age ≥14 years
      • Non-CNS involvement
      • No prior exposure to any BPaLM drugs >1 month unless drug resistance to them is ruled out
    • Not recommended in:
      • TB meningitis or CNS TB
      • Pregnancy and lactation
      • Age <14 years
      • Known exposure to BPaLM drugs for over 30 days without confirmed susceptibility

Explanation of other options:

Mutation only to INH A and katG gene (Option B): Indicates isoniazid resistance, but rifampicin resistance is required to define MDR/RR-TB. Without rifampicin resistance, the patient does not qualify for bedaquiline-based MDR therapy.

Rifampicin sensitive (Option C): First-line anti-TB drugs are used for rifampicin-sensitive TB. Short-course bedaquiline regimens are specifically for rifampicin-resistant cases.

Extrapulmonary TB like tubercular meningitis (Option D): Bedaquiline has poor CNS penetration, and tubercular meningitis is a contraindication for short-course regimens due to limited efficacy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with an irregular pulse and shortness of breath. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed in his jugular venous pressure (JVP)?
questions.solution:
In the JVP waveform, the 'a' wave represents atrial contraction. An absent 'a' wave is typically seen in atrial fibrillation, where the atria do not contract effectively due to irregular impulses.

Explanation for other options:

Cannon a wave (Option B):

  • They are large, prominent waves in the JVP that occur when atrial contraction is against a closed tricuspid valve, often due to arrhythmias like complete heart block.

Prominent X descent (Option C):

  • The X descent in the JVP represents atrial relaxation and descent of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole.
  • Prominent X descent is generally seen in conditions like tricuspid regurgitation or right ventricular failure.

Prominent Y descent (Option D):

  • The Y descent reflects the rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.
  • Prominent Y descent can be seen in conditions such as constrictive pericarditis or right heart failure.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with complaints of lethargy and persistent tiredness. On physical examination, he has noticeable perioral hyperpigmentation. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg and heart rate is 110 beats/minute. Laboratory investigations reveal serum sodium of 125 mEq/L and serum potassium of 5.5 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone with fludrocortisone is the treatment of choice in Addison's disease, as it replaces both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids.

  • The constellation of symptoms; lethargy, postural hypotension, hyperpigmentation, and biochemical findings of hyponatremia and hyperkalemia are characteristic of Addison's disease, i.e., primary adrenal insufficiency.
  • This condition results from adrenal cortex failure, leading to deficiencies in cortisol, aldosterone, and adrenal androgens.
  • The low cortisol causes fatigue, hypoglycemia, and hypotension, while aldosterone deficiency leads to hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and volume depletion.
  • ACTH levels are elevated due to loss of feedback inhibition, resulting in skin and mucosal hyperpigmentation.
  • Etiology:
    • Most common worldwide: Autoimmune adrenalitis
    • Most common in India: Tuberculosis
    • Other causes: HIV/AIDS, metastatic cancer, bilateral adrenalectomy, histoplasmosis
  • Investigations:
    • Random plasma cortisol: <100 nmol/L strongly suggests adrenal insufficiency
    • Short ACTH stimulation test: Cortisol <500 nmol/L post-ACTH confirms the diagnosis
    • Plasma renin ↑, aldosterone ↓: Indicates mineralocorticoid deficiency
    • Adrenal autoantibodies: In autoimmune cases
    • CT/MRI: Indicated if autoimmune antibodies are negative
  • Treatment:
    • Hydrocortisone: First-line glucocorticoid replacement
    • Fludrocortisone: Essential mineralocorticoid for sodium and volume regulation
    • Supportive therapy: Salt supplementation, patient education on stress-dose steroids
    • In acute adrenal crisis: IV hydrocortisone + normal saline + dextrose infusion

Explanation of other options:

ACTH (Option A): ACTH is used diagnostically in the short synacthen test, but not therapeutically. It has no benefit in Addison's disease because the adrenal glands cannot respond due to intrinsic damage.

Dexamethasone (Option C): Although effective as a glucocorticoid, dexamethasone lacks mineralocorticoid activity, making it inadequate as monotherapy for Addison's, where both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement are necessary.

Saline infusion (Option D): While useful in managing acute hypotension, it only provides temporary hemodynamic support. It does not correct the hormonal deficits, and without steroid replacement, symptoms will recur or worsen.

questions.text: A football player sustains a twisting injury to the ankle and knee during a match. There are no bony injuries detected on examination. The examiner is performing the test shown in the image to evaluate knee stability. Which test is being performed?
questions.solution:
The Lachman test is the most sensitive clinical test for diagnosing anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury, performed with the knee flexed to 20-30°.

  • The Lachman test is the gold standard clinical test for ACL integrity, especially in acute injuries like the twisting trauma described here:
  • Position: Patient lies supine, knee flexed to 20-30°.
  • Maneuver: Examiner stabilizes the distal femur with one hand and applies anterior force to the proximal tibia with the other.
  • Positive Test: Excessive anterior translation of the tibia compared to the uninjured leg, usually >5 mm.
  • Significance: Indicates partial or complete ACL tear.
  • Advantage: Preferred over the anterior drawer test because hamstrings are less active in 30° flexion, reducing false negatives.

Explanation of other options:

Posterior drawer for PCL (Option A): Assesses PCL by pushing the tibia posteriorly with the knee at 90°. Not appropriate for suspected ACL injury.

McMurray (Option B): Evaluates meniscal tears, not ligament injuries. Involves rotation of the tibia during knee flexion-extension.

Anterior drawer for ACL (Option D): Also tests the ACL, but less sensitive than the Lachman test due to influence from hamstring tension. Done at 90° flexion.

Reference:

Anterior Cruciate Ligament Knee Injury

Lachman Test

https://www.jospt.org/doi/pdf/10.2519/jospt.1995.22.6.263

questions.text: How does the graft get nutrition on day 3?
questions.solution:
On day 3, the skin graft primarily derives its nutrition through imbibition, a passive diffusion process from the recipient bed.

  • The "take" of a skin graft; meaning its survival and integration into the recipient bed occurs in three phases:
    • Imbibition (Day 0-3):
      • During the first 48-72 hours, the graft is avascular and survives by diffusion of nutrients, oxygen, and plasma from the recipient bed.
      • This process is passive and does not require vascular connections.
      • The graft appears pale and edematous during this stage.
    • Inosculation (Day 3-5): (Option B ruled out)
      • Capillaries from the graft align and connect with those from the recipient site.
      • Blood flow gradually resumes in the graft via reconnection of existing vessels.
    • Neovascularization (After Day 5-7): (Option C ruled out)
      • New blood vessels sprout from the recipient site into the graft.
      • This marks the start of long-term viability and integration.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551561/

choices.text: Secondary oocyte arrested in meiosis I
Secondary oocyte arrested in meiosis II
Primary oocyte arrested in meiosis I
Primary oocyte arrested in meiosis II

questions.text: After ovulation, the egg is released from the ovary. At what stage of meiosis is the released egg arrested?
questions.solution:
After ovulation, the secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II of meiosis II until fertilization occurs.

Oogenesis Timeline

  • Fetal life:
    • Oogonia undergo mitosis and begin meiosis I, becoming primary oocytes which are arrested in prophase I (diplotene stage) until puberty.
  • Puberty (monthly cycle):
    • Each month, under LH surge, one primary oocyte completes meiosis I, forming:
      • A secondary oocyte (larger cell)
      • A first polar body (smaller, non-functional)
    • Ovulation:
      • The secondary oocyte is released and enters meiosis II, but it is arrested in metaphase II.
    • After Fertilization:
      • Meiosis II completes only if sperm penetrates:
        • Formation of mature ovum
        • Release of second polar body
      • If fertilization doesn't occur, the oocyte remains in metaphase II and degenerates within 24 hours.

Explanation of other options:

Secondary oocyte arrested in meiosis I (Option A): Incorrect - the secondary oocyte forms after completion of meiosis I; hence, cannot be arrested in meiosis I.

Primary oocyte arrested in meiosis I (Option C): Incorrect - this arrest occurs before puberty, not after ovulation. The ovulated cell is a secondary oocyte, not a primary oocyte.

Primary oocyte arrested in meiosis II (Option D): Incorrect - primary oocytes never enter meiosis II. Only secondary oocytes do that after completing meiosis I.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers are given to all patients
Lung transplant is the best treatment if identified early
Lifestyle modification is the only possible approach

questions.text: An elderly female with a known history of scleroderma presents with shortness of breath. On clinical evaluation, her right ventricular systolic pressure is found to be 70-80 mmHg, and right heart catheterization reveals a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 35 mmHg. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Endothelin receptor antagonists are effective in improving symptoms and slowing disease progression in pulmonary hypertension, particularly in connective tissue disease-associated PH like in scleroderma.

  • This patient with scleroderma, dyspnea, elevated right ventricular pressure, and elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP = 35 mmHg) is likely suffering from pulmonary hypertension (PH)-specifically group 1 (pulmonary arterial hypertension) or group 2 PH (due to left heart disease) depending on underlying pathology.
  • Pulmonary Hypertension (PH):
    • Defined as mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) > 20 mmHg (updated threshold).
    • In scleroderma, pulmonary hypertension may result from:
      • Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) due to vascular remodeling (Group 1)
      • Interstitial lung disease with PH (Group 3)
      • Left heart involvement (diastolic dysfunction) leading to increased PCWP (Group 2)
    • Clinical Clues from the Question:
      • Elevated RV pressure (70-80 mmHg): Sign of significant pulmonary arterial pressure load.
      • PCWP = 35 mmHg (Normal = 6-12): Suggests post-capillary PH (Group 2) possibly from diastolic dysfunction or pulmonary venous hypertension in scleroderma.
    • Symptoms: Dyspnea, fatigue, and signs of right heart failure.
    • Therapeutic Approach:
      • Endothelin Receptor Antagonists (ERAs) (e.g., Bosentan, Ambrisentan) are approved for symptom relief and improved exercise tolerance in PAH, including scleroderma-associated PAH.
      • These block endothelin-1-mediated vasoconstriction and vascular remodeling.
      • Also used in combination therapy with PDE-5 inhibitors or prostanoids in advanced cases.

Explanation of other options:

Calcium channel blockers are given to all patients (Option A): CCBs are indicated only in patients with a positive vasoreactivity test (seen in ~10% of idiopathic PAH). They are not beneficial and may be harmful in connective tissue-associated PAH like in scleroderma.

Lung transplant is the best treatment if identified early (Option B): Transplant is reserved for advanced, treatment-refractory cases, not early-stage disease. Pharmacological therapy is preferred initially.

Lifestyle modification is the only possible approach (Option D): Lifestyle changes (e.g., sodium restriction, exercise, oxygen therapy) are supportive but not curative. Targeted pharmacologic therapies are essential for symptom control and survival benefit.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482463/

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness that improves with rest. She also complains of dysphagia and has engorged veins in her thorax. Based on the CT scan image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A thymoma is a tumour originating from the thymic epithelium and is the most common anterior mediastinal tumour. It is frequently associated with myasthenia gravis (MG), an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder. The symptoms and CT findings strongly suggest a thymoma:

  • Ptosis and muscle weakness improving with rest → Classic signs of myasthenia gravis, which is linked to thymic pathology in 30-50% of cases.
  • Dysphagia and engorged thoracic veins → Suggest compression of nearby structures, such as the superior vena cava (SVC syndrome), which is common in large thymomas.
  • CT findings → Typically shows a well-defined, anterior mediastinal mass, sometimes with calcifications or cystic changes.

Explanation for other options:

Pancoast tumour (Option B) is incorrect because Pancoast tumours occur in the apex of the lung, causing Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) and shoulder pain, but they do not typically cause SVC syndrome or myasthenia gravis-like symptoms.

Adenocarcinoma (Option C) is incorrect because lung adenocarcinoma usually presents with cough, haemoptysis, and weight loss rather than ptosis and fluctuating muscle weakness. It arises peripherally in the lung, not in the anterior mediastinum.

Small cell lung cancer (Option D) is incorrect because small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is more commonly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes like SIADH (hyponatraemia) and Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). While SVC syndrome can occur, fluctuating muscle weakness in MG is more typical of a thymoma.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the receptor with its primary sensory function?
questions.solution:
Pacinian corpuscles are specialised receptors that detect vibration and deep pressure. They are rapidly adapting and are found deep in the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.


Explanation for other options:

questions.text:
A 30-year-old patient presents with weakness. Laboratory values are as follows:
Blood pH: 7.3
Na⁺ : 134 mEq/L
K⁺: 2.8 mEq/L
Cl⁻: 113 mEq/L
HCO⁻: 12 mEq/L
BUN: 3 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
Urinary pH: 9.4
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis with hypokalemia, high urinary pH, and low serum bicarbonate is characteristic of Type I (distal) renal tubular acidosis.

  • Type I Renal Tubular Acidosis (Distal RTA) is caused by a defect in hydrogen ion secretion in the distal nephron, resulting in an inability to acidify urine despite systemic acidosis.
  • Key Findings in This Case:
    • Metabolic acidosis (pH 7.3 and HCO⁻ = 12 mEq/L)
    • Hypokalemia (K⁺ = 2.8 mEq/L)
    • Hyperchloremia (Cl⁻ = 113 mEq/L)
    • Urinary pH = 9.4 (inappropriately high → confirms defective distal acidification)
    • Normal anion gap: AG = Na⁺ - (Cl⁻ + HCO⁻) = 134 - (113 + 12) = 9 mEq/L
  • These features are diagnostic of Type I RTA, especially the inappropriately alkaline urine in the presence of systemic acidosis.
  • Additional Clues Supporting Type I RTA:
    • Often associated with autoimmune diseases, hypergammaglobulinemia, or drugs like amphotericin B
  • Long-term complication: nephrocalcinosis and renal stones
  • Treatment: Potassium citrate or oral bicarbonate supplementation

Explanation of other options:

Type II Renal Tubular Acidosis (Option B): Proximal RTA presents with low urinary pH (<5.3) after initial bicarbonate loss and typically has less severe hypokalemia. Urinary pH >9.0 is inconsistent with Type II RTA.

Type IV Renal Tubular Acidosis (Option C): Caused by hypoaldosteronism, it presents with hyperkalemia and mild acidosis. In this case, potassium is low, not high.

High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (Option D): Calculated AG = 9 → Normal, so this rules out HAGMA (e.g., due to lactic acidosis, ketoacidosis, renal failure, toxins).

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Characteristics-of-the-types-of-renal-tubular-acidosis_tbl5_328347660

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Diagnostic-criteria-for-renal-tubular-acidosis_tbl4_267744743

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519044/#

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with extensive third-degree burns requires skin grafting. What type of graft is used to cover the post-burn wound?
questions.solution:
A split-thickness skin graft is preferred in extensive third-degree burns due to its ability to cover large areas and allow donor site regeneration.

  • In cases of extensive third-degree burns, where the epidermis and dermis are destroyed, split-thickness skin grafts (STSGs) are the treatment of choice.
  • These grafts include the epidermis and part of the dermis, which are harvested from a donor site using a dermatome.
  • STSGs can be meshed to expand their surface area, allowing maximum coverage from limited donor skin, an essential advantage in patients with large surface area burns.
  • Key advantages of STSGs:
    • Donor sites heal spontaneously, allowing repeated harvesting.
    • Can be meshed to cover larger areas.
    • Easier graft uptake due to thinner dermis.
    • Common donor sites include the thigh, upper arm, and abdomen.
  • In contrast, full-thickness grafts (Wolfe grafts) are not suitable for large surface area burns due to limited donor site availability and more difficult graft survival.

Explanation of other options:

Full-thickness skin graft (Option B): Involves the entire dermis and epidermis. While it provides better cosmetic outcomes, it is unsuitable for large wounds due to limited donor site availability and poorer graft survival in avascular burn beds.

VAC dressing (Option C): Used for promoting healing in chronic or infected wounds through negative pressure therapy. It is not a grafting method and does not provide skin coverage for extensive burns.

Normal sumag dressing (Option D): Not a recognized or standardized method for burn care or grafting. This appears to be a non-specific or incorrect term in burn wound management.

References: Evolution of skin grafting for treatment of burns - ScienceDirect

choices.text: 3 cm posterior to the anterior fontanelle
3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.text: You're assisting with a ventouse (vacuum-assisted) delivery in a primigravida woman due to maternal exhaustion. The obstetrician instructs you to place the ventouse cup correctly. Where should the ventouse cup be placed?
questions.solution:
The ideal placement for the ventouse cup is at the flexion point, which lies 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle along the sagittal suture.

  • The flexion point is key in vacuum-assisted deliveries.
  • It lies on the sagittal suture, exactly 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle.
  • This point corresponds to the optimal location for the ventouse cup to facilitate delivery.
  • Why this location?
    • Promotes maximum flexion of the fetal head.
    • Allows passage of the smallest diameter (suboccipitobregmatic, ~9.5 cm) through the birth canal.
    • Ensures effective traction, reducing risks of:
      • Cup detachment
      • Head deflexion
      • Prolonged labor or injury
    • Ventouse is typically used in:
      • Prolonged second stage
      • Maternal exhaustion
      • Non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns (in certain settings)

Explanation of other options:

3 cm posterior to the anterior fontanelle (Option A): Incorrect - this is not equivalent to the flexion point and may result in deflexion of the fetal head during traction.

6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle (Option C): Incorrect - this places the cup near the anterior fontanelle, which compromises proper flexion.

Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle (Option D): Incorrect - although central, this is not the flexion point and may reduce the efficiency of traction.

questions.text: If words are interpreted differently by the sender and receiver during communication, what type of communication barrier does this represent?
questions.solution:
• A cultural barrier occurs when differences in cultural backgrounds, norms, values, or worldviews influence how words, gestures, or messages are interpreted.
  • Certain words, expressions, or concepts might hold different meanings or significance in different cultures, leading to misinterpretation or misunderstanding.

Various barriers to communication for health education


Linguistic (Option B): Linguistic barriers occur when there is a difference in the language spoken by the patient and the healthcare provider. If the misunderstanding is due to language differences or poor comprehension of medical terminology, then the barrier is linguistic. However, since the question suggests that the issue is related to understanding the meaning, and not necessarily the language itself, this is not the primary barrier in this case.

questions.text: What is the earliest age at which a unilateral cleft lip in a newborn can be corrected?
questions.solution:
Unilateral cleft lip repair is ideally performed at 5-6 months of age, ensuring adequate weight gain and tissue maturity.

  • Cleft lip repair is generally timed based on the "Rule of 10s":
    • At least 10 weeks of age
    • 10 pounds in weight
    • 10 g/dL hemoglobin
  • This rule helps minimize anesthesia-related risks and ensures optimal healing.
  • In practice, definitive surgical repair of the unilateral cleft lip is performed around 5 to 6 months of age, after sufficient facial growth and weight gain have occurred.
  • This allows for better cosmetic and functional outcomes with reduced complications.
  • Earlier correction also promotes better feeding, speech development, and social interaction.
  • Timing of repair:

questions.text: Which of the following is the anticoagulation of choice for a pregnant female at 36 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Unfractionated heparin (UFH) is preferred at ≥36 weeks gestation due to its short half-life and reversibility, making it safer around delivery.

  • During pregnancy, anticoagulation must strike a balance between maternal benefit and fetal safety.
  • At 36 weeks, labor can start anytime, so we need an anticoagulant that:
    • Does not cross the placenta (fetal safety)
    • Can be rapidly reversed (surgical/delivery safety)
    • Unfractionated Heparin (UFH) is ideal here because:
    • It does not cross the placenta -> safe for the fetus.
    • It has a short half-life and can be reversed with protamine sulfate → ideal for sudden labor or emergency cesarean section.
    • Can be stopped 4-6 hours before delivery, reducing bleeding risks.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of recurrent lung infections. A chest X-ray was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Recurrent respiratory infections along with dextrocardia on chest X-ray are hallmark features of Kartagener syndrome.

  • Kartagener syndrome is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired ciliary structure and function.
  • This ciliary dysfunction leads to poor mucociliary clearance, resulting in chronic respiratory tract infections.
  • Kartagener syndrome is classically defined by the triad of:
    • Situs inversus (including dextrocardia)
    • Bronchiectasis
    • Chronic sinusitis
  • It affects approximately 50% of patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia.
  • The underlying defect in ciliary motility contributes to:
    • Impaired clearance of respiratory secretions -> recurrent lung infections and bronchiectasis
    • Impaired mucociliary action in the sinuses -> chronic sinusitis
    • Abnormal embryonic organ rotation -> situs inversus
    • Sperm motility issues -> male infertility
  • Diagnostic criteria include:
    • Clinical history of chronic respiratory symptoms from early life
    • Presence of situs inversus or sibling with it
    • Evidence of reduced or absent mucociliary clearance
    • Electron microscopy showing ultrastructural ciliary abnormalities
  • Management is supportive, focusing on treating infections, physiotherapy, and in severe cases, lung transplantation.

Explanation of other options:

Cystic fibrosis (Option B): Though it causes recurrent chest infections and bronchiectasis, it does not feature dextrocardia or situs inversus. Sweat chloride testing and genetic analysis confirm diagnosis.

DiGeorge syndrome (Option C): Presents with cardiac defects, thymic hypoplasia, and hypocalcemia, not chronic lung infections or situs inversus.

Down syndrome (Option D): Can have respiratory issues due to structural anomalies, but does not present with dextrocardia or the classic triad seen in Kartagener syndrome.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3519024/

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/kartagener-syndrome

questions.text: In a study examining the relationship between diet and disease incidence, 80 out of 200 vegetarians and 100 out of 200 non-vegetarians were found to have the disease. Which statistical test is most appropriate to assess the association between diet type and disease occurrence?
questions.solution:
The Chi-Square Test is a non-parametric test used to study the association between two qualitative variables.


Explanation for other options:

Paired t-test (Option A):

  • This test is used to compare the means of two related groups. For example, it could be used to compare pre- and post-treatment measurements in the same subjects.
  • This is not suitable for comparing categorical data (diet type) with disease status.
  • It is more appropriate for continuous variables.

McNemar's Test (Option B):

  • It is used for paired nominal data to determine if there are differences in proportions.
  • It is often used in studies with a matched case-control design or in before-and-after studies where the same subjects are measured twice.
  • This test is not suitable for comparing two independent groups (vegetarian vs. non-vegetarian) about disease status. It is used for paired data rather than independent groups.

Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test (Option D):

  • This test, also known as the Mann-Whitney U test, is used to compare differences between two independent groups on a continuous or ordinal outcome when the data does not assume normal distribution.
  • This is not suitable for categorical variables like diet type and disease status.
  • It is used for comparing continuous or ordinal variables.

questions.text: A patient presents with headache and confusion and is diagnosed with a brain tumor. Family history reveals the presence of both brain and kidney tumors in close relatives. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of brain tumors, kidney tumors, and a positive family history strongly suggests Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome.

  • VHL syndrome is a rare, inherited autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene, predisposing affected individuals to a variety of benign and malignant tumors across multiple organ systems.
  • This includes brain and kidney tumors, which are central to the case described.
  • Common manifestations include:
    • CNS hemangioblastomas: especially in the cerebellum, leading to headache, ataxia, and vomiting.
    • Retinal hemangioblastomas: which may impair vision and may be an early sign.
    • Renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type): Occurs in ~70% of patients and is a leading cause of mortality in VHL.
    • Pheochromocytomas: Can cause hypertension, palpitations, and sweating.
    • Pancreatic cysts and neuroendocrine tumors
    • Endolymphatic sac tumors: May lead to hearing loss.
  • Diagnostic criteria (Dutch and Danish):
    • With a family history: One VHL-associated tumor and a first-degree relative with VHL.
    • Without family history: At least two distinct VHL-related manifestations (e.g., cerebellar hemangioblastoma and renal cell carcinoma). Genetic testing confirming a pathogenic variant in the VHL gene is definitive.
  • Management is multidisciplinary:
    • Surgical removal of CNS hemangioblastomas, retinal tumors, pheochromocytomas, and renal tumors.
    • Targeted therapies such as Pazopanib for advanced renal cancers and Belzutifan for VHL-associated tumors.
    • Kidney transplant may be needed after bilateral nephrectomy in cases with extensive renal involvement.

Explanation of other options:

Neurofibromatosis (Option A): NF1 and NF2 can involve brain tumors (optic gliomas or vestibular schwannomas), but kidney tumors are not typical features.

Li-Fraumeni syndrome (Option B): Associated with brain tumors, breast cancer, sarcomas, and adrenocortical carcinomas, but not classically with kidney tumors.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (Option D): A vasculitic disorder with asthma and eosinophilia; tumors are not part of its clinical spectrum, ruling it out in this context.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1463/#

https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms/def/von-hippel-lindau-syndrome

questions.text: A patient with oral cancer underwent radical surgery with PMMC flap reconstruction. What is the important indicator for adjuvant radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Extranodal extension (ENE) is a major criterion for adjuvant radiotherapy following surgery in oral cancer patients.

  • In oral cancer management, adjuvant radiotherapy is considered when certain adverse pathological features are present in the postoperative histopathology report.
  • These features are categorized as major and minor criteria.
  • Extranodal extension (ENE) where cancer has breached the capsule of a lymph node is a major indication for adjuvant radiotherapy, even if present alone.
  • The aim of adjuvant radiotherapy in such cases is to reduce the risk of local and regional recurrence and to improve overall survival.
  • The external beam radiotherapy is typically delivered postoperatively.
  • Indications for Adjuvant Radiotherapy:

Explanation of other options:

Multiple lymph node metastasis (Option B): It is considered a minor criterion. Alone, it is not sufficient to indicate adjuvant radiotherapy unless accompanied by at least one other minor criterion.

T3 tumor (Option C): Also a minor criterion. It may suggest an aggressive tumor, but adjuvant radiotherapy requires at least two minor or one major criterion.

Close margin (Option D): Defined as a surgical margin between 1-4.9 mm. It is a minor criterion and not an independent indication for adjuvant radiotherapy.

questions.text: A woman has just delivered a healthy baby via normal vaginal delivery. You are considering the timing of IUCD insertion for contraception. What is the earliest time at which an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) can be inserted?
questions.solution:
An IUCD can be safely inserted within 48 hours of vaginal delivery, ideally immediately after placental expulsion, to reduce the chance of unintended pregnancy.

  • Postpartum IUCD (PPIUCD) insertion is a widely recommended and effective method of long-acting reversible contraception (LARC).
  • The earliest and commonly practiced insertion times are:
    • Postplacental insertion: Within 10 minutes of placental delivery, before uterine involution begins.
    • Early postpartum insertion: Within 48 hours after delivery. This window is considered safe and convenient, especially if the woman is motivated for contraception and already in a healthcare setting.
    • Interval IUCD: Done after 6 weeks postpartum when the uterus returns to its non-pregnant state.
  • Advantages of PPIUCD:
    • Convenient and acceptable (done before discharge)
    • Highly effective
    • Immediate protection
    • No interference with breastfeeding
    • Less perforation risk due to thick uterine wall
    • Cost-effective
  • Disadvantages:
    • Higher expulsion rate than interval insertion
    • Mild discomfort or bleeding

Explanation of other options:

After 6 weeks (Option B): A common alternative, especially when missed earlier, but not the earliest time.

After 3 months (Option C): Safe, but unnecessarily delayed if immediate postpartum contraception is desired.

After 6 months (Option D): Too delayed and not standard practice unless medically indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the school health program under Ayushman Bharat?
questions.solution:
Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) tablets are provided weekly, not monthly, under the Ayushman Bharat scheme to prevent anaemia in school-aged children.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an initiative promoting school health.

  • Comprehensive health care for children from birth to 18 years by screening them for birth defects, diseases, deficiencies, and developmental delays (4Ds). (Option B ruled out)
  • Children identified with these conditions receive early intervention and follow-up care provided free of cost, including surgeries.

Anaemia Mukt Bharat - Providing iron and folic acid supplements - under WIFS (Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation) (Option D)

  • 5-9 year children: Weekly 1 IFA - 45 mg. of Fe + 400 mcg. of folic acid, sugar coated - pink colour. Biannual deworming with one tablet of Albendazole 400 mg done during the National Deworming days once in 6 months (10 of Aug and 10 of February of every year)
  • Adolescent boys and girls - weekly 1 IFA - containing 100 mg Fe and 500 mcg of folic acid and biannual deworming with 1 tablet of 400 mg Albendazole. (Option C ruled out)

Menstrual hygiene management: (Option A ruled out)

  • Sanitary pads are provided to girls
  • Usually in rural areas

Nutritional Services:

PM POSHAN (POshan SHAkti Nirman) Scheme

  • Previously called as National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools (Mid-Day Meal Scheme) (Option D)
  • Provides one hot cooked meal (⅓ Calories, ½ protein) to school children studying in Classes I-VIII in Government and Government-aided schools. To prevent dropouts.

Reference:

  1. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)
  2. Anemia: Mukt Bharat (AMB) | National Health Mission, Tamil Nadu, Department of Health & Family Welfare, Govt. of Tamil Nadu, India
  3. Operational Guidelines for Weekly IFA Supplementation Programme for the theCommunity-Basedd Intervention Guidelines for Anganwadi Workers
  4. PM Poshan

choices.text: Rheumatic heart disease with mitral stenosis
Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic regurgitation

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and pedal edema. Jugular venous pressure (JVP) shows a rapid Y descent. Auscultation reveals a high-pitched early diastolic sound. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of rapid Y descent on JVP along with a high-pitched diastolic sound suggests chronic constrictive pericarditis.

  • Chronic constrictive pericarditis results from pericardial thickening, fibrosis, and sometimes calcification, which restricts diastolic filling of the heart.
  • Over time, this condition impairs ventricular filling and elevates systemic venous pressures, causing signs of right heart failure such as pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and ascites.
  • Key features include:
    • Elevated JVP with rapid Y descent: Due to abrupt early diastolic filling before sudden pericardial restriction halts further expansion.
    • High-pitched diastolic sound ("pericardial knock"): Heard early in diastole, representing sudden cessation of ventricular filling due to the stiff pericardium.
    • Kussmaul's sign: Rise in JVP on inspiration.
    • Fatigue, ascites, peripheral edema: Reflect systemic venous congestion.
    • Atrial fibrillation: Common due to chronic atrial dilation and hypertrophy.
  • Investigations:
    • Chest X-ray and CT scan: May reveal pericardial calcification.
    • Echocardiography: Shows thickened pericardium and characteristic Doppler flow patterns.
    • Cardiac catheterization: Confirms equalization of diastolic pressures, helping differentiate from restrictive cardiomyopathy.
  • Management:
    • Medical therapy: Diuretics to manage symptoms.
    • Definitive treatment: Pericardiectomy, which removes the thickened pericardium. Though curative in many, it carries a significant operative risk and variable outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

Cardiac tamponade (Option B): Presents with prominent X descent and absent Y descent on JVP, due to restriction of diastolic filling. The presence of rapid Y descent in this case argues against tamponade.

RHD with mitral stenosis (Option C): Typically presents with a loud S1, opening snap, and low-pitched diastolic rumble, not a high-pitched knock or rapid Y descent.

Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic regurgitation (Option D): Produces a high-pitched decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard at the left sternal border, but does not explain the rapid Y descent or right-sided signs.

questions.text: What is the ideal pressure setting for vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation of other options:

The standard and most effective negative pressure setting for VAC therapy is -125 mm Hg, which optimizes wound healing by promoting granulation and fluid removal.

  • Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy is a form of negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) that enhances healing in both acute and chronic wounds.
  • The system uses a foam dressing sealed with an adhesive drape and connected to a vacuum pump to apply controlled negative pressure.
  • The ideal pressure setting is -125 mm Hg, which has been shown to:
    • Promote granulation tissue formation
    • Decrease local edema
    • Reduce exudate and bacterial colonization
    • Improve perfusion to the wound bed
  • VAC therapy can be used:
    • To secure a skin graft onto a recipient bed
    • For temporary coverage in open abdomen wounds
    • To manage chronic wounds, such as pressure ulcers or diabetic foot ulcers
  • The pressure may be applied continuously or intermittently, based on wound type and patient tolerance.

Explanation of other options:

60 to 80 mm Hg (Option B): This lower setting may be used in sensitive areas or in patients who cannot tolerate standard pressure, but it is not the ideal or most commonly recommended setting.

130 mm Hg (Option C): This is above the recommended pressure and may compromise tissue perfusion, potentially damaging fragile granulation tissue.

80 to 100 mm Hg (Option D): Though acceptable in certain clinical scenarios, this range is less effective than -125 mm Hg for most VAC therapy applications.

questions.text: A man presented with bilateral swelling of his legs, diarrhoea, and dyspnea. He has a history of consuming mustard oil from a local vendor. Which test should be performed by the health inspector to check for the adulterant?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests epidemic dropsy, commonly occurring when mustard oil is contaminated with argemone oil. Paper chromatography is the most sensitive test for detecting the presence of argemone oil in edible oils. It helps identify the adulterant based on the separation and visualisation of specific components.

Epidemic dropsy:


Methylene Blue Reduction Test (Option C): This test is used to measure the bacterial contamination of milk and is not relevant to detecting oil adulterants.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with an irregular 5 x 6 cm mass in the right breast. Histopathological examination reveals findings consistent with which of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
An irregular large breast mass with histology showing whorled stroma and leaf-like architecture is characteristic of a Phylloid (Phyllodes) tumour.

  • Phylloid (or Phyllodes) tumour is a fibroepithelial breast tumour that occurs most commonly in middle-aged women and presents as a rapidly growing, firm, and often large breast mass.
  • While it may initially resemble a fibroadenoma clinically and radiologically, it shows distinctive leaf-like (phyllodes) architecture on histopathology.
  • Size: Often larger than fibroadenomas (5-6 cm or more).
  • Histopathology: Biphasic tumour with epithelial-lined clefts and increased stromal cellularity forming leaf-like projections.

  • Classification: Benign, borderline, or malignant based on stromal atypia, mitotic rate, and margins.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed via core needle biopsy or excisional biopsy.
  • Treatment: Wide local excision with at least 1 cm margins; mastectomy may be required for large or malignant lesions.
  • Recurrence risk: Especially in borderline/malignant types within the first 2 years if not excised with adequate margins.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fibroadenoma (Option B): A benign, well-circumscribed tumour common in young women; lacks leaf-like pattern and typically doesn't grow as large or irregular as a phylloid tumour.


Mastitis (Option C): Presents with pain, redness, and fever in lactating women; histology shows inflammatory infiltrates, not a tumour.


Grade 2 breast tumour (Option D): Refers to invasive carcinoma, usually showing irregular malignant epithelial cells, not the stromal overgrowth and leaf-like pattern seen in phylloid tumours.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs will cause Torsades de Pointes if given with erythromycin?
questions.solution:
Astemizole significantly prolongs the QT interval, and when co-administered with erythromycin (a CYP3A4 inhibitor), it increases the risk of life-threatening Torsades de Pointes.

  • Torsades de Pointes (TdP) is a distinctive form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that occurs in the setting of prolonged QT interval, often drug-induced.
  • It can deteriorate into ventricular fibrillation and cause sudden cardiac death.
  • Risk factors include electrolyte imbalance (especially hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia), bradycardia, congenital long QT syndromes, and most importantly drugs that prolong the QT interval.

Astemizole

  • Astemizole is a non-sedating H1 antihistamine, previously used for allergic rhinitis and urticaria.
  • It has now been withdrawn in many countries due to its high risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
  • Mechanism:
    • Astemizole and its active metabolite desmethylastemizole inhibit the (Ikr/hERG) potassium channel, which is critical for ventricular repolarization.
    • This blockade prolongs the QT interval on ECG, predisposing to early after depolarizations (EADs) and triggering Torsades de Pointes.
    • When combined with erythromycin, a known CYP3A4 inhibitor, metabolism of astemizole is inhibited, leading to elevated plasma levels and exacerbated QT prolongation.
    • This interaction is synergistically proarrhythmic and potentially fatal.

Explanation of other options:

Levofloxacin (Option B): A fluoroquinolone that can prolong the QT interval on its own. However, it is less likely to interact significantly with erythromycin as it is not extensively metabolized by CYP3A4, and the risk of Torsades is lower than with astemizole.

Amoxicillin (Option C): A beta-lactam antibiotic with no known effect on cardiac repolarization or QT interval. It does not interact with erythromycin in a way that would cause QT prolongation or TdP.

Ceftriaxone (Option D): A third-generation cephalosporin that is cardiac-neutral. It neither affects QT interval nor interacts with CYP enzymes in a way that predisposes to TdP.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9165570/#

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8023479/#

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/astemizole

questions.text:
What is the median of the following data set?
Data: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8
questions.solution:
The median is the middle value of an ordered data set. Since there are 8 numbers, the median is the average of the 4th and 5th numbers (4 and 5). Thus, the median is (4+5)/2 = 4.5.

  • The median is calculated by arranging the variables in ascending order and taking up the middle value.
  • This applies when an odd number of variables are given, which is given by

  • The median is given for variables in even numbers by averaging the two middle variables.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with an ovarian solid-cystic mass on ultrasound. Which combination of tumor markers is most appropriate for further evaluation of the likely ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
These markers collectively help evaluate the most common ovarian tumors in young females, particularly germ cell tumors like yolk sac tumor, choriocarcinoma, and dysgerminoma.

  • In young women (especially under 30), the most common ovarian tumors are germ cell tumors rather than epithelial ovarian cancers.
  • The appropriate tumor markers help in diagnosing and monitoring specific subtypes:
    • AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein): Elevated in yolk sac tumors (endodermal sinus tumors).
    • β-hCG (Human chorionic gonadotropin): Elevated in choriocarcinoma and embryonal carcinoma.
    • LDH (Lactate dehydrogenase): Elevated in dysgerminoma, the most common malignant germ cell tumor in this age group.
    • CA-125: Typically elevated in epithelial ovarian cancer, but still assessed to rule out rare epithelial malignancy or in case of mixed pathology.
  • This combination is routinely ordered when evaluating ovarian masses in adolescents and young women to cover all common germ cell tumors.

Ovarian tumor classification:



Explanation of other options:

CA125, AFP, HCG, CEA (Option A): CEA is associated with gastrointestinal malignancies (e.g., colorectal cancer); not useful for evaluating ovarian germ cell tumors.

CA125, AFP, HCG, CA19-9 (Option B): CA19-9 is primarily elevated in pancreatic and gastrointestinal malignancies-not in ovarian germ cell tumors.

CA125, AFP, HCG, CA15-3 (Option D): CA15-3 is a tumor marker for breast cancer, not relevant in evaluating ovarian masses in young women.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fever, chills, and a productive cough. His vital signs reveal a BP of 150/88 mmHg, pulse rate of 110 bpm, respiratory rate of 18/min, and SpO₂ of 88% on room air. A chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of fever, cough with sputum, hypoxia, and lobar consolidation on chest X-ray is most consistent with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

  • This clinical scenario strongly indicates community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), which presents acutely with systemic and respiratory symptoms and radiographic signs of consolidation.
  • Etiology:
    • Typical pathogens: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus
    • Atypical pathogens: Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, Legionella, influenza virus
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms: Fever, chills, productive cough, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain
    • Signs: Increased respiratory rate, hypoxia, dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, bronchial breath sounds, crepitations
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Chest X-ray in CAP shows:
      • New lobar infiltrates/consolidation
      • May involve cavitation or multilobar disease in severe cases
    • Diagnosis:
      • Clinical + Radiographic correlation is key
    • Supportive tests: CBC, CRP, procalcitonin, blood cultures, sputum Gram stain and culture, urine antigen for Legionella and S. pneumoniae
    • Severity Assessment - CURB-65 Criteria:
      • Criteria Points
      • Confusion 1
      • Urea >7 mmol/L 1
      • Respiratory rate >30 1
      • BP <90 systolic or <60 diastolic 1
      • Age ≥ 65 years. 1
        • Score 0: Treat outpatient
        • Score 1-2: Hospital admission
        • Score ≥3: ICU care
      • Treatment:
        • Score Recommended Regimen
        • 0 Amoxicillin + macrolide/doxycycline, or monotherapy with either
        • 1-2 β-lactam + macrolide, or respiratory fluoroquinolone
        • ≥3 β-lactam + macrolide or β-lactam + fluoroquinolone (IV)

Explanation of other options:

Tubercular pleural effusion (Option A): Usually presents with pleuritic chest pain, dullness, and decreased breath sounds. Imaging shows blunted costophrenic angle or meniscus sign, not lobar consolidation.

Coal worker pneumoconiosis (Option C): Chronic occupational disease with small upper lobe opacities. No acute presentation with fever or lobar consolidation.

Silicosis (Option D): Due to silica exposure, it shows multiple small upper lobe nodules with possible eggshell calcification of lymph nodes. No acute systemic symptoms or lobar involvement.

questions.text: Identify the logo?
questions.solution:
The National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) logo features hands breaking free from chains, symbolizing liberation from stigma, and a lotus flower, representing purity and resilience, blooming amidst rays of progress. The logo reflects the program's goal of a leprosy-free India through breaking the chain of disease transmission and ensuring dignified care for all affected individuals.

Goals:

The NLEP's goals include:

  • Early diagnosis and treatment of leprosy
  • Disability prevention and medical rehabilitation
  • Reducing social stigma and discrimination

Reference: NationalLeprosyEradicationProgramme

questions.text: A physician is evaluating a patient for an occupational disease and finds that a coproporphyrin test has been performed. Which of the following conditions is most likely suspected?
questions.solution:
Lead poisoning disrupts heme biosynthesis, resulting in elevated urinary coproporphyrin, making it a key diagnostic clue.

  • Lead poisoning, particularly from occupational exposure, interferes with heme synthesis by inhibiting several key enzymes such as δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD) and ferrochelatase, leading to accumulation of heme precursors including coproporphyrin and δ-ALA (aminolevulinic acid) in the urine.
  • Investigations in Lead Poisoning:
    • Blood Findings:
      • Microcytic hypochromic anemia
      • Basophilic stippling of RBCs
      • Cabot rings
      • ↑ Zinc protoporphyrin (ZnPP)
      • ↑ Free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP)
      • ↑ Blood lead levels (>5 µg/dL is significant; >40 µg/dL may show symptoms)
    • Urine Findings:
      • ↑ Urinary ALA (>5 µg/L)
      • ↑ Urinary coproporphyrin (>150 µg/L)
      • ↑ Urinary lead (>0.25 mg/L)
    • Radiological Findings (especially in children):
      • "Lead lines" (dense metaphyseal bands) seen at long bone metaphyses due to inhibited osteoclastic activity.
    • Special Tests:
      • Calcium disodium EDTA mobilization test (especially in children) to assess response to chelation therapy.
  • Pathophysiology of Coproporphyrin Elevation:
    • Lead inhibits the enzymes involved in the conversion of porphyrin precursors to heme, including:
      • δ-ALA dehydratase
      • Ferrochelatase
    • This leads to an accumulation of porphyrin intermediates like coproporphyrin and ALA, which are excreted in urine and used diagnostically.

Explanation of other options:

Berylliosis (Option B): Occupational granulomatous lung disease due to beryllium exposure. Diagnosed via imaging and lung biopsy, not associated with porphyrin abnormalities.

Silicosis (Option C): Caused by inhalation of silica dust leading to nodular pulmonary fibrosis. Diagnosis is based on chest imaging and history of exposure, not urinary porphyrin tests.

Asbestosis (Option D): Chronic interstitial lung disease from asbestos exposure. Diagnosed via imaging (e.g., pleural plaques on X-ray/CT), not via heme biosynthesis markers.

questions.text: Identify the disease
questions.solution:
A unilocular, well-defined cystic lesion in the kidney on imaging is most consistent with a simple renal cyst.

  • Renal cysts are fluid-filled sacs that develop within the kidneys.
  • Most commonly, they are simple cysts, discovered incidentally on imaging and are usually benign and asymptomatic.
  • Causes:
    • Sporadic (simple cysts, most common)
    • Acquired (e.g., in patients on long-term dialysis)
    • Genetic (e.g., ADPKD)
  • Imaging Appearance:
    • Well-defined, thin-walled, anechoic (on USG)
    • No septations, calcifications, or solid components
    • No post-contrast enhancement (on CT/MRI)
  • Bosniak Classification (CT-based):
    • Category I & II: Benign, no follow-up needed
    • Category IIF: Requires follow-up imaging
    • Category III & IV: High malignancy risk - surgical management advised
  • Key point: Simple renal cysts (Bosniak I) are non-enhancing, thin-walled, and require no further management.


Explanation of other options:

RCC - Renal Cell Carcinoma (Option B): Usually appears as a solid enhancing mass on imaging; may have necrotic or cystic areas, but not a simple unilocular cyst.


ADPKD - Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (Option C): Presents with multiple bilateral renal cysts, often accompanied by hypertension, hematuria, and family history. Not a solitary cyst.


Hydatid cyst (Option D): Caused by Echinococcus granulosus, typically affects liver or lungs; renal involvement is rare. Imaging may show daughter cysts or water lily sign, not a simple unilocular cyst.

choices.text: Endoscopic dilation of the bladder neck

questions.text: A mother brought her 3-month-old male child to the hospital due to an inability to pass urine, with a similar episode occurring 15 days ago. Catheterization was performed without difficulty. A radiograph is provided. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are managed by endoscopic ablation (destruction) of the obstructing valves to relieve urinary outflow obstruction.

  • This 3-month-old male presents with urinary retention and prior similar episodes, and the radiograph likely shows a "keyhole sign", which is classic for posterior urethral valves (PUV).
  • This condition is the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants, seen in approximately 1 in 4,000 live-born boys.
  • PUV consists of membranous obstructive folds in the posterior urethra, leading to:
    • Bladder distension
    • Urinary tract infections
    • Hydronephrosis
    • Vesicoureteral reflux
    • Long-term complications like bladder dysfunction and renal insufficiency
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound: Enlarged bladder, bilateral hydronephrosis
    • MCU/VCUG (Micturating Cystourethrogram): Dilated posterior urethra and bladder wall thickening (keyhole sign)
  • Definitive management is endoscopic destruction (ablation) of the valves using a cystoscope.
  • Early intervention is crucial to preserve renal function.

Explanation of other options:

Partial resection of verumontanum (Option A): Typically considered in adult prostatic obstruction scenarios. It does not address posterior urethral valves, which are congenital membrane-like obstructions.

Endoscopic dilation of the bladder neck (Option C): Used in cases of bladder neck obstruction, not PUV. In PUV, the obstruction is distal to the bladder neck, so this procedure would not relieve the obstruction.

Indwelling catheter (Option D): May provide temporary bladder decompression but does not address the underlying cause (PUV). It's supportive, not definitive treatment.

questions.text: What is the typical time between fertilization and implantation in human reproduction?
questions.solution:
Implantation usually occurs about 6-10 days post-fertilization, with the average being 8 days.

  • After fertilization in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, the zygote undergoes mitotic divisions to form a morula and then a blastocyst.
  • This journey takes several days as the embryo moves towards the uterus.
    • Day 3-4 post-fertilization: Morula (12-16 cell stage) enters the uterus.
    • Day 4-5: Blastocyst formation begins.
    • Day 6-7: Blastocyst begins attaching to the endometrial lining.
    • Day 8 (average): Implantation is usually completed or actively ongoing.
  • Thus, 8 days is considered the average time for implantation to begin.

Explanation of other options:

2 days (Option A): Too early for implantation; the zygote is still in the fallopian tube undergoing cleavage.

14 days (Option C): Implantation should already be completed by this time; by now, hCG levels may be detectable in blood.

16 days (Option D): Implantation beyond this point is unlikely; if not implanted by now, the embryo is typically non-viable.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding von Willebrand disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Type 1 von Willebrand disease causes only mild to moderate bleeding symptoms and typically does not present with severe bleeding early in life.

  • Von Willebrand Disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, resulting from a quantitative or qualitative defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF), a glycoprotein critical for platelet adhesion and stabilization of factor VIII.
  • Classification of vWD:
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Mild bleeding (Type 1): Easy bruising, epistaxis, prolonged bleeding after dental procedures, menorrhagia.
    • Moderate bleeding (Type 2): Subtypes show qualitative dysfunction in vWF.
    • Severe bleeding (Type 3): Presents like severe Hemophilia A due to virtual absence of both vWF and Factor VIII.
    • Common symptoms:
      • Mucocutaneous bleeding
      • Post-surgical or dental procedure hemorrhage
      • Prolonged bleeding time despite normal platelet count
